As much as I would like to give this game a thumbs up, I simply can not, even given the amount of hours i have in to it because as the old saying goes, three's a crowd. 

For most of the 70 hours I had into Remnant 2 before this review I only had two gripes with the game that could be sort of overlooked due to the fun i was having
1. The games performance is not the worst ive seen, but given I have a rig well above the recommended requirements(radeon 6700xt, 32gb ram, ryzen 7 5700x) i did not expect to see so much stuttering, especially playing with my favorite class the summoner. No matter the settings i put the game runs very choppy, and the demand on the my resources is not warranted. Using 50% of my cpu  and 85%-90% of my gpu on low settings while still being very choppy, is just a joke. Especially considering the resident evil 4 remake only uses 20% of my cpu and 40% of my gpu and runs WAY better.

2. Being a souls-like genre you expect there to be a refinement to the movement of the characters, and your inputs to the characters. However, since the start of playing i could never shake the feeling there was a weird delay in the dodging and sometimes the switching of guns in the game. and sometimes that would mean the difference between life and death. now there are traits that directly influence those actions, however even after leveling those skills up to the max, there is still a delay in the inputs. This also, is not an internet issue because even offline both me and several other friends experience this issue.

But even with those two things in mind, i was , obviously able to overlook them because i was still having fun. However, the third reason for the downvote is the most unforgivable of reasons.

Finally after 70 hours of having fun and perfecting the build i wanted to fight the final boss and try to min/max everything i could to my liking and have the best shot of winning. they present me with the most non souls-like, insulting to the genre final boss i have ever seen. 

The final boss COMPLETELY nullifies any and all preparation or strategy reminiscent of other souls-like games and turns it into a IWBTG knock off and super over bloated length of a boss fight that almost leaves you with an epileptic seizure of an experience. IMO, the final boss completely makes the other 70 hours of  time i invested into the game feel useless. To make a game that is built around almost an ARPG level of building a character and then the final boss of the game throw that out the window, seems like a poor choice.

Remnant 2 is good game just as Remnant: From the Ashes is. So if you liked first one you will like this one to.

Like the first gamet this game is not a shoot and loot game. This is more shoot and scavenge game. That means most gear you will get by exploring and discovering secrets.

There are some new mechanics and boss fights are better than in first game but essentially this is the same game play as it was in first game.
So treat this game as huge expansion and updated game play of first one.

Difficulty:

Short explanation: Apocalypse difficulty is for meta builds and on every other difficulty any build is ok.
Long explanation: When it comes to game difficulty almost all of them are well balanced except for the Apocalypse difficulty where if you ask me they went over board with damage scaling. Even in first Remnant game enemies did not hit this hard but then again we also could upgrade armor back then.
On Apocalypse difficulty it comes to two game play styles: dodging all the attacks or wearing heaviest armor for damage protection so that you don't get one shotted.
On Apocalypse difficulty even a little mob will take more than half of your HP or almost all.
So if you want fair challenge and use what ever gear you want or build Nightmare difficulty is where most of us casual players will end up.

Co-op:

Do not know why but multiplayer runs better in first Remnant game if you ask me.
There are a lot of ping and lag problems that will mess up your timing for dodging enemy attacks if you are not a host.
At least they finally implemented region lock that you can select so it helps with the lag and ping.
Solo play is just easier for me then multiplayer with random strangers. Special on higher difficulties and since difficulty also scale up with how many people are in co-op.

DLCs:

1. The Awakened King:
The new random world map for Losomn is great.
I finally have feeling when I am traveling or looking at World Stone map that I am actually traveling the land and not just loading from area to an area. Hope they will do more maps like this in future.
We also get 20 more trait points and new gear.

Performance:

Keep it in mind that some people are experiencing performance problems.
Personally I have no problems with the game performance but it may be different for you depending what kind of PC you have.

Conclusion:

Putting performance aside this is a good game and an improvement from the first game in some game-mechanics and boss fights at least for me personally.

Remnant 2 refines most of what made the first game good and add some welcome changes as well. If you enjoyed the first game or souls likes you'll probably enjoy this one too.

The following is a list of small complaints/nitpicks in case the developers see:

-The game really needs a "curated campaign" option after you beat it once where you can select which version of each world you start in and which dungeons(within the available pool) you get. Imo this would make getting certain traits and items much less tedious, and increase replay-ability a lot, if I can guarantee a play through is going to be completely different, that's going to be way more engaging than hoping that I don't roll a bunch of the same dungeons/world starts.

-Not going to lie, going back to Yaesha was super disappointing. Both Losom and N'Erud felt very well fleshed out and interesting with their own self contained stories, but Yaesha felt like a complete retread of the first game, and not an improvement on it either. The possibilities are literally endless, so it just feels super lazy to visit a world we've already been to.

-Another location complaint is Root Earth, the complete lack of any story besides [i] root [/i] was super disappointing, and honestly felt really half baked. It's the last little bit of the game, so I can give it a pass, but the game definitely doesn't end on a high note.

-Having more scrap drop from the destructible environment set pieces than from the enemies you kill feels bad and definitely needs a rework. Don't get me wrong, I love to break stuff in the environment and get goodies, but when it feels wasteful not to break every little thing in an area because it will literally net you triple what the mobs gave you and you're constantly strapped for scrap then there's an issue in the design. 

-The main story is bad, teenage writing level at best. This would be a much bigger detractor, except it's mostly just an excuse to get you to travel to the different worlds, and the storytelling of each of those(minus Root Earth) is significantly better.

-Melee isn't really viable like the first game, too many bosses are completely impractical to hit. At the same time tough, if that's the cost of better boss fight designs then I can't complain. 

-Final boss phase 2 hurts my eyes/brain. This is probably just a me problem, but any time the screen is 95% red for more than a couple seconds I start to get a headache, and Root Earth's whole grey-scale + red leading up to it was not doing me any favors either. 

None of these complaints are worth me not recommending the game, but it sure as heck would be a much better experience with them being improved, so one can hope!

I wanted to like this game more but unfortunately there is some frustrating design and the graphic optimization was not good. This is more so in the beginning of the game but it does gets better when progressing forward.

 Enemy Design:

Enemy focus seems to be quantity over quality where you get the same kind of enemies and constant elite spawns when trying to venture around the map in certain areas. I know Yaesha was very bad with the elite spawns and it was the first map rolled out in the campaign for me. They were bullet sponges and I found myself running out of ammo. There were other areas where the enemies were a little more diverse but it does get monotonous when you have to replay in adventure mode to explore all the content.

Items:

There were a lot of different mods and weapons but good luck gathering all the scrap needed to upgrade your gear and buy new items. Resources take a long time to gather for new weapon upgrades, items etc. and that's even with the amulet that gives you double scrap.   The farming spots are hardly even worth the effort. Better to just re-roll adventure mode and playthrough an area again. 

 I did however enjoy the different variety of weapons to try later on in the game and some of the other mods. 

Boss Design:

 Whew, they definitely don't make them easy. There were a fair amount of bosses I really enjoyed fighting against and felt the mechanics required to fight them were fair. I also liked that there are a fair amount of mini-bosses in the game as well. Other ones, what really made things frustrating is that you have a limited field of view to see what is coming at you, damage sponges,  and the few that can one shot kill. 

There was one boss that almost made me quit playing the game which was Labyrinth boss. The worst thing is this boss is near the beginning of the campaign and its not even a real boss fight. Just a really gimmicky puzzle that forces you to memorize the walkway patterns and jump around between platforms.

 Combat:

 I have to give this a big thumbs up as there are a lot of different classes, builds, and fighting styles to choose from.  You get to spend points leveling up your different traits, learn new traits as you progress, and automatically level up the class you picked. You get three different skills to choose from, a special ability, passive skills, and other attributes that are upgraded from the class leveling.

 On top of all this, you level up a secondary class on top of the first class you picked to make a hybrid build for your character. Adds a lot of variability to the way combat works.

Maps:

  I feel like there is a fair amount of exploration but only if you roll an adventure mode story with your on-going main story campaign. There is some cool designed areas but the problem is, you find yourself going through the same areas over and over just to explore other parts that were undiscovered. The side areas in the maps all have very similar design along with the enemies being monotonous with too much quantity. 

Story:

 Not a whole lot to write home about. Got kind of bored with it and didn't really follow everything.

Graphics:

Another game that is poorly optimized. I was shocked at first because I was only getting 20 to 25 fps with all the graphic settings set to low/medium until I turned on a setting called "upscaling". That was the only saving grace to the games graphics but it came at a cost making the game look more grainy when it was set to performance mode. The game most of the time was holding 60+ fps majority of the game and a few areas around 50-60 fps.

Crashes/Bugs:

 Didn't really have a ton of issues personally with this. The game has crashed on me a couple times and thankfully did not delete any saved data. The game cannot run MSI afterburner or it will crash. I have heard others have major issues with the game crashing.

 The only other issue I had was the map rotating around when using a controller, and a couple menus which was pretty annoying at times. I'm not sure what the issue was as none of my other games have stick drift happening from the controller.

This game does not play well with 13th/14th gen CPU's (mine is the 13900k). It constantly crashes with low video memory errors and low level fatal errors - particularly during shader compilation when your CPU is pushed its hardest. There are threads for this everywhere on steam! (just type in low video memory and see for yourself...). Same issue persists with Robocop Rogue CIty, Lords of the Fallen 2023 and even Banishers Ghosts of New Eden.

If you plan on buying this game, then you will want to accept that you will very likely have to underclock your CPU to avoid crashing... You have been warned...

My Fix (thanks to a lot of online advice): Download Intel Extreme Tuning Utility. Then change your performance core ratio back to 53x (or even 52x if your having ongoing issues).

Its been months and this is still an issue VERY FRUSTRATING!!!

Remnant is not dark souls with guns, it's something much different all together. The campaign is relatively short, about 20 hours and takes place over the course 4 different acts, each with their own unique and beautiful world to explore, dungeons to find, puzzles to solve, secrets to uncover, and enemies to overcome. There are several different classes to choose from and Remnant gives you the freedom to mix and match classes on the fly to fit your play style or circumstance. There are plenty of weapons to find and create and you can equip mods to them which is the equivalent to an ash of war if you've played elden ring; Mods give your weapons various abilities and most of the boss weapons have mods that are specific to that weapon. There are also a variety of accessories and armors to collect as you explore the world, some much harder to come across than others. Although the campaign is short, replay ability is high because certain parts of the world are procedural generated and you may experience a new layout or mini boss than in your previous playthrough; I've done 3 or 4 playthroughs now and I'm still finding things I totally missed and with a heavy emphasis on co-op you and your friends can run dungeons for hours or play through the entire campaign together. Also there are definitely illusory walls in this game so stay sharp! If you're reading this because you've been thinking about buying this game or it's currently on sale and you decided to check it out, do me a favor and do not hesitate, just buy it and get the deluxe edition; you're going to want the dlc, trust me.

Honestly this game reminded me of the secret world more than anything else I've played and yeah, I definitely see inspiration from dark souls scrattered throughout but Remnant is it's own game through and through, I appreciate the vision the developers had for this game, and they have definitely made a loyal fan out of me

Remnant I started off as "Dark Souls with guns" but the series is evolving into its own thing. 
Remnant II is the logical next step that keeps most of its working formula the same while fine tuning and improving parts that were lacking. 
Multiple difficulty levels allow you to adjust the experience to your skill level and willingness to put work into it.
It's a also a game that will hide large parts of its content if you are not playing through it paying attention, with some things so obscurely hidden that it's figuratively impossible to find them out without looking something up. But that also means there is a lot of replay value and rewards for putting in the time with it.
Admittedly this can be a double-edged sword, though, when the item you know you need is hidden behind multi-stage RNG world rolls that do not make it difficult to get, just time consuming.

It's a great soulslike when you play it solo and good fun while keeping up the challenge for the most part when playing in Co-op while adding the layer of party composition on top of the build composition.

Definitely recommended unless you do not enjoy soulslikes.

The biggest issue I have with this game is the weapon and archetype unlocks. If you just played through the game normally, you'd likely be disappointed with the amount of new weapons you unlocked. This is because they have intentionally made these unlocks so obtuse that you would never feasibly find them without a guide.

For example, there is a weapon that is unlocked by clearing a pipe then waiting 90 minutes for the room to flood. Another involves completing a world, then backtracking the level and jumping off the map to teleport to an extremely well hidden path. There's an archetype that involves running into toxic gas that covers the perimeter of the map to find an item hidden out there that you cannot see from a safe area.

Check out how to unlock the Archon class for the absolute epitome of what I'm talking about here.

I don't mind a game having one or two of these things, but it is so abundant here. And these aren't little niceties, they are cornerstones of your build. Questionable, even bad game design in my opinion.

Pros:
-Story is very focused on and flushed out compared to Remnant 1
-Dozens of RNG-Based gear spawns that vary from world to world, as well as bosses to provide variety across numerous runs
-Pretty straight forward game play mechanics, easy to pick up and know everything if you've played the first game
-Unique world bosses that some times have two different fight scenarios and rewards based on how you approach them
-Each of the three worlds that you visit along your play through have completely distinct environments and challenges, in terms of what monsters you face as well as what plight they need your assistance with
-Different classes (Archetypes) for you to choose two of to mix and match to suit your play style, with some being hidden within the game or locked behind special scenarios

Cons:
-Feels like they focused more on the story than the actual game play aspect of this game compared to Remnant 1
-So many RNG-Based things that some times you end up spending an entire day just to get the one piece of gear you want
-Almost no armour sets in this game compared to the first one, and none of them provide any set bonuses at all. They completely removed that fun mechanic that they had in the first game
-Rings? Oh, it's got rings... The base game has 145 rings and the DLC adds another 20-25 rings to the game, 75% of which you'll *never* use, and with no way to sell/store gear it just clogs up the inventory
-The guns are almost too unique, with there only being three or four that don't seem like they were made for a very niche scenario, so unless you want to switch weapons every few minutes your options are rather limited if you want just a decent all-round weapon
-Did I mention how many useless rings there are? Could have easily just brought back armour set bonuses from the first game and gotten rid of over half of the rings

TL:DR; 6/10
-First game, Remnant: From the Ashes was *so* much better compared to this game that it almost seems like a downgrade when you compare the two. If you're really interested in trying this game out and you have not played the first one, I sincerely urge you to just buy the first game instead. The story in that one isn't as flushed out as in this one, but man does the game play of it just feel so much better, in both terms of both (re-)playability and variety of gear.
-This game isn't bad, but just leaves much to be desired when compared to the first one

Plays like if Destiny was made to be intentionally obtuse and feel clunky, which is a remarkably odd choice considering I can just uninstall this and go play Destiny instead. Story is soulless and generic, environments are drab and bland, combat feels boring and repetitive until you grind through enough gameplay to unlock actual gameplay elements which is again, odd design direction considering almost every other looter shooter makes you enjoy playing the game initially, rather than making you feel like you're playing a character with no abilities, Parkinsons disease, and a worthless pea shooter for a gun for 30 hours. Perhaps a game for people with masochistic tendencies, but for me it misses everywhere the games it's trying to emulate hit, INCLUDING the original game, which is baffling.

They doubled down on the game scaling with your power level but the problem is that you don't get increased exp, drops, or anything to compensate. 

Once the game scales any weapons you find that are below the weapon in your inventory enchantment level cannot be used effectively until you level them up to the same level effectively locking you out of trying new weapons. 

The optimal play is to NOT enchant anything but your weapon skills until the final level  because the the game rolls the power level of an area when you load it for the first time. So the game punishes the player for engaging with the system. Games like this is why  automatic level scaling has a bad reputation. This is almost as bad as the Last Remant.

You have to reroll the world in adventure mode and hope you get the triggers/scenarios and you don't know until you get to that map/area.

The game play itself is fun but they worked very hard to force the player to play multiple times instead of making an incredible systems where you want to engage with it more. Also, the story is *lmao*

Quick and simple review.

If you liked Remnant 1, this is an a must buy. If you like souls games, this is most likely an easy purchase, especially if you used ranged or magic builds. For those who are unsure, this game is basically Dark Souls with guns and 3-player FULL co-op. (While you only progress the host world you join, you get to keep all the loot you find and take it with you back into your own world.) Even for those who are shy of the Souls-like genre, this game comes with a "Normal" difficulty that has less challenging enemies so you can get used to the gameplay loop and turn the difficulty up later if you want.

I recommend this game at any price, and the DLC is an obvious purchase if you want more dungeons, items, and content. Buy on sale if you're unsure but I doubt you will be disappointed.

This is one of the most fun games I have ever played.  I had no experience whatsoever with souls like games, but I did like shooters so I bought it after watching a short review video.

I started the main part of the campaign in Losomn on survivor difficulty in the Beatific Palace story line.  I proceeded to die no less than 20 times trying to get through the first main door.  Normally, I would give up at that point saying to myself the game wasn't for me, but I was really intrigued by the possibilities of the game.  So, I kept trying and I am so glad I did.

I have only played solo and have since beat the game on Apocalypse multiple times and also beat veteran mode on hardcore difficulty.  I have leveled every archetype to level 10, except for invader.  I explored a huge majority of the game and obtained a huge majority of items as well.  I have geniunely enjoyed all 3 worlds and the labyrinth.  I have enjoyed the dungeons and boss fights.  I enjoy the item hunt and making builds.  The overall gameplay loop is very satisyfing.

General Gameplay - 10/10
I really enjoy shooters and this one did not disappoint.  I enjoyed learning how to dodge and weave in damage between dodges.  The overall gunplay, abilities, and mechanics are responsive and satisfying. 

I enjoy the world being broken up into larger overworld maps and lots of dungeons.  I can pick this game up and play just long enough to do a dungeon or I can go for a several hour session and both can be fun.  I don't feel obligated to play for a long time, but don't get bored of it after a short time either. 

The game has just the right amount of stress and release.  I can play an overpowered build and just mow through dungeons and bosses to release the stress of the day.  Or, I can up the difficulty or change to an experimental build and raise the heart rate a little.  I did my veteran hardcore run to get Savior after over 200 hours in the game.  Going through Root Earth on that character got me as close to the stressed out feeling of the original Halo when I was first introduced to the Flood as I have ever felt in a game in over 20 years.  I was stressed and scared, but in a good way.  And it felt great to finally beat the last boss.  Just like it felt so good to finally be above ground facing the covenant instead of underground with the flood.

Items & Builds - 10/10
I haven't played another game that got me hooked on the item hunt as good as Remnant 2.  Various gear pieces can have a wide variety of impact on how you play the game.  They can be as generic as small constant damage bonuses to something that drastically alters how you play the game.  It may not have the depth of customization where spreadsheets are necessary, but there is still a lot of customization that make theorycrafting, hunting for items, and executing an experimental build very enjoyable.  

Although I haven't fully leveled invader yet, I can say that the archetypes are well designed.  They each offer different ways to play and provide synergies and build opportunities.  There is a lot of build diversity available and so many fun choices.  

Exploration & Aesthestics - 10/10
I really like art of the worlds and just wandering around in them shooting things.  My favorite world by far is N'erud.  The whole atmosphere and aesthetic of that world is amazing, especially the skyline.  I also think that N'erud has the best story of the three worlds.  I also really like the stark contrast of each world as they are very different from one another.

Performance - 10/10
I have had no performance issues playing at maxed settings.  For reference, I have an i7-12700, 64GBs DDR4 ram, RTX 3070 graphics card, and nvme 4.0 ssd.

In closing, I cannot recommend this game enough.  It is an easy 10/10 game in my opinion.

Pretty good overall, though I think I kinda prefer the first one. Had some trouble at the start, but found a much better area to explore after re-rolling the campaign. It was pretty great from that point forward. The areas and monsters are really well designed and the difficulty level was always just right until the very end where I got schooled by final boss and needed to work on gittin gud some more.

Getting the game with the DLC is very much recommended. It really adds a lot of variety to your playthrough and it's great standalone experience as well. The game has three major areas to explore, and the King DLC is one of them.

The end game can be a hit or miss depending on your tastes. It kinda implies that you can spend a lot of time re-rolling the areas to get different layouts, events, and a chance to make different choices. It also lets you get more of the best gear, level up additional skill sets and get to your perfect build, but I'm struggling to motivate myself to keep going further without some major goal.

One upsetting point is the lack of armor selection or an upgrade mechanic. The premium edition came with some of the best armor in the entire game already in my inventory, so the whole mechanic became pointless. I was also very much short on cash most of the time, which means that I could only invest into upgrading one set of weapons. You either follow a guide to work out what's worth upgrading or stick it to the end with the basic weapons you got at the start like me.

Even after so many updates the game is still terribly optimized. I installed it again because of the new DLC and wanted to check if they optimized the game an acceptable amount, but my FPS is literally the same as on launch, no difference at all.

They did add a potato graphics setting, which gave me an additional 10-25 fps depending on the area, but the game looks like PUBG Mobile with it. There's no way I'm going to recommend this game to anyone if they can't even give us a stable 60 fps when the game looks like a mobile game (this was even with FSR on performance).

My PC is not that great (1070 Ti, Ryzen 7 3700x, 32 GB) but I can run other games that look way better just fine:
- Cyberpunk 2077 on highest settings (FSR balanced)
- Updated The Witcher 3 on highest settings
- DOOM Eternal on highest settings

There's no reason my PC shouldn't be able to run this game at a stable 60 fps without it looking like a bad mobile game.

It was mostly disappointing and just makes me want to play remnant 1 survival mode again.

The game has performance issues all across the board, and the upscaling makes things blurry. Mine crashed more times than I know, somewhere in a range above 40-60 times for seemingly random reasons. 

When the particle effects get dense, it can struggle and still maintain a playable framerate, but your inputs get a significant delay. 

The introduction is very grating and out of place seeming in the established universe.

The main story is questionable, and as your protagonist is now just a side character in someone else's story, it would play out the exact same way if you never played it, which is a baffling decision and makes it all wrap up in a way that feels meaningless.

The guy in charge of balancing From the Ashes allegedly quit the company, and it feels like the publisher drove a lot of strange design decisions that really alter the feel of the game. 

The release and 3 day access state wasn't great- a number of weird bugs and promised content that is either missing or in one case spitefully hidden by the developers because someone allegedly 'almost found it' in testing. The developers apparently are mocking players in the official discord as well, and combined with the spiteful last minute change, that makes for some major red flags in my opinion.

There are more 'things to do' to make your build, but every single aspect of it is nerfed. Your character can end up feeling much weaker than they should, as enemies scale faster than you. A specific note on jank- Upgrading your weapons directly levels up enemy HP and the damage they deal to you. This is similar to Remnant 1's system, but is really out of whack here. Enemies scale faster than you this way, and also scale in ways your character cannot balance out. 

It still has a similarity to from the ashes, but they shifted focus from all the characters you grew to know. Ford literally just disappears (assumedly to a future DLC?) in the first 10 minutes. The protagonist you went with through (potentially) Chronos and Ashes just disappeared. The returning shopkeepers just feel like a token nod to the fact Ashes exists.

It's fun to mess around with, but I think I'll only play from here on to make me feel less bad about purchasing it, and I can't recommend it unless it's on sale, they actually put all the content in, they fix the standout bugs, eliminate the causes of at least half the crashes, fire the devs doing weird stuff, and take a step back and look at the more bizarre design decisions, like putting one of the gear types into a gacha system in town.

The music is good, but it's all in short snippets unfortunately, and they added an unnecessary inception BWOMMMM stinger on top of the miniboss intro/outro from Ashes, which was perfectly fine as is. 

It's actually really disappointing to see the game like this, as I was expecting to have a lot of fun with this.

[h1]A Masterful Sequel That Enhances Every Aspect[/h1]

[h2]Gameplay Improvements & Co-op Experience:[/h2]

"Remnant 2" enhances the series' gameplay with an expanded arsenal of items and character builds that encourage experimentation and replayability. The co-op aspect remains a cornerstone, offering a seamless and enriched multiplayer experience that enhances the fun.

[h2]Story Continuation:[/h2]

The narrative picks up the torch from its predecessor, delivering a compelling continuation that will satisfy fans and newcomers alike. It's a testament to the developers' dedication to world-building and storytelling, ensuring that the journey feels both familiar and fresh.

[h2]Balance & Difficulty:[/h2]

I went as far as the Nightmare difficulty, finding the challenge to be perfectly balanced. It's accessible enough for new players without diluting the thrill of victory that veterans crave. This fine-tuning ensures that "Remnant 2" is never too daunting, making it a joy to dive back into the fray time and time again.

[h2]Replayability:[/h2]

The vast array of guns and items is a collector's dream, forcing us to explore every nook and cranny of the game's rich environments. The requirement to play through multiple times to obtain all items adds a layer of depth and replayability seldom seen in games today. It's an addictive loop that keeps you coming back for more.

[h2]Accessibility to Newcomers:[/h2]

For those who haven't had the pleasure of playing "Remnant: From the Ashes," fear not. "Remnant 2" welcomes newcomers with open arms, thanks to its standalone story and intuitive gameplay mechanics. It's a perfect entry point into the series, offering enough context to get you invested without feeling lost.

[h2]Conclusion:[/h2]

"Remnant 2" is a triumphant sequel that builds on the foundation of its predecessor in every way possible. From gameplay enhancements to its engaging co-op, balanced difficulty, and the sheer joy of exploration and collection, it's a masterclass in how to elevate a franchise. Whether you're a returning fan or a curious newcomer, "Remnant 2" is an essential addition to your gaming library. Highly recommended for anyone looking for a deep, rewarding, and endlessly fun experience.

This game deserved a 2023 GOTY award more than Starfield. My wife, who /hates/ Dark Souls, absolutely loves playing this game with me. We have cooped the entire game together. 
- We think Remnant feels more player-accessible than Dark Souls is because dark souls "locks" players into an animation with nearly every action in the game, and Remnant does not. In Dark Souls, when you swing your sword, you can’t dodge-roll until after the animation is complete. In Remnant you can dodge roll at almost any time. This small design decision has made a monumental difference for us, making Remnant feel entirely different and fun. This does not make the game "easy" though, if you play on higher difficulties. 
- The sound stage is incredible. The music is epic and wonderful, artfully designed to match the world or zone you are exploring. But what stands out to me especially is the addition of enemy attack audio cues. Of course, there's still the pre-attack "big windup" animations, but Remnant also makes innovative use of attack-sound cues unique to almost every enemy in the game. I did not realize how much my game play had grown organically around the brilliant audio cues until my headphones came unplugged during an encounter and I felt my world dissolve into chaos. Well done Devs, I have a whole new appreciation for sound design. 
- The ability to multi-class, the variety of abilities offered, and the variety of weapons break the "Tank/DPS/Support" mold in innovative and fun ways! 
- Most of the writing is wonderful and thought provoking. Each world you travel to has multiple stories you can play through (only one story per play through). Stories are told through NPCs with fun dialog options, and writings if you want to spend time reading. Usually the writings are well worth it, and my wife enjoys giving dramatic reenactments. Not sure what happened with the main quest... but the others are great! I’m hoping they release a DLC that revamps the main quest because its sadly lacking. 
- The game play loop is different from other action games because of the addition of puzzles. The Action//Puzzle variation is very cool and fun. If you don't want to solve the puzzles, go ahead look up the solutions and get the reward. We have tried hard to solve them ourselves and have loved the experience. Some of them stretch on for quite a while, and there are some very... obscure secrets... which we have avoided looking up solutions for so far. I can tell something is there but... still trying to puzzle it out. 
- In my opinion, Remnant has the perfect mix of "Hand Crafted" and "Randomized." The zones are built from different hand-crafted tiles each time they are re-rolled. The game fits together like a beautiful digital Lego set. The campaign is designed to be played through multiple times, and each time you will get a different handful of Lego pieces. Some of the puzzles stretch across multiple Legos, which can make solving them very challenging. I love that character progression is persistent, only the world changes. You can have multiple characters although I'm not sure why I'd use this feature because they introduced the ability to save "builds" in the equipment menu, which is appreciated. 
- The difficulty settings are challenging for a lot of games to get just right for players. We think remnant devs have done a great job. We started out on "Medium" until we got used to the gameplay, and then raised the difficulty. We did have to restart the campaign to do this, which was ok! Restarting the campaign does not reset your character progression. Now we are playing on "Hard" (the highest is "Very hard" but you need to beat the campaign once to unlock it). Full disclosure, we ended up spending 4 hours trying to beat one boss over two play sessions. Beating it was immensely satisfying, and we loved the experience. Before playing Remnant my wife would never have wanted to even play a game where this was a possibility, but this experience was well crafted and we both loved it.
- I love that for me, who plays games more often than my wife, I can still play solo because its easy to avoid playing content we have not experienced together. When we can play together, every new area is a mystery to us and we love exploring, looking for secrets and solving puzzles as a team. Enemy and bosses are clearly designed to be synergistic with coop play and are challenging but fair. 
- The Devs have been responsive to player feedback, making changes and upgrades. 
- Truthfully I am confused why the player ratings on steam are not higher than 90%. This game rocks, especially coop.

Short version:
Game's really cool and fun. Wish I could recommend it, but it crashes all the damn time. This is a defective product.
(Also my god the writing is irresponsible as fuck)

Long version:
1. The Crashing
I've managed to reduce the crashing by deactivating GPU overclocking and similar stuff all over and cranking the graphics all the way down to the "Potato" setting (real nice to have my tech insulted in the menu btw). So for me it's playable now, as long as I reboot the machine before playing.

But I shouldn't have to reconfigure my whole rig in service of the whims of a single game. The state of this thing is inexcusable. I'll revise this review if they ever fix the problem. At time of writing the game's been out for 5 months, so I'm not holding my breath.

2: The Randomized Looter Shooter
If you liked Remnant 1, you'll probably like this. The procgen stuff is pretty well put together, but gets samey, as procgen stuff tends to do. I don't mind that. I think it's a cool idea to have your looter shooter come pre-packaged with its own randomizer.
And the looting and the shooting are excellent.

3: The Scaling
The Scaling problems from Remnant 1 are still here, but lessened, if I understand it correctly. I'll try not to make too firm a statement, because all I know about how it works here is second-hand knowledge. If you're gonna play this, I urge you to look up how the game scales its difficulty.
The short version is: only upgrade your weapons when you need it. Overlevelling your gear is dangerous.

4: The Story stuff
I had kinda hoped they'd learned from their severe writing missteps in Remnant 1, but it's pretty much exactly the same. The good stuff is still good and the bad stuff is still so, so bad.

Spoilers for Remnant 1 but not Remnant 2:
[spoiler]In Remnant 1 there is the world of Rhom. It's a nuclear wasteland populated by aggressive mutants. These mutants, though, are clearly sapient. They are, essentially, people, despite appearances. They are also extremely xenophobic and will attack outsider on sight. The result is that you spend a lot of time rampaging through their villages, shooting absolutely everybody and ransacking their homes. Not to put too fine a point on it: To progress through the game, you have to commit acts of genocide. The Rhomites being xenophobic jerks does not justify this kind of response.
There's also a particularly fucked up bit in Reisum where you find a cage with Urikki slaves. When you fine the key you can open the cage, but you will find that the slaves don't leave. You can't interact with them in any way except murder. And in fact, what you're supposed to do here is pick out the one that has a prosthetic eye and kill them. To get the eye. What. The fuck.[/spoiler]

Spoilers for Remnant 1 and 2:
[spoiler]In Remnant 2, you eventually get to the world of Losomn, which is populated by the Fae. To progress here, you will, again, rampage through palaces and city streets, just gunning down everybody while the Fae (and the Dran) scream at you to get the fuck out. Further, the lore asserts that Fae are inherently chaotic, murderous creatures, naturally driven towards murder for sake of entertainment etc. Essentialising a whole people like this is obviously very messed up and honestly I should have seen this coming. It doesn't really matter that they're trying to make a point about libertarians (I swear they do, it's not subtle), but it's really undermined by how they justify feudal tyranny to do it.[/spoiler]

A Thrilling Journey of Perseverance and Camaraderie

As an intermediate-level gamer with a penchant for challenges, I've always been drawn to titles that push my limits and keep me on the edge of my seat. Remnant 2, the highly anticipated sequel to the original masterpiece, has not only met but exceeded all my expectations. It's a game that has taken me through countless failures, only to emerge victorious in the end, and it has become an addiction I can't resist, especially when played with others.

Remnant 2 is a testament to the art of relentless persistence. From the very start, the game makes it clear that it won't hold your hand, and that's exactly what I crave in a gaming experience. Multiple missions have left me cursing my decisions, scratching my head, and questioning my skills. But let me tell you, every failure was a lesson learned, a battle scar earned, and a challenge that only fueled my determination.

The combat system in Remnant 2 is a masterpiece. It's fluid, intense, and unforgiving. You'll need every ounce of your skill to prevail against the diverse and menacing foes that lurk around every corner. The game doesn't just pit you against cannon fodder; it throws complex and unique enemy types your way, each requiring a different approach and strategy. The sheer variety of weapons and abilities at your disposal adds an extra layer of depth to the combat, allowing you to tailor your playstyle to your liking.

What truly sets Remnant 2 apart is its co-op experience. While the game is exhilarating when played solo, it reaches a whole new level of enjoyment when you team up with friends or other gamers online. The synergy of different character builds, the coordination required to overcome tough boss fights, and the shared triumphs after countless defeats create unforgettable moments of camaraderie. Remnant 2 teaches you that teamwork isn't just an option; it's often the key to success.

The visuals in Remnant 2 are nothing short of breathtaking. The game world is a meticulously crafted tapestry of post-apocalyptic beauty and despair. The attention to detail in the environments, the eerie atmosphere, and the subtle storytelling through environmental cues immerse you in a world that's as captivating as it is dangerous. The dynamic lighting and particle effects add another layer of immersion, making every battle feel epic and intense.

The replay-ability of Remnant 2 is another factor that keeps me hooked. The game's procedural generation ensures that each play through is unique, with different maps, enemy placements, and loot drops. It's a game that encourages you to explore, experiment, and discover new secrets with each run.

In conclusion, Remnant 2 is a must-play for gamers who relish a challenge and are addicted to the thrill of hard-earned victory. It's a game that rewards perseverance, strategy, and teamwork while delivering an unforgettable gaming experience. With its breathtaking visuals, deep combat system, and co-op magic, Remnant 2 has firmly cemented its place as one of my all-time favorites. It's not just a game; it's an adrenaline-fueled journey that you won't want to miss. Grab your friends, sharpen your skills, and prepare to embark on an unforgettable adventure in Remnant 2!

Remnant 2 has bosses and encounters that i cant help but think were made with mainly co op in mind. Such as the dreaded CUBE!!! boss. it's fun, it's challenging and just over all engaging. it also has co-op. did I mention co-op? in our post co-op stores gaming landscape today? yea, it has that.
co-op is drop in/drop out style, you get to keep all the gear you find, really the only issue I have with it is the fact that the game is graphics intensive and that can actually cause you crash when playing co-op.

as for the game play, I've actually never played Dark Souls. so working with Dark Souls style fighting was new. it feels very fresh and honestly they did an amazing job meshing those I-frame mechanics and the gun play. beating bosses is not at all straight forward and easy unless you have a solid understanding how to play the game but it is so extremely satisfying when you do.

everything in the game is a roll of dice, there's 3 whole other worlds and each has 2 (and now more with the new DLC) story arcs which are your first roll of dice. from there, it rolls which dungeons you'll have in these worlds then stitches together the overworlds of each realm based on those dungeons. THEN EVEN FURTHER DOWN there are different tile sets that can appear in dungeons (dev team calls them "Injectibles") and further change how the world looks. every time you play, the world is different.

aside from all that, the game does seem to crash more often on my now aging system(cries in gtx1060) but the game is absolutely stupendous about auto saves and along with it, has excellent cross experience for loot drops (if you grab it, you keep it, specific game mode does not matter not does story restarts, it's yours, Queen :D).

overall, I was not expecting this game or the first game to be this good. 12/10 it's been fantastic

I'm not complete on my first playthrough, but have both a solo character and coop character with friends.

Baseline gameplay mechanics so far work well and after a short familiarity phase has become pretty natural. Although, I'd say the tutorial is not great: Enemies move fast, and trying to get used to having to aim down sights to shoot (which slows your movement) while dodging enemy charges and projectiles all at once makes it feel harder than it is. This, I think, is mainly because the tutorial is basic movement, then an enemy swarm, then small sporadic mob attacks with 3 NPC helpers, then a boss fight. The combat ramp just feels uneven in the tutorial.

Also the tutorial doesn't explain multiple mechanics, which I only learned through loading screens: Shift while aiming swaps shoulder view, Alt crouches, Mouse Wheel OR X swaps weapons, Hold Left click without aiming to charge a melee attack... mechanics like that. By no means are all of these breaking, but rather annoying that they don't explain it directly despite the utility (it teaches X is swap weapons).

Bosses, aside the tutorial boss, have been difficult but manageable and generally fun. Except the Altars that summon poison spewing/exploding adds in waves for a melee weapon, that is pretty bad design (cramped quarters, tanky mobs that constantly drop stagger causing poison bombs, large numbers). Other than that, the boss fights have been pretty cool, with mechanics that can be figured out without looking anything up but not "bland". Boss runs after a death have been minor as well, and not really losing anything on death makes it feel more like "Oh, yeah I gotta hide behind the pillar for that mechanic I think, let's try that" instead of "Oh fuck that bullshit, now I've gotta do all this shit again".

The main hub definitely could use literally any indication who all the merchants are. I found the weapon merchant (who you talk to as part of the tutorial, but he doesn't show his shop at that time) about 7 hours in during coop, on accident. The Armor merchant I found just because I decided to talk to the weird looking guy.

Also, you are tied to a character from the start of the game, Cass, who comes off as fairly annoying. But this is because they don't establish her connection to you well; opening starts with you two walking and chatting, and your character apparently knows her for a while. But the player doesn't, and they don't really establish her to the Player... like, at all that I can see. She becomes a merchant and will scream at you constantly in the ward to talk to her during various story parts, which again just makes her super annoying because to the Player she's just a random other NPC. Like, seriously, you the Player know her about 10 minutes longer than the Weapon Upgrade guy (who from intro scene thought was the Medic Supplies guy) or the random Mayor dude that I don't think I interacted with beyond opening hub cutscene.

Anyway:

Game is pretty fun, definitely feel like a Souls-type game with a tweak on the combat structure. Bosses are good, areas are interesting, views are great, weapons are pretty neat, and so far build variety (that are... ugh... "ViAbLe" hate that gamer term) seems pretty open.

I imagine replayability is moderate at best, since areas are fully randomized, but it seems the order of appearance, availability, and occurrence of like... uh, side event(?) things is somewhat random so there is enough room to vibe around with friends doing random stuff I think.

I'd give it a good 8.5/10 so far: Worth Picking Up, Solid Game // Definite Buy on Sale -- Just push past the tutorial before making a final decision.

Remnant II is fantastic. 

The intro is clunky, and the way you acquire your first Archetype feels rushed and unsatisfying, but everything after that shines. 

Once you get into your first area map, you immediately feel the tension. This world is out to kill you, and lets you know you better take it seriously. From the jump, the combat is stiff and unforgiving, and has that Dark-Souls edge that I'd been looking for in a 3rd person shooter. 

The gun shots have weight and impact, and the melee weapons have a solidity to them that gives some bone-crunching feedback that feels great. Side note: there are so, so many cool weapons peppered throughout the various procedural maps, and it made me want to keep coming back for more. 

The level designs can be grueling, and playing them solo never fails to get my heart pumping. You don't know where the next save marker might be lurking, and dying before you reach the thing will send you back to where you started. True that loop can get a frustrating, but the elation I felt when I finally cleared a section made it worthwhile. 

The area bosses are seriously demanding, and you need to understand your load out if you're going to survive. And while I didn't always like some of the timing and telegraph decisions the devs made, I was able to learn them and slog through nonetheless. I will say that the mini-bosses and rank-and-file enemies were often more interesting to me (or at least more fun?), and I definitely had many heart-pounding encounters that stuck with me, and left me craving more. One minor grievance I have, is that this game sends sh*t flying at your from every angle, but doesn't have the best auditory cues, so you have to keep your head on a swivel when you're in the sh*t...

One last thing, this game feels great in multi-player, and I recommend giving it a go with a hommie.

Right out of the gate I want to let you know that this game is VERY good and even if you do not like souls-likes it is worth a try as it is far more approachable than most games in the genre. If you are a destiny refugee, this game will scratch many of the same itches that destiny does. There are some things you NEED to know before purchasing this game though:

1. As previously mentioned and stated in the tags, this game is a souls-like. That means there is no first person view and dodging attacks is very important in this game. Only very specific builds can get away with not needing to dodge attacks. 
2. Some of the items you receive in this game are broken. The fixes they release end up breaking more stuff. There are so many different stats and modifiers to those stats that this game will probably never be bug free. (Get A QA department Gunfire, seriously)
3. This game runs on the UE5 and 99% of the time it looks great. However, I need to mention that I have experienced some graphical glitches when it comes to terrain in certain areas. It is by no means game breaking and happens very rarely
 
That's out of the way, lets talk about the good stuff. 

Remnant's campaign is procedurally generated. Yup. You read that correctly. The overall story is the same across every campaign, and there are 2 worlds that will always appear as the 2nd and 5th world in your playthrough no matter what. I will not explain why because that involves spoilers, though the game's main story isn't much to write home about anyways. The other worlds you will find yourself on are generated randomly. The game has tiles similar to a warframe mission, but it uses that method to construct the worlds you will explore and the dungeons you will fight through. It is worth noting that not every item, dungeon, and boss you can encounter will spawn on a world. You will have to run through a world multiple times to encounter everything. 

Remnant 2 has 11 classes (currently, expect more) and you can equip 2 at a time. Some classes are built around taking damage, some are built around dealing damage with your guns or status effects, some are about healing, and some are about using mods (mods explained next paragraph). All of these classes are unique and equally viable.

The buildcrafting in Remnant 2 is very intuitive and easy to pick up. You have armor, which affects your damage resistance (DR) and how fast you can roll. You have a primary weapon ( a long gun like a sniper, shotgun, ar, lmg, and the rest), you have a secondary weapon (revolver, sidearm, smg, etc), and you have a melee weapon. Each normal gun has a mod slot, which gives the weapon an ability that recharges with kills that can add acid onto your bullets or create a fire tornado. They also have mutator slots, which affect the guns behavior in some way. Think increasesdfire rate, critical chance, etc. You have a relic, which can be used as a health potion or can grant passive healing or can grant defensive buffs like shields. Relics have 3 slots for relic fragments and relic fragments give small bonuses to almost every stat in the game. 

Then you have trinkets. Oh boy. You have 1 amulet slot and 4 ring slots. These grant powerful bonuses that will define your built once you have enough to start crafting one. They are too varied to explain here but trinkets are very important. Last but not least, you have attributes. You have 85 attribute points that you can put into whatever you want. Want to dodge with the heaviest armor in the game? Go for it. Want to passively regenerate health and have life steal? Go for it. Want to make your dodge faster than your sprint? Its possible. You have to unlock attributes though. Some come from reaching the max level in classes but most will come from completing challenges or secret puzzles in the worlds. 

Bosses in Remnant are top tier. The final boss of the game is one of the best boss fights I have ever played, though having a good build in the late-game trivializes everything. The bosses are certainly not as difficult as other soulslikes but they are no cakewalk. Most worldbosses are incredibly cinematic.

This game is a strange mix between fun and frustrating gameplay.

The game has a lot of variation in enemies and surroundings, which makes for fun gameplay. The graphics and sound effects are good and makes for a fun time.

Unfortunately the game also contains several very frustrating elements. Throughout the game, you won't find any new weapons or armor, but will find huge amounts of rings. 

You are expected to upgrade your existing starter weapons, which you do by gathering crafting materials and using those materials to increase weapon damage ever so slightly. If you are lucky and find the right crafting materials, you may be able to purchase a single new weapon, before completing the game.

Gameplay often requires you to heal or reload your weapons to stay alive. Doing so makes you vulnerable for the 5 second duration it takes to complete the action and dodging or jumping, to avoid getting killed, will reset that duration. 

If your weapon overheats, you are forced to finish for the overheating animation to finish, before being able to either change to another weapon or use the weapon again. During those 5 seconds, you can't do anything except slowly walk around.

If you get hit by an enemy, you will often get stunned. While stunned you have to wait for the stun animation to finish animating, before you are able to control your body again. If you get attacked during those 5 seconds, you will get downed again or get killed.

The game heavily evolves around boss fights. Bosses will continuously hammer you with melee weapons, which has a 50 meter range and if you don't dodge the weapon at the exact right time or if you run out of dodge/sprint power, you will get hit and you will be stunned. If you dodge, you won't be able to see where you are dodging to. Dodging into a deadly pool on the ground will stun you or damage you, making boss fights even more frustrating.

The game would be greatly improved by removing stun mechanics, removing the required wait duration for animations complete, reducing boss melee attacks to melee range, massively speeding up reload, heal and special ability action durations and adding some new weapons and armor drops to the game.

I really wanted to like this game but there's too many problems.

[h1]Positives[/h1]
+I love that you can wear 4 rings at once, most rings are impactful, and this is where a lot of build variety comes from (along with amulets).
+Dungeons have a lot of secrets and cleverly hidden stuff. Some dungeons also have different layouts yielding new secrets and items.
+There's a lot of places to explore and things you can do.
+The couple bosses I beat were actually fun and challenging. They also significantly toned back the regular enemies bosses spawn compared to the first game. However it's still lazy design for almost if not all bosses to spawn regular enemies.
+The map is amazing and properly shows the terrain as well as where you haven't explored yet. Makes me think of Metroid Prime. Why don't more game do maps like this?
+No penalties for death unless you're on hardcore obviously. This takes away some of the frustration of the BS in the game.

[h1]Negatives[/h1]
-I don't feel in control of the combat flow or how things unfold. When you're getting swarmed dodging doesn't do anything except let them get closer because you're not shooting. And your backwards pace is slow, nor can you sprint backwards with the camera facing forward. This means elite melee enemies combined with other enemies spamming ranged shots at you equals an unfun time. So try to sprint away and put distance between you, but then they hit you with their own ranged attack. No I don't want to be forced to use the neutral backstep dodge, that is awful gameplay design forcing that on people.
-The above is exacerbated by the fact that enemies can and will spawn behind you. Lazy design, and clearly meant for co-op.
-Melee elite enemies are cancer and should not exist in a game where you shoot 99% of the time and have limited escape options. There's only 1 archetype that is melee focused. The rest of the time you're shooting, and as previously discussed your options for disengaging melee combat are extremely limited.
-The AI is dumb and doesn't seem capable of acquiring new targets. I cheesed a melee boss because my handler dog was blocking the doorway and the boss was completely ignoring it and trying to get to me but failing. So I let my dog chew on him for a minute getting his health almost gone then I finished him off. Why did the boss not start attacking the minion? You see this other times when a melee elite is chasing you as several of your minions are slowly whittling away its health and it completely ignores them.
-Archetypes aka classes are boring. You can level them up and get some minor bonuses but once they are leveled to 10 there's nothing else to do with them. Each archetype has 3 active skills you can alternate between at any time, but that's it. no skill trees or anything to make this stuff unique, nor is there any kind of real end goal. It's very basic and shallow.
-The overall gameplay loop is also boring. There's not much to it besides hoping you find rings/amulets that fit with your playstyle. You find them... and now what? There's not really anything else to do. You're killing the same enemies over and over to get resources to upgrade your weapons so you don't fall behind the level scaling, but otherwise your gameplay and how you do encounters remains the exact same. 10 hours I played the game and absolutely nothing changed with how I did combat.
-Armor is super boring and has no special effects; just damage reduction and status resistances.
-The puzzles are dumb and boring. Most of them seem to come down to figuring out the correct symbols and then inputting them. Riveting. I was far more impressed with the secret passages cleverly hidden behind pots and things like that. Also there's secret walls, but to give them credit they make a distinctive sound and when you get close you can see the texture moving. You can then simply pass through them. No Dark Souls 1 BS here. But there's other puzzles like traps that instakill you, and invisible walkways. All this stuff slows down the game and draws you out.
-Encounters are formulaic and dumb. People in the forums are telling the truth when they say each encounter feels the same, because it does.
-That girl you start the game with is extraordinarily annoying, but it's obvious the devs expect you to think she's cool and strong. She's not, she's rude and a capital B. Thank goodness she's gone from the story after the tutorial and becomes an unimportant merchant.
-Speaking of I don't really care for any of the characters actually. They're all generic and boring. Although those aliens are kind of interesting.
-Going off that the story is boring and uninteresting, but at least more effort was put into presenting it than your usual Souls-like, although I hear the payoff and reveals are disappointing or plain bad.
-Weapons aren't all that interesting and the mods you get for them which add a special ability are ok, but not enough to hold interest. There is a shooting range to test your weapons and see the dps, something the vast majority of Souls-likes bafflingly don't do.

Ultimately I don't feel that sense of player skill progression that I do in melee-focused Souls-likes such as Lords of the Fallen (2023). In those the melee never gets boring because you are constantly improving your tactics against the various enemies. In Remnant 2 there's not much more to do than stand and shoot at things. We needed skill trees and real build variety like an ARPG.

So if you're still interested, it's not an awful game, it just may not hold your interest for long especially if you're a solo player. Wait for a heavy sale if you must get this.

Yeah, well, I liked Remnant and I even liked Before the Ashes so it's not surprising that I like Remnant 2.  Of course, this wasn't guaranteed and if I'm honest I kind of like the original a little better.  The problem is that while the sequel has a lot of changes that are genuinely for the better, it still *feels* very much the same and so I don't really compare mechanics so much as atmosphere and I liked the places in From the Ashes a little more.  I think it's because they were fresh and new, and so even if places like Yaesha look great here, one can't get away from the feeling of "been here, done this."

It's kind of a small complaint but maybe the most real problem a sequel can face: the plot isn't quite as interesting here, I don't feel like we really get some payoff we might have liked from the original, and while I don't think Remnant ever had a particularly strong cast of characters this is a place where, at best, Remnant 2 hasn't improved things.  So it really is a mechanical upgrade for the most part and while you have more development options ... I'm also not really convinced they matter all that much.

Let's not kid ourselves or anything.  Remnant has stellar combat feel and gunplay.  This is why I like it, this is what has always gotten me hooked.  But class development, upgrading your weapons and whatnot, it's nice to have but I can't say that I *genuinely* feel it in the moment to moment gameplay.  I often find myself ignoring special powers and mods because I don't really need them a lot of the time.  This, again, speaks to how good the core combat feels by itself, but it's why I can't be quite as enthusiastic about the sequel despite what appears some fairly interesting upgrades.  You can now dual-class, you have more mods and mutators for your weapons, and of course there's even more guns to choose from!  It is a solid game, but it's an okay sequel if that makes sense.

Still, the play time is no lie: the game is still fun to play.  There are still interesting stories in these worlds to find.  I may not be quite as enthusiastic about it as a sequel, but as a game Remnant is fun and engaging.  I can recommend that pretty easily.

The level design is pretty good, but the standout to me is the enemy design (in terms of combat flow,) I did not get bored fighting any of the enemies in the game, they did a good job with giving you stuff to shoot, even the bosses are generally fun to fight.

There is a lengthy list of downsides that go along with the praise though, the story is worthless, it's basically there to excuse the "starting over" mechanic, unfortunately this does sort of retract from the "do I care" aspect about this game, because generally, no, I don't really care about this game and I don't see myself sticking with it for very long. The other major downside I don't mind whinging about boils down to "the game is stingy", specifically with upgrade materials/money. I would give Remnant 2 an 83%, because at the end of the day, it's actually fun, and that's the part that matters most, get it on sale when they release a version with all the DLC for 20 or 30 bucks.

Remnant 2 is a third person shooter/souls-like and has been called "dark souls with guns". Now, I'm going to make this review extremely personal, and as such, I do not recommend this game. However, I wouldn't call it a bad game, I'd say this is a 7/10 I did not like.

While Remnant 2 offers an interesting blend of genres, in my opinion, it is dragged down by an extremely repetitive gameplay loop, very low enemy and gameplay variety, generic visual design and an extremely uninspired and uninteresting story and universe. 

The game starts fun, and its procedural design shines at the start. Levels are complex and have several secrets. However, even as far as the first large zone, you'll start seeing the dreadful enemy variety, minimal AI in the enemies, and repetitive visual design. This whole game is basically held together by competent shooting mechanics and a compelling difficulty curve that can be hard at the start but is rewarding to dominate.

The final third of the game is also the final nail in the coffin. The repetitiveness of scenarios and enemies, uninteresting level design, recycling of content and a seemingly endless gauntlet right at the end became nigh unbearable. The final enemies are quite challenging, but you can do it with some practice. I got to the final phase of the final enemy of the game, until basically boredom was intolerable, and I had to drop it. 

Please note this is my experience as a single player, I have not engaged in multiplayer, which I suspect could be quite fun.

Overall, as I said before, this is a game that starts on a good note, but never fully capitalizes on its strengths and plateaus rather quickly, only to never peak, and drop into a swamp at the endgame. The story is also completely forgettable and is unlike fromsoftware games, lacks a potent hook of mystery to lead the player forward.

On the technical side the game isn't nearly as pretty as it is demanding, and Unreal Engine 5 isn't utilized well in my opinion.

7/10. Competent, but definitely didn't like it.

As a devoted fan of the original Remnant, I can confidently say that Remnant 2 has blown me away with its sheer brilliance and captivating gameplay. This game is nothing short of a masterpiece, combining elements from its predecessor with stunning innovations that elevate the entire experience to a whole new level.

The gameplay mechanics are nothing short of revolutionary. The combat system is fluid, dynamic, and responsive, providing an unparalleled sense of satisfaction when taking down hordes of challenging foes. The addition of new weapon types and abilities further deepens the strategic aspect of the game, keeping me constantly engaged and on the edge of my seat.

The level design is a true work of art. The world feels interconnected and alive, with hidden secrets and challenging puzzles to discover around every corner. The randomized elements ensure that no two playthroughs are alike, adding significant replay value to an already content-rich game.

Probably the only two downsides which are worth mentioning are the limited allocatable trait points (capped at 60 for no reason), and the dodgy performance across various systems. As the devs stated, they designed the game around the use of DLSS/FSR, but the game still could have used more manual tuning of which according to the devs will happen with upcoming patches / fixes. So at least it seems that they are listening to the community feedbacks, and trying to resolve the issues as fast as possible.

In conclusion, if you liked / loved the first game, you can't go wrong with this one.

Update as of 2024 January the 20th, and after 100+ hours of gameplay:
With the release of the DLC they increased the trait cap to 85, and added the Loadout function, therefore with these additions the game offers much more variety, and with the Loadouts we don't have to manually change our gear anymore, which is a great plus, especially if you're playing multiple builds, or just simply want to experiment around with various gear. The performance somewhat improved, but there's still a lot of room for improvement. Especially with the new DLC map, there are still ongoing issues with fps spikes, and stutters, and playing in coop sometimes makes it worse. They released some Hotfixes however to mitigate the performance issues which are mainly derived with the release of the DLC, so the situation is not as bad as it was before, but still needs some obvious fixing.

this is my first review, so it'll probably disorganized as hell so bear with me. and this may contain spoilers unrelated to the story.
ill start off by saying this: i played the hell out of Remnant FTA, i played it until there was nothing left to do, and nearly 200 hours under my belt; when Remnant 2 was announced, i was over the moon! it looked so awesome with the addition of classes and the abilities they came with, multiclassing between them for cool combos, i was just excited for more Remnant gameplay. with that in mind, i was very disheartened to see what this game turned out to be, and i wanted to like this game SO damn bad. and trust me when i say this, my disappointment allong with this negative review comes from my love for the first game, and how this one just doesnt measure up by far in my opinion.
the first thing i want to touch on is the worlds, Yaesha is cool, i honestly liked it for the most part and it was cool to see the non-rebel Pan, even if it was kind of lacking in terms of their story and such. the labyrinth was super cool, im glad that they made it more of an explorable area and even had weapons/armor you could get there, the block bois are also super cute. the next 2 worlds i find are polar opposites, Ne'Rud i find to be very, very cool in terms of design, the lore and overall feel; however, it is super ass to play. everything looks like nothing, its a big open, neverending wasteland with very few visual....anything, except for the custodians house. the enemies here are mostly fine, except for the density is pretty annoying, mostly because you'll be struggling to find anything while constantly being attacked by droids or zombie dudes, and god forbid the meatball, what a crap enemy that thing is. in essence, the area is kinda just a chore to play. on to Losomn, this area feels great to play in, the enemy density is just right, it is relatively linear without being too hand holding, the visuals are nice and you can actually spot landmarks; but like, it just doesnt feel alien, at least the first half and even kind of the second half. its just 18th century England with vampires. everything is human here, they tell time the same (big clock tower), they have human tools, human buildings, human weapons...everything. they even speak english, not as in they know it, english is legit their language as far as im aware (could be wrong and willing to be). it just doesnt feel alien, its like being on slight fantasy earth, which i feel like that defeats the purpose of travelling to different worlds.
next ill get on to gear and such starting with the weapons, the guns are mostly fine, i did find that some of them are a little too weird, like the ghostly finger rifle; but thats just personal prefference. melee weapons on the other hand i believe could have been a lot better, and should have been. most of them dont have a unique trait, and if they do its pretty mid. it basically just boils down to the damage number and moveset attached to the weapon, with moveset in mind, i found that the melee movesets were also kind of lacking, in the first game, there was a different attack for just about every different movement option in the game (running, dodging, backstep, etc) in this the same attack is used in multiple movement options, and most of the weapons only have a 2 hit combo, whereas in the first game, all weapons were at least 3, and the charged attacks felt a lot better and usually came with a different animation; unlike in 2 where its the same animation, just with some more effort in it. and as a big fan of unarmed melee builds in the first game; i felt personally attacked when i discovered that unarmed builds are basically not a thing, even when using accessories that boost unarmed effectiveness. speaking of melee builds, sure you can do them but i find its really only viable when your playing challenger and using juggernaut, otherwise you just get overwhelmed by surprisingly small amounts of enemies and promptly defeated. which i think in general is pretty lame. 

On to armor now; i think it was a really weird decision to make armor un-upgradeable, coupled with the fact that enemies do incredible amounts of damage in this game, most regular enemies will 2/3 shot you no matter what and even with the fortify trait and Leto's you can basically take an extra 2 hits if your lucky and it'll just be like this for the entire game; it basically leads to using armor for the looks rather than what it does. speaking of "what it does", they no longer have armor traits, they tried to replace this with the mutators and such, but they just dont measure up to the armor traits from the first game in my opinion, either too small of a bonus, or the bonus should have just been a trait.

On to accessories: i found that most of the accessories didnt offer a big enough or accessable enough bonus, not saying they need to be goated, but a lot of them were just "okay" and nothing that you could synergize with other rings or make builds out of; they were basically weak add-ons. and some were hard to access actual usage out of, for example i remember me and the bois found a bleed focused one, but never saw a bleed weapon for a looooong ass time or even another ring/amulet to make enemies bleed through normal means. i could be wrong about the accessories, but thats just the short of how i felt about them.
Lets talk about traits now. idk what the heck was going through their heads when they made this system, but it is easily the worst part about the game. in the first game there was 100 traits, in this one i believe theres around 30 or so, bearing in mind that the first game has DLC there are still far fewer traits even at launch by comparison. further than that the trait cap is 65. this leads to some big issues; one being that there is no grind to get all the traits. trait grinding is easily a lot of my hours in the first game and just some fun bonus to get along the way while trying to get other things, such as more traits or hard to get gear which there was a lot more to go out and get btw. second, some traits are just must haves, which means that builds become too similar and other traits are just never used, such as area traversal speed. the trait system being the way it is, really kills the game.
Lets look at the bosses. the bosses, save for a select few (looking at you abomination) are pretty good. i do believe having an insta kill move doesnt really add anything to the game, mostly because of the main problem; nearly every boss has the goon squad on back up for the whole fight, and its just tedious. im all for having adds in boss fights, but when the difficulty of the boss is prevalent only because of the adds, its just mediocre design. and im down for a difficult boss, ive been around the block with video games, i can do difficulty; but artificial difficulty, coming from adds, semi-quick insta kills, tedious boss design, or outright cheesy "hah got em" garbage thats just unfun to deal with; is just extremely boring to me. all that to say, the bosses are good, but some of them are tedious/boring, and others are downright unforgiveable. in contrast to a lot of the playerbase, i found the final boss really fun btw.
ive probably forgotten some points i wanted to make, but this is getting long. all this to say, i dont think this game is all the hype people seem to think it is. in my eyes, its everything the first game was and less. in some big ways and small ones. it takes too much away wthout giving enough back, its not equivalent exchange. some things are good, but a lot of things are far from it or uninspired. like it said in the beginning, i wanted to love this game, and never in a million years did i think i would write a negative review about it; but it let me down, pretty hard. theres barely replayability, no grind, less items to get, few good items to obtain. its just alright. and i believe it should have been better.
