CONS:
Although the secrets are cool, if you are a completionist, you might find it annoying that you'll have to roll the dice and rely on RNG to get what you need. Some of the secrets are so obscure that they were only discovered by data mining. Though that's not necessarily a bad thing, it means that you need to have a browser window open for YouTube videos and the Wiki. BTW, the WIKI leaves a lot to be desired. Not completely the devs fault, obviously.... though a smart studio would partner with content creators to make sure a game like this has a good Wiki.

Clearly a lot of work into this game. But I cannot recommend it for two major flaws: 

1) Every enemy encounter is an ambush. So it is impossible to be tactical with how you approach a battle, when enemies spawn randomly 5ft behind you. It makes battles feel cheap, when you are fighting then suddenly new enemies spawn behind you out of nowhere. It ruins any strategic gameplay. 

2) Enemies always out-scale you in progression. So what is the point in progressing, when enemies are always 1-3 levels above you? Seems pointless to me; no souls game does this.

For these reasons I cannot recommend the game.

This game has a lot of Pros and Cons, There are some things about it that I liked, 

The guns feel good to use, I like the class system, the ability to have two classes at once is cool, the two new worlds are interesting and the stories that revolve around them are interesting enough.

but there's a lot I really don't like and it overall ruins the experience of the game for me

While i do like the new class system the overall character building feels like a downgrade from the first game, The traits are very squashed down and you are now limited by the number of points you can spend overall and the types of traits you can get I.E. what they do, it feels more limited in how you make a character because there is just an objectively few good traits you will always run. 

The armour has changed to no longer have perks or buffs assigned to them now it's just Armour, Weight, and resistance, which means much like the traits there is just objectively a correct few sets to wear, giving you the best Armour and Resistance to Weight, so again it takes away for choice when building a character.

Now the builds overall can be very fun, but now the games have been out for some time I've watched as a lot of the more silly and gimic build have been Nerf or removed which is bonkers to me, in a purely PVE non-live severs game why the devs felt the need do this is mind blogging, now i hear the argument, "oh it made the game to easy or it wasn't intended to be used like that" AND? let me say again this is a 100% PVE game, who cares if the game is too easy? if that's what you find fun then congrats Devs you made a fun game, if it was PVP or a bug or exploit then i would understand, but as it stands its just falls under the mindset of "this isn't how we wanted you to play, your not having fun the way we intended".

Unlocks in this game are unnecessarily hard or convoluted and with no indecision on what to do or how to do it, this is a game where replaying the worlds and making new runs inbuilt into the core of the game play and that's fine, but when i need a wiki open just to understand what i need to do for even a change at something, not to say anything of a third party tool just to make sure i don't waste 2 hours in a world that doesn't even have the one thing im looking for that bad game design, saying nothing of the whole ass class that people NEEDED to data mine for because there was no way of find out the info otherwise 



Now for the worst bit in my opinion is the story, the Main story to be precise, no sugar coating it, its hot garbage, some of the worst, confused, cut-together writing I've ever seen, the cuts in the main story are so clear that it's painful and the plot holes are miles across, some of my Favs
-Cass is cured of her Root sickness (How? When? Just because we got to ward 13?)
-Ford has a magic Cube (why? Who's this old friend who gave it to him? Where does he go?)
-Clementine has magic "anti" root powers (didn't explain from the first game, doesn't here)
-The Keeper in general (Starts as an Eye, turns into a more human shape, not explained, and apparently has developed a relationship with Clementine over the game, ah yes all three times we see them)

 Oh and [spoiler]we're in the matrix now[/spoiler]

The real nail in the coffin for me was the name of the final boss, it just showed me that no one on the writing really cared about what was going on here a damn shame as the story of these games is pretty cool and has a lot of chance for good writing

a lot of what I've said here was taking into how I played the game, as of writing I've beat the game on all but Apocalypse, and you could make the argument of saying "oh but i don't care about the story or the grinding for items i just want to play a run" OK that's fair and valid, but do you really think its ok paying $60 for four hours of gameplay? because that's how long a single run takes, if you are great, more power too you, but this game very much wants you to do multiple runs and to do that grind 


Over all and at the end of the day did i have fun playing this game? Yes it was fun with friends

So if your looking to buy it, wait for a sale and make sure you have friends to play with, it makes the whole thing a hell of lot more enjoyable

First off, I didn't play the first version, so my review may be a little subjective. That being said I have played Destiny, Destiny 2 (2k plus hours), Dead Space, Diablo 4, every Halo entry, COD and a variety of other notable titles. I will heavily compare and contrast this to Destiny 2 being the most prominent game I've played. 
     Gameplay.
     So, as a shooter goes, it feels very intuitive and input friendly. I started on M&K but switched to PS4 input fairly early on. Both input methods felt approachable and relatively easy, given the assumed difficulty of the title. The hit boxes seem pretty clean both offensively and defensively. The movement range is a nice even pace, leaving only timing and mechanical understanding to be the gates. The Archetypes, weapons, relics, mods and various equipment are very well described and easy to utilize. Having played FPS's primarily it was a pretty easy transition. I would like to add that similar to D2 it seems ranged and melee damage types have fairly balanced capabilities in regards to their ease of use and efficacy. Suffice to say, you have a lot of flexibility in how you decide to deal damage.
     Buildcraft Potential. 
     I, in my infancy with the game, see this as having sustainability long term in regards to the various ways you're able to play. 4 starting Archetypes, granting a second along the way and a number of "secret" ones help to flesh out your unique gameplay loop. There doesn't seem to be a limit to how many types you can acquire, or level on a given account, so the world is yours to seize. Combine this with the elemental affixes and jewelry and you have a large pool to pick from. I would argue that this game is less redundant in this sense than D2 because of the uniqueness and power fantasy of each Archetype. 
     Loot. 
     The loot is great. A bunch of super convoluted secrets hidden away in normal activities for those willing to spend the extra time. You're not bogged down by a bunch of trash gear or gold sinks, just new unique items to fit into your build. The resource scarcity is just enough to make you thoughtful about what you upgrade, but ultimately doesn't hinder your ability to play the game. There is a nice combination of obvious regular upgrades and hidden ones to please both the casual player and the completionist. I enjoyed not having to sift through 100 rolls of the same item only for a marginal upgrade. Each piece offers something unique and otherwise unattainable.
     Environment/Sound.    
     Stellar environments with significant differences between worlds/biomes. Not incredibly interactive but not static either. Visually pleasing on high graphical settings and very immersive. My PC defaulted to "high" settings but upon manually moving them up to "ultra" I didn't notice any significant performance issues. The sky boxes are very well rendered and represent the best of what I appreciated about D2. 
     This game has some of the best sound scoring I've heard in a game. Atmospheric, peaceful, haunting and tense. It's hard to equate it to something, but essentially it doesn't distract you from the gameplay. Once you notice it's very agreeable, especially in patrol zones or open world. I would argue that it has the most insightful music to environment pairing of any game I've played. 
     Final Rating.
     At the time of writing I have 27 hours in. Not a long time but enough time. Given everything I've previously considered I would personally give Remnant II a 9/10. To some it may be generous, to others underwhelming, but given the depth, content, replayability, diversity, design and sticker price, I think it is worthy of the score. Think of how Diablo 4 launched. At $70 USD.... This game has content.
     Definitely go check this game out, it's worth the ticket. Get back to me with your impressions!

Remnant 2 is definitely not a bad game. It plays very similarly to the first game but with more focus on class roles versus just general equipment. With your classes determining your playstyle and ability, it makes for some very interesting combinations. At first I was extremely disappointed I could not don the full cultist set and spam the bubble shield with hunters mark, but as I progressed I found the many minor perks you gain from your classes more than make up for the lack of armor bonuses. As I entered the lategame a plethora of options opened to me, and my build became genuinely fun to play. This game starts off like shit, I won't sugarcoat it. The story is contrived and the voice acting is decent at best, but the actual gameplay is where it shines. The addition of a wide variety of dragon hearts is quite a cool touch, but somewhat lackluster when you consider 90% of them are niche at best, and genuinely unusable at worst. I feel Remnant 2 plays smoother and more diversely than the first game, in terms of build quality and abilities, but certain "improvements" feel rather lacking. The minimap is god awful, bugging out and looking like shit; occasionally it decides a portion of land simply does not exist, or to get stuck at max zoom despite my efforts to move it out even slightly. Certain items are locked behind getting lucky with multiple layers of RNG tied to the main campaign, which I am not a fan of but begrudgingly grind out regardless. The final boss fight, however, was an experience to be sure. It has mechanics that I personally quite enjoyed and would place in my top 10 coolest boss fights solely because of 1 mechanic, ignoring the visuals included. I loved every second of the fight and it was truly a grand battle to finish out my journey. Unfortunately, the final boss of the DLC was a complete pushover. A friend and I with half-completed builds (we swapped off DOT builds to preserve his hammer for an alt boss kill reward) managed to beat the One True King first try on apocalypse difficulty. He had perhaps one threatening attack, which was quite literally just a massive AOE with maybe a 0.5 second windup. The gun you gain from killing him (alt kill where you don't break his hammer; yes that is genuinely a challenge it just takes damage as he uses it) is probably the coolest weapon I've used in both games, featuring an auto homing mode. That being said, it is close in terms of DPS and general playstyle/build to the Chicago typewriter (my beloved).

tl;dr Remnant 2 is not bad, but certain aspects hold it back from being a direct upgrade from the first game. I'd encourage picking this game up if it's on sale, but I cannot bring myself to recommend it at full price. Hopefully future DLC and updates will bring more content and potentially fix the more glaring issues.

This game legitimately surprised me.  I was expecting a looter-shooter that borrowed ideas from other games but I didn't expect it would implement those ideas better than those other games and surpass them.   It's scaling difficult incentivizes exploring and building out a character.  Exploring is made pleasant by a dynamically generated replayable content.   You can pick the most mundane task (ie. levelling up a subclass archetype) or grinding out a resource and combine it with the pursuit of some elusive item you need.  But at its core it encourages players to experiment and try out new class combinations, gear combinations, and offers the sandbox to build and test the most OP combination you can imagine.  No battlepass.  No pay-to-look-good storefront (looking at you Diablo devs).  It respects player's time and investment in the base game.   Highly recommended.

I feel like the talk around this game and hype was completely unjustified. I remember a lot of streamers and youtubers claiming this was basically the best thing since sliced bread, had a lot of content and felt really good to play.

Honestly, what a crock. Gunplay was so~so to the point I would say even Mass Effect 1 had better gunplay. The issue was there was zero impact behind your shots. You may as well have been mimicking shots with a stick to replicate the way this game treats shooting. Didn't matter the weapon, didn't matter the power it all felt like throwing a wet beanie bag at your target.

There's only three biomes outside of the intro, hub area, intermission area and final zone/boss area and they all felt very linear and uninspired. One of the two zones was essentially copy pasted from the original game with not much changed in terms of aesthetics. The story was downright terrible and the characters were incredibly bad. The ending also gave zero closure or explained anything at all that was going on. I won't go into it for risk of "spoilers" - if you'd be able to spoil a game that quite literally has no story - but it was crap.

All in all, taking my time, this took around 20 hours for me to beat mostly solo(I was probably AFK for around 6-8 hours at one point over the holidays). at a certain point, around 6 or 7 hours in I felt like I was still in the prologue only to realise I was well and truly in a decent chunk of the game. I thought there would be many more than just three biomes and was very surprised to find that there's only three biomes in the entire game which felt less than the original game.

Replay value? So, apparently each biome has around 2-3 different "stories" which is supposed to give "replay value" but the reality is it's just the same tileset randomly generated with different "overland" map layouts depending on the biome. It doesn't feel different and the randomness only feels random in terms of the dungeons you see at set points on the "overland" map. Honestly, why bother playing through a second or third time to "experience" these "stories" when the stories are so threadbare, uninteresting and literally have zero impact on the entire area save the boss fights you come against and a few layout changes to the map. It's not great.

Graphics are "okay", nothing great. I've seen better five years ago. Boss fights range from pump and dump kind of "fun" to "This is just bad design". The boss fights are never engaging, fun in and of themselves and only ever tend to be a pump and dump engagement with a few dodges here and there.

The DLC is a waste of money. It's not a new zone, it's the same zone but with a handful of "dungeons" included that can now spawn in the biome randomly and has a "story" but pretty much just uses the same or very similar layout.

I would give this one a miss unless you want to pick it up on the cheap for a quick 20 hours to waste. Otherwise, just watch a series instead. It's not a great game. If this were any more than 40 bucks the general consensus would be that the game isn't worth the money.

Biggest carrot I've ever chased in a video game. I strongly dislike: Souls games, bossing, and exploration. Elden Ring, Sekiro - no thanks. Even in AC6, which is even further from a Soulslike, I generally disliked bossing. But in Remnant 2, I am absolutely hooked on all three elements.

At first I wasn't sure about the game loop, but I just cleared the last boss in the campaign, and I gotta say I'M IN for the ride. Rerolling the worlds, exploring every inch of a tileset, and getting rewarded with sick gear and weapons is addicting AF. Every reroll is a unique RNG adventure with new maps/bosses, like a quasi roguelite. I don't actually know how to stop playing. It's bad.

That's not even mentioning the deep combat, rich lore, incredible boss design, and limitless build crafting. I slept on R2. Especially with its price point, it's EASILY my GOTY for 2023. Support these devs!

The game is great. I play it single player and everything people say about it is true. However, it's not perfect. The secrets are wayyy to secret. You need a guide, no matter how good you are at sleuthing. I want a challenge that I can realistically solve by myself or I would at least like to have a hint as to where to search for clues. If there was some kind of index that gives you a vague sense of how many secrets are undiscovered in a given area; that would go a long way to solving the playability issue. 
One spot that the game really excels in is the massive arsenal of unique and fun weapons. It's a shame your confined to only two at time. You can switch relatively quickly but with so many interesting tools it seems the two weapon paradigm is unnecessarily limiting. Lots of games let you have four or more weapons at the ready without any cost to smooth gameplay. You reach the capacity for max weapon upgrades early on so it becomes a tedious exercise of saving up resources to fully upgrade a new weapon before trying it out. I much prefer Warframe's model of leveling up weapons with usage to Dark Soul's resource investment. It encourages a great deal more experimentation and opens up the long term goal of mastering individual equipment. Were I the developer, I would consider a hybrid system. 
I like the low-level of storytelling, even though I love story games, sometimes you just want gameplay. This may be the one thing Remnant 1 does better than 2. In the first one, the entirety of the story came from scraps you pieced together while out exploring. Here, there is a lot more presentation (ironically in contrast to the discovery of secret areas and items). The world stories never seem to come to anything. You enter a world, find out who needs killing, do the killin', then hit the old dusty trail. The formula could use a good deal more subtlety and complexity and it has room for it considering how interesting the characters and entities are. You are usually congratulated on your bullet placement skills but the worlds never actually seem to be effected by your actions, not even your home Earth. It makes your feel like a tourist instead of a hero (or villain). 
I conclude with a quick shout-out to the Lovecraftian Fenrir! I love that monster and the super-powerful weapon you turn him into, the one that causes bleeding when the jaw shaped reticle closes and the many red-glowing eyes that open and close based on reload status. I want to be buried with it!

Got all achievements and like 99% of items (yeah I reran Yaesha 10+ times for Endaira's End and delivering goods to Empress/Leywise), solo apocalypse all the way so definitely not skill issue. 

Gameplay is undeniably brilliant, Venom, Annihilation and Nightweaver are some of the best Git Gud moments on higher difficulties. Yet balance is just out of the window in the late game. Far too many rings and amulets are straight-up Walmart/Wish versions of similar items that just clog up your inventory. Sidegrades and meme builds add to the fun, but not items that require situational activation but perform worse than the general version in like 95% of the situations. The sad part is that this applies to weapons as well, so many outlandishly stylish weapons are being neglected because all you need is Enigma and Krell Axe.

Build diversity is also extremely limited in apocalypse unless you are an utter masochist who can stand prolonged fights where you may get one-shotted at any moment. You either go medic tank builds with Leto or you go full glass cannon with elemental Ritualist, HUGS or Archon mod spam, maybe spectral blade bore build if you're feeling edgy. Top tier builds like these are extremely OP that let you melt bosses in under 2 mins, while anything else requires more than double the amount of time and effort.

Overall still a great game, but not as endlessly grindable as the first one. Grab it without hesitation if on discount.

Remnant II: A Sequel that Shines Bright in the Darkened Realm

"Remnant II" emerges from the shadows as a sequel that not only lives up to the expectations set by its predecessor but boldly carves its own path in the darkened realm of gaming. This game is a testament to the evolution of a franchise, showcasing refined mechanics, gripping storytelling, and a pulsating atmosphere that immerses players in a world teeming with danger and intrigue.

One of the standout features of "Remnant II" is its commitment to preserving the core essence of its predecessor while introducing innovative elements that elevate the overall experience. The gunplay, reminiscent of a well-choreographed dance, feels even more satisfying and responsive, offering a seamless blend of precision and chaos as you navigate through hordes of otherworldly foes.

The storytelling takes center stage, weaving a narrative tapestry that unfolds in captivating layers. The world-building is meticulous, drawing players deeper into a lore-rich universe where every corner holds secrets waiting to be unraveled. The characters are more than mere NPCs; they are companions on a journey, each with their own stories and motivations that add emotional weight to the overarching narrative.

Environments in "Remnant II" are a visual feast, showcasing the developers' attention to detail and artistic prowess. From desolate landscapes to eerie dungeons, each locale feels meticulously crafted, creating a sense of immersion that keeps players on the edge of their seats. The dynamic lighting and atmospheric effects contribute to the overall sense of foreboding, enhancing the game's dark and mysterious ambiance.

Cooperative multiplayer is a standout feature, offering an experience that encourages teamwork and camaraderie. Facing the challenges of "Remnant II" alongside friends is a rewarding endeavor, as each encounter becomes a strategic ballet of gunfire and abilities, culminating in shared triumphs and the thrill of overcoming formidable adversaries.

The question of whether I would recommend this game to other players elicits a resounding "Yes." "Remnant II" is a shining example of a sequel that not only builds upon the strengths of its predecessor but also pushes the boundaries of what a cooperative action RPG can achieve. Whether you're a fan of intense gunplay, rich storytelling, or challenging cooperative gameplay, "Remnant II" stands as a beacon in the darkness, beckoning players to embark on an unforgettable journey.

This game is immediately worse than the original. It runs like absolute crap. The story, which was told so well visually and with minimalism (you know, like a soulslike), is all lame cutscenes here. How did Forespoken get clowned on so hard yet this game contains lines like, "Oh, this is bad. Bad with a side of broccoli." One of the first interactions you have with an npc involves you asking them if they like a girl they know. Also, did I mention this game runs like crap? It does.

The main thing I want to say about this game is that it's a game specifically, and to its core, designed for 3+ people to play with. You can solo the game but soloing it for me has lead to an experience, that when I am not walking through the same area over and over again, I am dying to easy bosses from poorly designed mechanics. This review is written from the perspective of a single player.

The level and world design, while visually striking at first, ends up feeling extremely monochromatic. The level design lends itself to replayability first and foremost, but it comes at the cost of having a single unique environment. In fact, you will get a sense of deja vu as you encounter the same corners of an area used multiple times. Something about this felt particularly futile. As I walked through the 2nd or 3rd world with a unique art set, it just felt completely hollow to me, like I was in an infinitely repeating maze....because it was.

The combat mechanics I found often were unfair on veteran mode. So many times the boss I was fighting would create added enemies from every direction. If you turn to face one set of adds, your back will be to another set and your side will be to the boss. Better yet, some adds come from above too. There are so many threats at once that for a single player to take care of that mistakes are inevitable, and they made no effort to rescale the game for single players aside from health/damage changes. I will note though that adds are necessary because they drop ammo. But that doesn't make them fun.

What is even worse, is that one attack can lead to your death at almost any point in the game. In dark souls, for example, if you get attacked so hard that you fall down, you are immune from attacks for a moment until you can get up. In this game, if 3 enemies attack you at the same time, or one enemy has an animation that does 5 attacks in a row, you are going to get stunlocked and go from full health to 0. And you cannot dodge role immediately after an attack, and even if you do manage to roll away, the enemies push you aggressively to where rolling doesn't often create much distance and recovering from a scenario like this is very difficult.

These are my major gripes, but there were a lot of other small frustrations that added up, and I think being a coop game primarily, the solo experience itself almost feels like you are grinding an MMO doing repetitive tasks and gaining minor stats as you go, but you are ultimately playing an MMO alone which is one of the most soul sucking experiences I can imagine.

So this game isn't that bad, but I absolutely do not recommend it for solo play. It's unfulfilling without friends and potentially very frustrating depending on the areas and class you role. Some may ask why not play online with randoms. My game was set to public the entire time, and in 12 hours I was only paired with 3 different people. Trying to join a public game took over 5 minutes so I gave up on that idea, so I wouldn't recommend relying on the public game experience.

[h1]After 100% finishing this game, I noticed that..[/h1]
I had more fun playing the first Remnant.

I would still highly recommend this game, and there are many things Remnant 2 does better than Remnant FTA. but the following issues are what plagues this installment of Remnant:

[h2]Performance [/h2]
From Low FPS numbers, to stutters, to straight up crashes. It does not matter what is your rig you will face issues, if your rig is latest gen you will get crashes, if it is not then you will get ~60fps and still crash every now and then.

Read about the dev updates or other reviews for more details.

[h2]Difficulty [/h2]
While Remnant 1 mostly used a bunch of ADS to increase the difficulty of bosses (Not the best game design), it did also have some amazing boss fights which were both fun and challenging on Apocalypse difficulty (e.g: Ixillis )

Remnant 2 on the other hand, handles apoc difficulty by simply adding a ton of health to the boss and enemies.
This [i]DRAGS OUT[/i] the fights much longer than it should, and we end up having so many easy bosses with long looong fights. This makes [u]Apocalypse difficulty NOT FUN[/u] 

[h2]AI can't keep up [/h2]
Due to all the verticality added to this game, [u]the enemy Elites became so easy to beat.[/u]
Simply jump around from one platform to another and watch as the single digit IQ AI takes a moment to comprehend the [i]amazing trick[/i] you have pulled, or better yet, climb up the 1 meter platform and watch as the AI slowly starts the climbing animation while you empty the entire magazine into his nostrils, only for you to simply jump back down soon after.
Repeat this a few times aaand he's dead.

[h2]Weapons aren't as fun anymore[/h2]
I'm gonna name a few guns which are either not included in this game, or have been butchered unfortunately.
[list]
[*] Hive Cannon
[*] Beam Rifle
[*] Alternator
[*] Devastator
[*] Repulsor (Unique mod completely overshadowed by the Stasis Beam Mod)
[*] Spitfire :(
[/list]
Notice something? Every weapon that had the ability to do elemental dmg by default was changed. Spitfire was SO much fun, switching between a fully automatic weapon that FELT like a main weapon and a FLAMETHROWER was life man.. I never cared if it was the best side weapon, I still picked it every time. its replacement in Remnant 2 is so depressing I actively avoid unlocking it.
That's the thing about Remnant 1, it had way less guns but they all felt [b]Unique[/b]

Now let's compare this to remnant 2,
Wtf is the difference between a western classic, a silverback 500, and a service pistol?
the difference between a wrangler and a rusty lever action?
A sagittarius and a Royal hunting bow?

I know they have different stats but [u]they FEEL the same, why would I switch between weapons when my experience does not change?[/u]
There are exceptions like the cube gun, Enigma, Sorrow, etc.. but they are the minority in this game


[h2] The Good [/h2]
Overall I would still recommend this game, My review is coming from a remnant fanboy perspective which is why I'm so critical.

Everything mentioned below has been vastly improved upon in remnant 2 imo. They include:

[olist]
[*] Classes, an amazing addition
[*] Way More Items
[*] Puzzles are more fun
[*] Visuals
[*] Map design
[/olist]

[h2]Conclusion[/h2]
Great Game, Alleviated issues of the last Remnant but introduced some new issues.

This game is fantastic. The settings, the bosses, the variance of items and weapons and how those allow you to fully customize your gameplay are all spot on. They also knocked it out of the park with the replayability, both in terms of offering multiple difficulties and in how the procedural generation works. It massively rewards exploration, there are so many delightful secrets to find and there's almost always something new to discover.

Regarding loot, this doesn't randomly generate stats on the items you find which is a major plus imo. It's incredibly frustrating to find an item you've been hunting for in a game like Diablo but it had a bad random stat distribution. Here, if you find the item it's exactly what you expect and the same for everyone, making it much better balanced for how it's used in builds and easier for you to create the build you want.

Also, the co-op in this game is fantastic. It's very easy to drop in and out, and persists in a way that just lets you focus on having fun with your buddies. I've heard it's a bit more frustrating when you're playing with randos, but if you have a group of friends and you're on voice comms it's a blast.

This review needs a huge, bold preface: [b]You need to suffer through the tutorial and N'Erud I promise it gets worlds better. [/b]Starting at the first world boss, this game blossoms like crazy. The weapon and archetype gameplay and designs are super unique. The weapons feel very similar to Warframe however the combat is very in-line with souls-like games.

The Campaign was very solid. I did my first play through on Veteran difficulty and I very rarely felt like I was being cheaped out by enemy design. My biggest pain point was with very specific enemies with very unforgiving weak points or just enemies flat out overtuned (yes I'm talking about the green and blue sewer shits). However, the game does allow tons of freedom when it comes to tackling adversities so I never felt like I couldn't find a build that would significantly help with certain boss fights or enemies.

All the boss fights in my first campaign were pretty incredible but I have to shout out one boss in particular [spoiler]Venom was one of the most insane skill checks that this game had and was totally unexpected. This boss is arguably harder than Annihilation and was so unfair (in a fun way) at times that I really pulled every punch with my build just to delete this guy.[/spoiler] There were also some boss fights that were just horrific but usually those had a much smaller health pool and didn't have to really stand out too hard. 

The one key thing about Remnant is your story choices matter. You will get different rewards based on what options you chose. This is a key component to the entire campaign of remnant. There are two ways to mitigate FOMO: Adventure mode and Campaign re-rolling, both of which carry over all weapons and stats on your character. Adventure allows you to do a self isolated run of one major location (which again is going to be randomly generated and different on repeat playthroughs) whilst re-rolling the campaign allows you to do a fresh run. I am currently on my second campaign and am super surprised how fresh the game still feels on repeat. 

TL;DR this game impressed me beyond belief and I am shocked that I hated the game at first because the turn around was insane.

Remnant FTA was a phenomenal game and one of my favorites to date, but Remnant 2 has gone so above and beyond that sometimes I forget it's a sequel. 
In terms of artistic direction, Remnant 2 might just be one of the most visually stunning games of this decade, on par with the likes of Elden Ring, which is especially impressive considering R2's significantly lower budget and shorter development period. 
Gameplay-wise, R2 retains the most attractive elements of RFTA, namely its item balancing and build variety. There are more enemies, more weapons, more build possibilities, more mechanics, but one would be mistaken to categorize it as an RFTA expansion -- R2 is a spectacle, in a way that RFTA never tried to be. Even the UI shows this: in RFTA, the fast travel screen was a drop-down list of a handful of locations, while in R2, the UI has been overhauled into an intricately designed map with points of access. 
Small changes like these hints at a fundamental shift in GFG's creative vision with this game: they don't want to be a casual looter shooter anymore, they want to be taken seriously. However, some problems I have with this game also arises from this shift. 
From the impossible-to-find secrets to puzzle boss fights like the labyrinth sentinel, it seems that R2 takes itself too seriously at times. It demands so much energy and patience from the player that I can see many potential fans being driven away, but even when you commit your full attention, there is always that sinking knowledge that you're missing out on 80% of the game's content by not checking the wiki. That, to me, is the core issue with R2, even more than the scaling system that everyone hates. I'm glad that R2 is getting at least three DLCs, and I hope GFG manages to find a compromise in the future. A middle ground between wanting to speak and wanting to sell, I suppose.

Review : 
The game is exactly what is advertised. A soulslike experience with guns that is also really good in a co-op format. The bosses and enemies all seem to be quite well designed exactly for a co-op experience which is ,in my opinion, the most important thing seeing as co-op pretty much trivializies a lot of soulslikes. 
I will say however enemies and bosses being designed around co-op doesnt necessarily mean they are challenging or difficult. I do wish some of the bosses and enemies were a little more engaging.
The Areas are fine with some being better than others, but Ill chalk that down to personal preference more than anything else. 
Music is also quite enjoyable, a rather generic orchestral score for most of these, a staple of the genre. Alas, it serves its purpose kinda well.
One thing to note is that the game is, atleast to a certain degree, procedurally generated, which means aside from the general aesthetic of some areas and aside from the most basic of enemy variants you could do a playthrough 3 or 4 times and never encounter the same boss in the same spot. This does wonders for replayability but if you get unlucky with your rng regarding bosses and their placement you could be left enjoying the game less your first time around than if you dealt with the bosses in the backlog.

[spoiler]The final boss is super challenging and its pretty much the only boss in the game that had me and my friends die more than a handful of times. It is also the best boss in the game in my opinion especially due to the very very unique design of said boss fight. If you arent won over by the game I urge you to stick around until the end atleast with your first time. Its worth it. [/spoiler]

I really did not enjoy my time with this game despite expecting to. I am a long time Souls fan with over 1k hours in Dark Souls + Elden Ring combined. This game did not hit the spot for me, for a few major reasons which I will list.

1. Lack of graphics options and poor optimization. Game runs fine mostly when playing on the absolute lowest settings but even then, in actual fights the framerate can tank to really low numbers. This is on a 1080ti and i7 7700k cpu.

2. The voice acting/story is really, really bad. It's like a bootleg TV show from the late 90s. I couldn't put up with it. I wish I'd skipped more of the scenes and turned off the dialogue because all it really did was break my immersion.

3. It's blurry. The game uses upscaling because the devs didn't spend time optimizing it so the game just ends up looking somewhat blurry. Not a fan.

Obviously having only played a few hours of it I'm not equipped to review the entirety of the game but I played enough of it to confidently say that I do not recommend it to most people and that I will not be continuing to play it.

Boring and not fun.  Almost all the systems inside the game don't matter.

If you can aim-and-shoot, as well as dodge - you will beat the game.  I don't need to use class archetype skills.  I don't need to upgrade my relic or use any shards in it.  I don't need to use or upgrade mutaters.

The only thing you need to do is upgrade your weapons (so you don't run out of ammo).  But you can easily use the beginner weapons to carry you through the game!

Do NOT use the cube gun as it conflicts with picking up loot.  Cube gun doesn't use ammo, so you can never pick up 'secondary ammo'.  But 'secondary ammo' always drops on the very top of loot stacks, so you can't pick-up any loot below the secondary ammo.  You need to switch secondaries, fire off rounds, reload, then pick everything up, and switch back your secondary.

Also MOB behaviour is extremely disappointing.  It starts very fun and engaging in Yeasha (first zone) with mobs spawning behind you, flanking you, flying at you from above.  It's a great start and leaves you eager for more.  All later zones MOB behaviour is simplified, linear from the front, and super easy compared to what you experienced earlier.  It feels like two different company/teams worked on different levels.

Early game - linear levels with fast paced engaging combat.  Mid and late game - maze levels with way less and much simpler combat.

Not an innovative game, definitely not game of the year.

[b]Short and Sweet answer on whether or not you should play this game;[/b]
Yes, the gameplay loop, combat and world building is top notch that will entertain you especially if you bring friends. The negatives are mostly the laughable "story" and optimisation issues.

[b]Long and Detailed review then;[/b]
The Positives:
*The gunplay and class system is interesting and really incentives build experimentation.
*World exploration and building is another thing that's done really well (for the most part), some of the world specific stories  are really well done and captivating.
*A lot of hidden secrets that (for the most part) are logic based, or based on exploration. Some of them are just pure bs and random with no clues given.
*Most of the bosses are also done splendidly, a pure spectacle with tight mechanics that will test your skill and response time.
*The end bosses of every world are amazing and have different forms and battles depending on dialogue or story options you've made throughout the world's run. With different rewards depending on what boss or what form of the boss you've killed.
*Replayability is the name of the game, every campaign is randomly generated with tilesets, items, specific end bosses of the worlds and dungeons. The story of the worlds can even be different depending on which one got spawned in. Hell, even the starting world is random between three options. I cannot stress this enough, if you enjoy a game with a lot of replayability then this might be the game for you.

The Negatives:
*The main story is so a laughably bad, you can ignore it completely and please do ignore it. The "main" characters in the central hub world are also not anything to write home about. I have played Remnant 1 and even I was still confused on who they were and why they were at the camp.
*The game's optimisation is atrocious, it's the worse I've seen in recent years. Everyone I know meets the recommended requirements with flying colours, have the game installed on an SSD and all of us are forced to play the game on low to medium settings. And still we get awful stuttering, horrific frame drops and crashes.They bring out patches and updates that fixes the optimisation issues, but the very next patch throws out all of those fixes and introduces even more problems. The games optimisation is awful and I blame the AI upscalling for making game devs complacent with optimisation, because why fix it when AI will do it for you?
*Though the games worlds have amazing exploration, there is one world that just drags the entire experience down to a grinding halt. N'Erud is the worst world to run through by far, it's nothing but a grey desert with roaming packs of enemies with dungeons scattered all throughout the very edges of the map. N'Erud's overworld maps would have to be reduced by half to make it an enjoyable experience, because as of right now, it just takes forever to go anywhere and do anything. It's a shame because N'Erud's story, end boss and world building is amazing, but the gameplay experience is just awful.
*Final thing I'll mention is the boss design, though the majority of the bosses are designed really well and are punishing but fair. Some of them are just cancer. Slipping up one mechanic equals an instant death even on the lower difficulties, oh and if you're playing 2 player co-op, then goodluck in trying to find an opening to revive your friend, because the boss is going to pound you into the dirt where you belong.I believe a Youtuber said it best. Remnant 1 feels like Dark Souls, but Remnant 2 feels like Elden Ring.

I would also like to point out that the balance of the game can be a bit wonky at times as well. Specifically the games balance around the amount of players in a world. If you're playing the game solo then it's fine, it's a test of skill and patience. If you play in a three man group then it's fine as well, if one of the party goes down, one can distract the enemies while the other goes to revive. But oh damn, the game was not balanced around a two player team. If your friend goes down and there are enemies nearby, or a boss is currently beating your ass, just let them to die and try to kill the enemies yourself. I was forced to always have a specific build equipped in order to revive my friend remotely, because if I ever got near him, the enemies or boss would just instantly attack me, forcing me to either dodge spam and try again over and over again, or they'd just kill me outright.

I know I've said a lot of negative things, but thinking back on the game, it's mostly the optimisation that's a major gripe that makes me want to never play it again. Playing the game and discovering the plethora of secrets that are hidden with a full group of friends, has been some of the most fun I've had in a long while though, and would recommend the game based purely on that aspect.

The initial hours of gameplay in this looter shooter are quite enjoyable, showcasing a decent experience. The level design is intriguing, featuring some engaging puzzles. Nonetheless, the primary issue lies in performance, rendering the game practically unplayable without DLSS/FSR, even on high-end graphics cards. The end-game zones are worse, as the game frequently crashes and is riddled with bugs.

(as of now, I am unable to progress in my campaign because the game crashes at a certain area and resets progress every time )

Despite introducing interesting classes/archetypes, the developers imposed a cap on traits, compelling players to alter their builds periodically. However, the grind for these builds becomes tedious, as players are constrained to repetitively face the same 3-4 enemy types for leveling up and experimentation.

The graphics are OK, but appear slightly dated.  Not bad by any means.  Just not up to the level of other modern games on PC.  I was a little worried by the appearance of Ward 13, but it gets better once you start moving through the dungeons and biomes. Overall – Remnant II is unfortunately a great marker for the trend that PC gaming had during 2023. Developers would release an incomplete, broken, game and then stop supporting it shortly after. I checked the steam forums and reddit for a fix, there wasn’t an official fix from the developer, but some fellow redditors had a solution that involved changing some backups save files. I was able to load in and beat the final boss, but this issue was unforgivable for me, how has the developer not patched this? I wouldn’t recommend this game to anyone. Not Recommended.

Remnant 2 has been described as Dark Souls with guns, and I think that's almost right. More accurate would be "Dark Souls with guns but without the controls to make that work, or any consequences for failure and really messed up progression". Essentially, if you are here for the guns, progression is over as soon as you walk in the door - with the exception of one pistol in the first dungeon, you aren't going to find any other guns in this game. Bows and magic scepters galore, yes, but no actual GUN guns. And this by no means holds you back - by all means, upgrade your starting gear to the nines, it WILL carry you through the end of the game. Assuming of course you don't get bored before the end of the game, because with no consequences for death, and no incentive to explore, the game's threadbare story gets boring very quickly - especially when the writers would rather say (almost verbatim!) "shut up tho" when questioned about certain aspects of the story. There's also no real challenge, as you don't lose any resources on death, and cash is only used for upgrading weapons - you gain XP separately. Boss fights aren't that great either - a lot of them are just bullet sponge versions of normal enemies, or hordes or normal enemies. Attacks are not particularly well telegraphed, and even on light equip loads, rolling feels extremely clunky, and has far, FAR too many recovery frames. Sprinting is awkward and slow, and while it's not so slow you can't break off enemies, it's so slow that it FEELS like you can't actually escape. Which is of course a big problem when your primary combat is ranged, your melee options are lackluster, and the shitty dodge roll leaves you with 0 good tools for close engagements. 

I'm sure if you co-op this with friends shit-talking each other over voice chat it's fine (also there's friendly fire, so don't try to melee things when someone is shooting them), but as a single-player experience there REALLY isn't a lot here. Heck, even as a co-op experience, with no gear to seek out or character build objectives to hit, I struggle to find a reason to get a group of friends together to play this.

Poorly designed at all times and in all aspects. Interesting boss design but ultimately not worth playing because of stun-lock combos, canned animations limiting player input, and horrendously boring gunplay. All enemies in all areas use entirely swarm mechanics, frequently if not always spawning and teleporting behind the player. Hit registration is entirely unreliable as "Vulnerable" spots just either randomly count or don't. Enemies are visually interesting but because of their overly busy design you can't track vulnerable strikes at all. You will get a vulnerable strike on an enemy's obvious glowing weak point and then shoot it again on the same enemy and do regular damage. Other times you'll shoot the same type of enemy in an entirely unremarkable spot on their body and it will flash as a Vulnerable hit. Guns are unsatisfying to use and classes are boring and equally unsatisfying. Guns have, for lack of a better term, no character or handling.  Melee is surprisingly nice to strike enemies with but the enemy and environment design means melee is totally ineffective on a great deal of enemies, especially small annoying swarm ones.

"Dark Souls with guns." doesn't do this game justice. Yes, there's lots of concepts here from Dark Souls, but there's also plenty of other things too. The class system is the biggest thing that sets this apart. It literally determines what your character does. Plus, this game puts it's own spin on the class system by letting your character equip two classes at the same time, and you can switch classes at any time.

Also, guns may be the main focus of this game, but melee is very powerful too. I've been doing mostly melee for a while, and it feels a little overpowered. It's only when I encounter a group of flying enemies or a floating boss that I feel the need to fire a gun. However, this is on easy mode. Harder difficulties may create a different experience.

Also, I had a great time starting out as the Handler. It comes with a dog that fights, heals, and can even revive you when you're down. You can also pet it. <3

Decent 3rd person shooter with a lemon twist of Bloodborne, especially in the weird Victorian London-esqe world. The focus on ranged weapons gives it a different flavor but muddles some of the well-oiled combat you might expect from a proper FROMSOFT "soulsborne".

Making a character build is fun. You'll have access to a lot of different guns and melee options, plus rings and runes that give you useful passive abilities. Once you have access to multiple classes, you can mix two of them together to create some interesting combos. I enjoyed combing the Ritualist with the Gunslinger to dump a bunch of damage-over-time effects on enemies, which then increased my crit chance thanks to my weapon mod, then mag-dumping an LMG in their face.

Random generation of the worlds with different hand-made dungeons gives some extra replayability and exploration, though if you're the type that likes to use guides to find all the secrets you missed the first time around (or just to help you when you're stuck) you'll have a harder time due everyone's playthrough being different.

Recommend playing with friends, a lot of the combat is built with co-op in mind.

I enjoyed exploring with friends in the first dozen hours, but everything changed after entering the third playthrough. One issue is that, as a player, I need these weapons and items to perform better in boss battles, rather than spending my time searching in a soul-like game just for some collections. 
And, this game encourages free exploration on random maps, but it turns out to be a pseudo-random world. While this may not appear significant, the late-game experience becomes poor due to several factors. 

1.Limited Map Options: The absence of the option to freely combine levels results in players constantly recreating maps in Adventure Mode to find desired hidden content. The lack of a choice to freely combine maps leads to repetitive experiences.
2.Limited Randomization: Random maps offer only a limited number of permutations, making me feel bored when facing repetitive terrains and monsters again and again. This design doesn't seem wiser than including all contents in a single large map.
3.Poor Item Interface: The item interface has poor indexing, making it challenging to select needed equipment among dozens of items. The game lacks any indication of progress in collecting hidden equipment, which is disappointing for a collection-oriented player.

In conclusion, while Ruins 2 aims for replayability through rich hidden elements, it falls short due to a lack of consideration for true replayability.

TL;DR: 7.5-8.5 depending on your expectations and wants from a game. Good value on sales.

PROS:
Gorgeous scenes, very different stylish worlds, nice music, and a solid sequel overall. Core gameplay ideas remained same but some alterations were made and game is more action packed compared to the first one. Bosses are still challenging and fun.

CONS:
Core gameplay loop remains same for all worlds, not that many differences between enemies and it gets kinda tedious going from checkpoint to checkpoint (e.g. optional dungeons) and clearing regular mobs.

MEHS:
The delivery of worldbuilding does not meet the scenery of the worlds you visit: you just get to a world and go shooting-tooting. Nobody explains you what's happening until like 1/3 of clearing the world and the notes and diaries you find don't help much.

The idea of 1 world 2 plots seemed cool, but the end result is kinda strange: you can't dive much into the plot on the first try and the level becomes just a set of dungeons and corridors for you to clear and move the plot.

The dialogue sound disappears if you move camera from the speaker, that was pretty weird.

END COMPARISON:
Imagine getting a Rolls-Royce on a budget: stylish, luxury with a lot on technical feats here and there and a lot of effort being put into it. And then driving for groceries in traffic jams.

Same here: a lot of effort from designers, change of day/night and associated events, tons of secrets on levels. And it's all boils down to pretty repetitive gameplay for the most part, remember: boss battles are sparse.

I'm surprised to see such positive reviews for this game. Remnant 2 felt like a huge downgrade in replayabilty when compared to the first Remnant game. A big reason for this is the lack of Survival mode which was endlessly replayable in the first game. I'm sure down the line Remnant 2 will add this feature but that brings up the other problem with this game: the bosses. They were either headache inducing or complete pushovers. There really wasn't any middle ground for the boss difficulty and fight mechanics, never mind the fact a few boss fights had such cluttered visual effects to the point it could be hard to spot the boss in the visual mess. This leads to the next problem: enemy types. The enemy types were boring almost all the way through. Humanoids were cool looking to fight, but largely pushovers, and the droid and "zombie" type enemies were complete borefests to engage with and look at. Only the first world with the original and new Root enemies were interesting to me (and the enemies at the very tail end of the game). That brings up the next problem: only three core biomes, again, a downgrade from the first game. Boring enemies, lackluster locations, and mostly boring bosses, a huge problem for this "soulslike" game. 

    The archetype system at first seemed interesting but actually unlocking the archetypes becomes a headache. This game at the end of the day is a chore to grind, so locking some of the interesting archetypes behind obscure requirements kind of limits what classes you can actually beat the game with on the first attempt. Beyond min-maxing and grinding your heart out at the "end game" I don't really see a reason using anything besides the starting classes. You'll have to pick a new unleveled archetype mid way through your first playthrough and essentially grind it up to an acceptable level or it will functionally be a downgrade in your power level. Also, just for humors sake: look up how to unlock the summoner. It's beyond frustrating. It is the opposite of fun. It also takes a while to level the archetypes and it's prohibitively expensive to upgrade guns, so on your first play through you better like the gun you chose and the archetype you chose. Ultimately the game is set up for grindability but for what reason? To steamroll the mostly boring bosses or bang your head against the wall on the others? (Venom was the only hard boss I enjoyed fighting) To repeatedly plink away the dreadfully boring robots? To grind an archetype which at the end of the day isn't better than the starting ones? Oh yeah, there is no text or voice chat in this game so playing with randoms is a complete headache that shouldn't be. There were so many situations where if I could've merely typed a sentence it would have resolved a wipe to a boss mechanic. Everyone else who did not recommend this game complained about the connectivity issues (which are there) but to me the biggest problems are with the core mechanics, locations, and enemies in the game. It's a beautiful game that is good enough for one play through but it completely misses the magic and endless replayability of the first game. The second I finished the last boss I let out a sigh because I knew I would not be buying any of the DLC's or playing this game again.

If you make it past the first 2-3 hours of uninteresting intro and tutorial, the game just skyrockets to a completely unexpected gem.
You have co-op looting shooting and dungeons/trials of Destiny, and the questing/difficulty of the Souls Series.
The main campaign is complete bait, as the best experience is explored in the world(s).
The bulk of the fun is in the gameplay and exploration. 
STARTING is the part where you're at your weakest and easily drops many players off. 
It's akin to Destiny or any MMO in a smaller scope.

Side quests and stories are that of a Souls game somewhat... Good or bad depending on the player
(if you are an *actual* Souls fan, then you'd know that answer..)

Build variety and strength comes with time. As you require independent questing for specific loot, or just playing and using what you get luckily dropped. Key items and quests require a web of pathing if you want anything specific. Remember playing Elden Ring or any souls game and wanting a specific armor or weapon from a questline? Well that exists here, and it's made as fun.

Builds really only come online after you unlock a secondary class, as there's multiclassing, and when you really start getting good traits/mods/rings/amulets. Everything is unlocked via bosses, world drops or questlines. There are very few NPCs with exceptions.

The level designs are that of a roguelike but with soulslike checkpoints, and every run you FIRST-TIME start a world you get different layouts and key areas with different events/quests going on. The order of the worlds you go through will be random, with the only static ones being the required ones to progress. And yes, if you don't like what locations your world ended up rolling, you can re-roll at will.
ALL character progress stays.
This is very well executed replayability and it's keeps you playing.

This is very much worth getting, especially at it's current sale price.
Be wary of the performance, the FPS does struggle and it's a rather demanding game.

This game is my biggest disappointment of 2023. For being a sequel, it offers little noticeable improvement over the gameplay systems of Remnant 1, systems which can best be described as serviceable.

Gunplay is fine, and dodging and movement feel fine, nothing to write home about. Weapons and archetypes are cool, but often have strange caveats that make them hard to work with, and many of them. especially the cool ones, are absolute nonsense to unlock. 

Artstyle is awesome, with enemies and levels being amazing to look at and play with, and the top-notch graphics really push it along as well, but the soundscape is overall meh, with little noteworthy to mention.

Story is nonsensical, with pretty much everything explained in grand and flowery sentences that clearly attempt to invoke Dark Souls in their nature, but lack any actual meaning that make Dark Souls engaging. There is no flow to the story, since levels are 100% disconnected from the plot outside of the very last one, and much of the dialogue is laughably terrible.

Bosses are, overall, boring and unnoteworthy, it felt like many were designed with the idea of co-op in mind, and were more puzzle bosses than actual combat challenges. Most weren't very challenging, to the point where the final boss, which, without spoiling anything, is *awesome* and very challenging, was a massive shock since nothing prepared us for that.

The game is very short, I finished it in 19 with a friend and we hardly rushed it, probably wouldn't be much slower by yourself since we did spend quite a bit just shooting the shit in the main hub. It feels like a game that gets its length from enticing you to replay with a different build, but with how stupid it can be to unlock many of the cooler weapons and archetypes, as mentioned previously, I just have no desire to actually do so. Plus, ultimately, there's not enough service put into the gunplay that I can image getting a different gun would actually feel super different.

Remnant is yet another game claiming a "souls-like" experience, but fails to execute on all fronts. In particular, well designed bosses are the core of a souls experience; however, 90% of the bosses are generic and lazily designed. With the rare exception, they all generally fall into the following categories:

A) Generic, easy-to-kill boss with nonstop adds to artificially increase difficulty
B) Boss bum rushes the player in a tiny, enclosed area dealing heavy damage
C) Puzzles that aren't bosses, but serve as the capstone to the world or side area

Unfortunately, A and B are the norm with many fights being so poor that the player can't see the boss attacks due to the camera or due to the constant attack spam and stunlocks from adds. (Chained stunlocks leading to death are extremely common even on the easiest difficulty. It's apparent that the devs do not fundamentally understand how to design difficult enemies that can still present a fair fight.)

The best "bosses" in the game are almost all in category C, which are a breath of fresh air compared to the rest of the game. I genuinely enjoyed them with the "fights" displaying unique concepts and mechanics. Unfortunately, these bosses are in the minority. 

There are several fun bosses (Root Mother or Cancer for example) that demonstrate that the designers could make better fights, but apparently they just can't do it consistently without resorting to lazy design decisions. [u]The most likely explanation is that the inclusion of co-op and the randomized, "rogue-like" campaign structure wrecked enemy and boss balancing to the detriment of the entire game.[/u]

One of the game's few bright spots are the puzzles and secrets, which are genuinely difficult enough for puzzle enjoyers to sink their teeth into; however, this aspect of the game isn't enough to overcome what is fundamentally an annoying and frustrating experience.

Very much enjoying this game even after over 100 hours. I also enjoyed the first game, but I like pretty much all of the changes that were made for the sequel.

Some things I like:
-Price tag is lower than most new games today.
-Style is mostly separated from game performance. There is a dark souls like roll mechanic that is affected by your armor weight but it is only one minor facet of build selection and it can be adjusted with rings and such if you want to wear heavier armor but have lighter roll etc.
-Guns feel very punchy and satisfying to use. The weapon variety is good and the balance between weapons is better than most games. There are just a couple of truly overpowered weapons.
-Build variety is staggering with the ability to choose two classes at a time, weapons, MODifiers, mutators, relics, relic shards, amulets, and four ring slots. It's fun to try out all of these things and it feels good to find a combo that works well for you.
-I absolutely love the aesthetics of the game. Each world has its own contributions, but overall it comes to a weird mix of post-apocalyptic and low-fantasy, though Losomn brought in some higher fantasy stuff too.

As an aside, the people who complain about the removal of armor bonuses from the first game are wrong. They were unnecessarily restrictive and killed style and fashion souls. You were always punished for not wearing a single armor set. Also, these bonuses were moved to Mutators and Relic shards so the functionality remains in this game, but decoupled from armor.

A few negatives but not dealbreakers for me:
-Game can be a bit unstable. Sometimes nothing, other times a couple crashes over several hours. DO NOT ALT TAB IF YOU CAN POSSIBLY HELP IT.
-Some of the weapons and gear are impossible to find without using wikis. The methods are really cool, but most people would never ever figure this stuff out on their own.

My personal rating for this game is 9/10. Very close to a perfect game. Tons of fun.

[h2] Dark Souls with Guns, The Sequel [/h2]

Bought this game about a month after its release since I had just finished Remnant: From the Ashes by then. It's just as addicting as Remnant: FtA was for me, kept my mind occupied and focused downloading the boss' moveset instead of mindlessly wandering the internet. Now to the actual review:

[hr][/hr]

[u] Graphics[/u]

A large improvement from Remnant: FtA. 

[u] Gameplay[/u]

Dark Souls but with Guns and World RNG.
You can go for Melee builds but I would assume that would be for a second run of the campaign (I haven't attempted this yet). Trait points being capped (to 65) compared to FtA (no caps at all) took some getting used to, but it wasn't that bad considering I had to really think about where to put points into for a specific build. (They increased the cap with the release of DLC1 to 85) (Note: you don't have to own the DLC)

[b] You can pet the dog, big W.[/b]


[u] Audio[/u]

It won't kill your eardrums that's for sure. Music's great as well, and don't you dare skip the credits song when you get there.

[u] PC Requirements[/u]

I played on Ultra with DLSS on Balanced averaging 90 to 100-ish frames.
RTX 3060 Ti + Ryzen 5 5600x, 32gb RAM @ 3600MHz.

[u] Difficulty[/u]

Souls-like gameplay but with difficulty settings.

[u] Grind[/u]

Could take months to get everything unless this is the only game you play daily or every other day;
or use Remnant Save Guardian to analyze your rolls and save a lot of time trying to find a specific item; [strike] and/or utilize save scumming, your move. [/strike]


[u] Story[/u]

If you are into lore then this game is a treat. There's too many things to read in one of the worlds though lmao. Unfortunately, you can't read in-game voice logs from a menu, you have to listen to it from start to finish; on the upside there's only one world with voice logs anyway.

[u] Game Time[/u]

I finished the story in [b] 69 hours, [/b] while also doing [b] 2 runs on Adventure mode. [/b] Could easily go into the hundreds.

[u] Price[/u]

Definitely worth the money, even more so on sale.

[u] Bugs[/u]

Unless some bugs are apparent (e.g. a skill not charging), you won't notice some bugs like in damage calculations until you go to the comment section in the wiki for that specific ring/amulet/mutator/mod/skill or you calculate it yourself. Another thing, this game was crashing a lot for me and it kept giving the same error as anyone else, I assumed it was some of the background apps I was running since they always closed when the game crashed. When I closed those (ZeroTier and HWiNFO), the game stopped crashing for me.

[hr][/hr]

All in all, a great game and possibly more fun with people (my friends couldn't play since they're saving money or their war machine will be able to cook an omelette while running the game, and then explode). If you guys want me to number it then I'd give it a 9/10.

I played over a hundred hours of the first game and really enjoyed its infinite replayability due to the fact that you had a bajillion traits and no trait cap. This game has a trait cap. 

It's gorgeous, the worldbuilding is fun, but I feel like by capping traits they changed a core aspect of the game that a lot of the players from the first enjoyed. They are increasing trait cap with the new DLC, but that still doesn't change the fact that there's no reason for me to replay the game after I've got my build set. 

In the first game, your build was dependent on your equipment, but your traits helped you survive and you could slowly through many hours become OP. And that was super rewarding! I'd struggle through harder difficulties at first, but later found myself able to solo them as I both learned the game and beefed up my character. I loved seeing that progress, feeling like I earned being an OP deathbomb. If I wanted to steamroll through a dungeon I'd go to an easier difficulty, if I wanted to work for the win I'd bump it up. 

Maybe I'll come back to this game once they develop it some more, but I really don't see the point. I don't understand why they changed the game's dynamic so much, either -- it rewarded hours put in and there's no PvP so there's no reason not to let people become OP.

Despite saying that, I genuinely believe that people should just play Remnant 1 instead. A lot of the things Remnant 2 does has been improved vastly from Remnant 1, such as the addition of classes to allow even more customization to your active abilities than before.

Alternatively...

Everything Remnant 1 did poorly, Remnant 2 does much worse at.

The highs in this game may be much higher than its predecessor, but boy do its low get so much deeper into the mud. For example, I really disliked most of the bosses. Remnant 1 had an issue with redoing Elites as bosses, but usually they had some sort of really interesting arena to play around like with the Archer Elite. In Remnant 2 when they bring back that same Archer boss fight it is found in a flat open area with only a single tree in the center.

This sort of downgrade in the bosses also reflect in the actual enemies as well. I found the way enemies approached the player in this game were often less interesting than they were in Remnant 1 with only a few highlights to mention.

That's a small thing I noted, but the biggest downgrade to me was obtaining weapons. In Remnant 1 most weapons had to be found, but in Remnant 2 most of them are just bought from Brabus. It's like the discovery is just gone. Sure rings are more plentiful, and some of them are far more interesting than what Remnant 1 ever came up with, but I really miss just being able to play Pokemon with guns. To have that ability to say wow and just put the sucker in my hand and test it out.

Honestly the more I play Remnant 2 the more sad I get. I hope they make another game, maybe not a direct sequel since I feel like this game made retcons to the previous two games in the series, but I wanna see them experiment and improve the formula some more.

Remnant 2: An In-Depth Review

Remnant 2, the long-awaited sequel to the Souls-like shooter Remnant: From the Ashes, arrived in July 2023. So, after months of exploration, boss battles, and loot drops, is it a worthy successor? Let's delve deep into the world of Remnant 2 and see what's in store.

Story & Worldbuilding:

The narrative takes place years after the events of the first game. The Root has seemingly been defeated, but its remnants still plague the world. As a "Scour" tasked with rebuilding civilization, you'll travel through procedurally generated worlds called "Wards" brimming with hostile creatures and environmental hazards. While the story takes a backseat to the gameplay, it provides enough intrigue and lore to keep you invested, with cryptic messages and environmental storytelling adding depth.

Gameplay & Combat:

Remnant 2 shines in its refined combat. The satisfying gunplay combines with strategic melee options, demanding mastery of both to tackle the diverse enemy roster. Dodging, parrying, and weapon mods add layers of complexity, creating a rewarding loop of learning enemy patterns and exploiting weaknesses. The addition of four distinct archetypes (Handler, Hunter, Challenger, Medic) and multi-classing opens up diverse character builds and playstyles, catering to various preferences.

Level Design & Progression:

The procedurally generated Wards offer surprising variety in environments and enemy encounters. Each playthrough feels fresh, ensuring replayability. However, the lack of handholding can be frustrating at times, with unclear objectives and map navigation demanding player initiative. Progression feels satisfying, with loot drops rewarding exploration and experimentation. The crafting system lets you tailor weapons and armor to your preferred playstyle, further enhancing the sense of customization.

Multiplayer & Co-op:

Remnant 2 shines in its co-operative aspect. Up to three players can tackle the Wards together, creating a fun and challenging experience. Sharing resources, reviving fallen comrades, and coordinating strategies adds another layer of depth to the gameplay. However, some technical issues like inconsistent hit registration and frame drops can dampen the co-op experience.

Technical Aspects:

The visuals are decent, with detailed environments and impressive boss designs. However, certain textures and animations lack polish. Performance is generally smooth on higher-end hardware, but frame drops and minor technical hiccups can occasionally disrupt the flow.

Overall Verdict:

Remnant 2 is a solid evolution of its predecessor. The refined combat, diverse world design, and satisfying loot loop offer a deeply engaging experience. While the story takes a backseat and technical issues persist, the core gameplay loop and co-op potential are undoubtedly captivating. If you enjoyed the first Remnant or crave a challenging Souls-like shooter with unique twists, Remnant 2 is definitely worth diving into.

Here are some additional points to consider:

    The difficulty curve can be steep, especially for newcomers to the genre.
    The lack of fast travel in Adventure Mode can feel tedious at times.
    The ending might leave some players wanting more closure.

Final Score: 8/10

Remnant 2 is a rewarding and challenging experience that builds upon the foundations of its predecessor. While not without its flaws, it offers a unique blend of Souls-like action, shooter mechanics, and procedural worldbuilding that will keep you hooked for hours on end.

I hope this in-depth review provides you with a comprehensive understanding of Remnant 2 and helps you decide whether it's the right game for you. Enjoy the Root!

This is an excellent, if slightly flawed, game.  I truly enjoyed the first Remnant and the sequel improves on pretty much everything.  However, some of the flaws in the first game are present here as well.

Combat is a blast and there is a fantastic selection of classes, skills, gear and weapons to use.  Some of the weapons are really unique and deviate from standard shooter formulas.  The armor in particular is amazing looking, even if it's been rendered mostly aesthetic only in this game.

I only have two real complaints.  The leveling and progression systems are awful.  Truly terrible, same as the first game.  Because the world scaling always matches your power level, upgrading your weapons actually hurts you.  Upgrading in a game should always be a pure benefit for the player and gated behind resources if you want to limit progression.  The second issue is that a lot of the content is locked behind RNG that even rerolling adventure mode can't fix.  For example, there is a particular weapon that requires you to get two different random levels in the same campaign because you have to pick up an item and then turn it in much later.  Quest items can't be brought across from Adventure mode and you can't check your campaign to see if you've rolled both of the required areas.  This is really unsatisfying if you are looking to get that particular gear.

Overall I really enjoyed my 54 hours with the game on my first play through and definitely recommend this to anyone who enjoys 3rd person shooters.
