So, the long of the short is that - yes. I recommend this game. I've had my fun, I think it's a fun and fairly decent game for what it is despite the few annoyances I have with it. It's an improvement over the first game in many ways, though it makes similar mistakes its predecessor does while making some of its own.

The individual worlds are more interesting than the game's "overarching" story, much like the first game. It is also a painfully *short* game in terms of its main quest, though this can work in the games favour in ways I'll touch on later. The main story is, also, woefully underdeveloped with characters I don't *really* care about and the game tries *oh so hard* to make me care, or make me think they are cool. They are not. It's a tiny bit... it made me wince. To clarify - these are characters from the first game too. The characters barely came up in the main game's story, apparently being developed more in the DLCs (which I never played.)

This game gets its length from its replayability.. You won't see all of the dungeons, secrets, and cool shit in your first play through of any area (except the labyrinth which, again, we did not see enough of.), areas are structured together similar to how many 'randomly generated' games handle it, through premade tiles that the game will glue together. This game, thankfully, marks what areas are mandatory for progression and what areas are not through its map, and I appreciate that so much. It REALLY cuts down the tedium of repeat playthroughs, an issue with the first game.

I do believe the enemy design is mostly improved from the first game. The varied weakspots are welcomed to a degree, robots from N'erud having little sensors on the sides you have to aim for, humanoids usually sporting the head, etc. There's also fewer enemies in this game that wear my complaint from the first game on their head, quite literally, but those enemies are often still there... and unfortunately extended to many of the "minibosses" that make up most of the dungeons; another thing i dislike about this game. Many normal enemies, or elites, see themselves upgraded to "Bosses" or "Abberations", former often found in dungeons, latter often found in the field or in secrets. Fighting a small alien crab for 10 minutes that occasionally leaves the arena to embed itself in a host while the arena is constantly filled with exploding projectiles, harmful aoes, and dozens of tiny crabs for the whole fight is not fun. Fighting a boss enemy that features no weakspot, meaning the only way to get good damage is through status (shockingly limited in this game, compared to the first.) or by using close-range weapons that sport raw damage over anything else isn't... great. Many, many times have I found myself fighting a boss where I sighed and said "Man, I wish I had a fucking shotgun right now." - I said about the old game "It's a very odd design choice to make single shot, high damage on headshot weapons completely invalid for a large portion of the game by making every enemy wear a helmet that reduces headshot damage by 50%. That, and enemies always running AT you, pushed me towards using shotguns which were already some of the best guns in this game."

Additionally, Yaesha has seen a huge downgrade over the first Remnant. Very sad to see we do not return to the tree top villages, instead we are restricted to the ground and forced to fight one of the more boring enemy types in this game: the fucking root. Annoying little buggers. 

With most of my complaints out the way, let me say nice things about this game. I like the areas a lot more, they also FEEL more varied than the first game. First game had the issue of "Grey, samey looking ruined city.", "orange, samey looking ruined civilisation", "Samey looking green swamp", "Oh, shit, this area is actually really pretty and sports a lot of colours.". 

This game at least sports a genuinely desolate feeling area, devoid of the people that once inhabited; outlived by their automatons and the strange 'zombie' like creatures that now inhabit the runes of their still functional automated faciltiies. That is N'erud.
Losomn is an interesting place; two worlds smashed together and thrown into utter chaos at the cause of it. Dran, the people of Losomn, turn against eachother and viciously attack Outsiders in presumed defence (much to their demise, I have a shotgun with two barrels.), as they find themselves often hunted by the Fae who inhabit the other world that collided into theirs. Losomn is a very dreary place, the kind of streets you'd expect to see in the impoverished districts of some shitty victorian place. Rancid sewers, filled with wooden structures that people inhabit, too. 
The Fae, conversely, live in the most grand and opulent halls. Very pretty place to look at, gilded and decorated. That conceals their more... dark nature, however. And their petty, internal struggles.

I mentioned Yaesha, earlier, an area from the first game. It's seem better times, the once vibrant life of the dense jungles have withered and greyed as Yaesha sees the Root sucking the life out of the world itself. Still, some of its old inhabitants, some familiar to the player, return, as does much of its previous story elements.

Also - this game is absolutely CHOCK full of really cool shit. Some places have multiple outcomes, some places have cool secrets, and by god there are a lot of secrets both clever and bullshit in many places. If you enjoy digging through every little nook and cranny, you might enjoy the optional stuff in this game.
This is what I meant by "The game is short, measured by the campaign, but it's replayability comes from the side.", this game is more or less meant to be replayed over and over. Start on normal, the FIRST difficulty, to get some gear together. Play it again on higher difficulties for more of a challenge. Play it on even HIGHER difficulties to put your builds to the test. Along the way, you'll probably find things you didn't find before, or maybe your main bosses will be different! New guns, new secondary fires, new modifiers, new melee weapons, new classes! Await you on future playthroughs.

... I feel like I need to say something about weapon balancing, but I can't comment on it too much given how little guns I've used. Nightfall, a gun with the ability to gain infinite ammo and higher rate of fire with healing on damage, is the gun I found on my first playthrough. And holy fucking shit is that gun horrifically powerful.

Eh, I'm not sure if this 'review' helps anyone, and I know a lot of it is negative - unfortunately my brain has a tendency to focus on the negatives more than the positives, but I wouldn't RECOMMEND this game if I thought it was shit. Genuinely I think this game is fun and I do recommend it. Fun alone, fun with pals.

Remnant 2 is an absolute triumph of the gaming world! As a dedicated gamer, I've had the pleasure of immersing myself in countless virtual realms, but Remnant 2 stands out as a masterpiece in every sense of the word. From jaw-dropping visuals to heart-pounding action, this sequel takes the already remarkable foundation of its predecessor and elevates it to an entirely new level.

Visually Stunning:
Remnant 2 boasts graphics that are nothing short of breathtaking. The level of detail in its environments, character models, and creatures is a testament to the extraordinary dedication and craftsmanship of the development team. Whether you're wandering through lush forests, navigating treacherous swamps, or battling otherworldly beasts, every moment in this game is a visual feast for the eyes. It's as if you've been transported into a mesmerizing, post-apocalyptic dreamscape.

Dynamic Gameplay:
One of the standout features of Remnant 2 is its exhilarating gameplay. The combat system has been fine-tuned to perfection, offering a delicate balance between skill, strategy, and sheer adrenaline. The variety of weapons, abilities, and character classes is staggering, giving players endless options to customize their approach to each challenge. Whether you prefer sniping from a distance, charging head-on into battle, or employing stealth tactics, Remnant 2 accommodates your playstyle.

Endless Exploration:
The game's world is an open-ended playground filled with secrets, hidden treasures, and mysteries to uncover. It's a testament to the developers' commitment to storytelling that every corner of this captivating realm holds a piece of the puzzle. As you delve deeper into the narrative, you'll find yourself irresistibly drawn into the rich lore of Remnant 2, making your adventure a truly immersive experience.

Co-op Brilliance:
While Remnant 2 excels as a single-player experience, its cooperative gameplay is where the game truly shines. Team up with friends or strangers and tackle the most challenging encounters as a unit. The cooperative mode is not just about multiplayer, but about forging bonds and strategizing with your companions, and it adds an entirely new layer of excitement to the game.

Innovative Storytelling:
Remnant 2's narrative is a mesmerizing tapestry of intrigue, filled with well-crafted characters and plot twists that will keep you guessing until the very end. The story is driven by your choices, and your decisions have meaningful consequences, adding layers of depth to the experience.

In Conclusion:
Remnant 2 is a tour de force in modern gaming. It combines the best elements of action, role-playing, and cooperative play, while offering an engrossing story and spectacular visuals. Whether you're a fan of the franchise or new to the Remnant world, this game is a must-play. It's not just a sequel. It's a triumph that will stand the test of time as a defining moment in the history of video games. Prepare to embark on an unforgettable journey that will leave you longing for more. Don't miss out on the sensation that is Remnant 2; it's a remarkable odyssey you won't to end.

Definitely going in my top 5 favorite games. I enjoyed Remnant 1 and Remnant 2 expanded on every good aspect. While you can play it by yourself, it is infinitely better with friends. I've never even played a souls-like game before Remnant 1, and I still haven't. These games are far enough removed from the genre that a newbie can get into them. Some people complain about the story or the writing or the humans or whatever, but honestly I didn't notice it. I play the game for the cool ass weapons and mods, for all the cool ass skills and perks from the many archetypes/classes, for the cool ass enemies and bosses, and all the fun you have finding different ways to obliterate them. They did a great job with the weapons and mods, making many more than were in the first game and including a few of the memorable ones too.

That being said, I did actually enjoy the story. It tied the flow of gameplay together and connected to the first game in a sensible way. 

My only gripe is the final boss, it really needs its difficulty lowered (again). Three power level 20 players struggling for hours to take it down? that was the intention? really? I suppose we could have looked up broken character/damage builds but that's not the way we like to do things.

My favorite part though, are all the secrets. The game is chock full of them around every corner. The best weapons and items are of course hidden this way, and figuring out the puzzles or cryptic clues is always very satisfying. 

Some people tout the random world generation but honestly that's one thing that makes this game very worth the price. Remnant II is an excellent sequel, that (besides some minor and one major issue) improves on everything the original did on such a scale that I highly encourage picking it up for anyone even slightly interested in soulslike/FromSoft games. Even if the gun-focus doesn't seem initially like your jam, there's much that's familiar and the rest is a nice change of pace from other soulslike-games. The randomization aspect of levels and loot are reason enough to provide gameplay for a good while.

In this review I'll go over some of the basics of what makes this game so good, while being vague so as to not spoil any of the experience. This review was written after the first DLC launched, and it will be updated if anything significant happens as the rest of them are released.

_____________________________________________________________________________________
First off: the Archetypes. The best thing I can say about the class system of this game is that I hope other games will steal the idea from this one as the way Remnant II does it is brilliant. Each class provides a selection of three active abilities (of which only one can be equipped and used at a time) and several passive perks, along with a powerful prime perk that provides a major changes to how you play the game. The medic class for instance can recover estus charges (your healing potion if you're new to the genre) by healing allies, allowing them to keep themselves and others alive longer. Their abilities heal in various ways, and can even revive fallen allies back to their feet.

Once you have the item for a class, you can swap them at any time, thus allowing you to freely switch up whenever you feel like. You can also have two classes equipped at a time, providing many unique combinations of abilities and passive perks. It's a blast to think of and play as different combinations, with many of them having synergies with each other. There's a good selection of classes to start from, and you can unlock more by finding obscure secrets as you play through the game. Some aren't all that powerful, but even the worst ones have their use cases.

_____________________________________________________________________________________
Secondly: the loot. You can equip up to four different rings, an amulet, a long gun, a hand gun, a melee weapon, an estus flask and your choice of four armor pieces. Weapon mods and mutators also affect how you play. Of these the ones that stand out the most are rings, amulets, weapon mods and weapons. 

Rings and amulets provide passive effects to your character, with some varying from boosting reload speed, damage, or just giving you a chance to not consume estus upon use. Amulets often have more powerful, unique effects, like releasing toxic gas upon switching weapons or causing reloads to only consume half the ammo you reload. Rings tend to be more minor, but still retain significant effect on your build. With more than 70 amulets and more than 150 rings in the game, there's plenty to choose from.

Weapons vary in effect from bows to rifles to shotguns, with most having their own unique niche that they fulfil. Basic long guns and hand guns can equip weapon mods, while boss weapons and unique weapons usually have their own custom weapon mod that cannot be removed. Weapon mods are like spells you can fire from your gun, with some just dealing damage, some firing healing energy while others create new weakspots on hit enemies. Most guns and weapon mods are useful or even build defining, with some falling short compared to what others provide. Again, there's plenty to choose from.

Melee weapons also exist, but they're much more simplified compared to common soulslike weapons. Each one has a combo string, a heavy attack and a backdash attack. Many of the unique weapons change how you use them, with some being throwable while others might leave a damage over time effect. Melee combat is a great alternative to using ammo on common enemies, but against many of the bosses it's either reckless or basically impossible.

Estus flasks, or Relics as the game calls them, come in many varieties. Some heal you instantly on use, others heal over time, some provide other bizzare ways to regain health. With 23 unique ones to choose from, this system is like if Salt and Sanctuary healing was overhauled and expanded on. Not all are made equal but the standing out ones can define how you build your character (not going to spoil them of course!)

Armor is divided into light, medium, heavy and ultra heavy varieties. It uses a similar weight based system common to soulslikes where wearing heavier armor grants you better defences at the cost of slower invincibility rolls and more stamina consumption, while lighter armor allows you to roll faster at the cost of less resistances. There's good variety in aesthetics, with some being fantasy-like, some being just utilitarian armor, while others are just something like a cowboy costume. Armors don't provide anything beyond defences which is a shame since they had abilities in the first game, but the other loot provides them in spades.

_____________________________________________________________________________________
Thirdly, boss fights. The main bosses are a treat; unique fights that have a twist that changes up the normal dodging and weaving of normal fights. They are challenging and satisfying to take down, and even the minibosses pose a unique threat. Two especially memorable fights that everyone will meet regardless of randomization are sure to stick out. Love 'em or hate 'em, they're excellent in providing a unique challenge you can't find elsewhere. The final boss will thoroughly test you and your build (don't be discouraged, keep up the fight skeleton!).

_____________________________________________________________________________________
Now you know the basics of what makes this game cool. All that's left is to mention the few issues the game has.

Major issue: Performance. With the release of the first DLC, performance has taken a dive. I don't mean that it's a constant low framerate mess, just that sometimes in some areas it dips below what it should be. My computer can run the game on ultra settings just fine, but in some of the DLC areas the framerate has been reduced to less than a single frame every 6 seconds while the computer screams in agony. These dips tend to pass after a while, but it has gotten me killed more than once. If you don't plan on getting the DLC this shouldn't affect you (atleast according to some user reports which might not be reliable.)

Minor gripes: 1) Economy. Scrap, the main resource of the game, is hard to come by. Environmental objects and common enemies drop pitiful amounts, while chests, bosses and minibosses provide slightly more. All in all, you can't afford much beyond upgrading your main weapon until you start grinding an area you've already explored once again. The highest yield of scrap can be gained from picking up either amulets/rings you already have, or tomes of traits after you've reached the trait cap. As a result, the consumable items like buff potions are almost a bad investment when compared to saving for buying permanent power in the form of new weapons, weapon mods and weapon upgrades. If it were up to me, I'd boost income by introducing items like the souls from Dark Souls or runes from Elden Ring, a pickup that grants you scrap upon consuming it. These could drop from any viable loot source, and if they'd boost the player income by say 20-30% you'd have enough to go around for buying consumables or trying new weapons from the shop or whatever else you might use it for.

2) Story. The main story is very barebones, it's just an excuse to go see cool worlds and shoot enemies for loot. No lore channel will spring forth to explain the main story, as there's not much to go on. The world building for each of the areas is interesting and fun to read

I played the first game, and it is safe to say, this game DID improve from it, but in certain aspects...

This game has much more customization, too much almost. You have 3 stat bonuses to add to your relic, different relics (estus), 50 different rings but 10 main artifacts to make your build, stat increasing traits after beating most bosses, and progressively more complex mod abilities for your guns. Not to mention, many of the classes are not available from the start and require you too go out of your way to find. Most are not easy either, the engineer for example (look up a guide, idk how you'd find it otherwise). And those classes near the end; they won't even be that leveled by the time you beat the game, so it feels like a waste. Otherwise, making my character stronger felt empowering. There is so much synergy between the class archetypes, as well as the rings, artifacts, mods, and even the armors.

There are so many bonus, side objectives that if you skip, it makes you feel like you skipped half the game. You can do nothing but focus the main objectives and miss out on whole levels with boss fights and unique NPCs with great storytelling and perks. The side areas felt like chores you had to complete, and you'd be surprised when you encountered these nuggets of a sparatic, but amazingly well made world. I wish there was less fluff of killing the same few enemies is the same copy pasted dungeons with the only incentive being a boss or item you'd get. It is quite repetitive, much like the first game.

Though very specific, I wished you'd get to really know the characters. You're thrown in like you had a whole game already with them. I could care less about the tutorial interactions with my 'best friend / you owe me one / overly chipper' side character. She gets degraded into a store by the way, no cool missions to make up for this. I was really happy when you met Ford; I really hoped to go on one of his adventures, but he and Clementine ditch you to do the same old slaughter dimensional entities for the mcguffin to progress. I did not care about the city in the beginning, their dialogue was easy to miss, and they had no plot relevance. They were an 'immersive' 'this is what you are fighting for' element, but I wish you could interact with the town, like a defense mission for it. But they remain cardboard cutouts for you to role-play with.

Talking about the end here:

There was a huge difficulty spike hear the end. The second to last boss had no story relevance, but was a warning for the final boss. It was HARD, and me and my friend had real builds to try to fight him. Even then, it took us about 10 tries, with each attempt being 10 or more minutes. It was not a satisfying end, and I feel like they made it that way on purpose. It is the most logical, setting up newgame+, but it deeply upset both me (remnant 1 player), and my friend (new player). I want a conclusion. Not a "play the game again, or get the DLC" let down. There is so much customization I could go back and do, but I feel exhausted, and unable to bring myself to go back into the dungeon crawler simulator. I feel bad for those NPC and boss moments that genuinely surprised us. If the game was cut down to half the areas in each world, but retained the side content, It would be much easier than having to wade though actual sewer levels to discover small, but touching stories in this shattered universe.

The ending to the first game was how I wished this game ended. The Wander is my cannon Anomaly.

But all in all, not the best, but also not the worst. Still recommend if you want a gun play souls-like.

Overall, a more than good game. Still feels like some things need to be addressed such as it disconnection me from friends sessions until I close and reopen the game about every boss fight.

                                                                                      𝐍𝐄𝐆𝐀𝐓𝐈𝐕𝐄
• Some enemies/bosses have some jank hitboxes where even avoiding it, you'll still be hit. Could be skill issue/desync.
• Perma-stun lock.
• Challenger archetype feels weak early on where you still only want to rely on guns since a lot of bosses seem to live in the sky or hug ceilings. Your prime perk DIE HARD is also a negative where if you get put down during a boss fight, to only get back up for that boss to 1 shot the zone you're in, sucks.
• Some bosses spamming ads where you fight them more than the boss and have to evade/run when a boss exposes a weak point.
• Party scale gets pretty difficult at 3 players where we would suggest doing it solo to make it easier. Funny how that works.
• NPCs and lore is pretty forgettable, but the interesting world more than makes up for it.

                                                                                          𝐏𝐎𝐒𝐈𝐓𝐈𝐕𝐄
• Adventure Mode is a nice addition to comb through multiple levels and grind through them.
• Armor is so much better where you don't have to worry about them messing up your build, while looking cool.
• Trait points are limited to 85 levels but are so much more impactful.
• Your character no longer feels sluggish.

Quick Summary:  2.5/10
1) Character customization (physical):  Dogsh*t.  Afterthought.  Doesn't matter.

Long summary:

Hey Gunfire Games.  It appears you're trying to make a game.  I presume you want it to be enjoyable.  Here are some tips from someone who actually plays video games that maybe you can use for Remnant 3:

Good idea:  Make boss kills feel rewarding by having them drop unique weapons and armor.
Bad idea:  Not having bosses drop anything useful at all, ever.

Good idea:  Character customization.
Bad idea:  Have everyone look identical, man or woman, if they are wearing the same armor.  Sh*t, just pay a nerd who mods for Skyrim to show you how.

Good idea:  Allow players to use an arsenal of different skills that they can combine to form their own unique playstyle.
Bad idea:  Only allow players 1 ability to use at a time.

Good idea:  When a player levels up, reward them with something.  Anything.  Seriously, literally anything is good.
Bad idea:  Making leveling up completely pointless by not rewarding the player with anything.

Good idea:  Have fun, enjoyable online Coop where the players have multiple ways to aid each other and work together.  (Left 4 Dead 2, Vermintide, etc)
Bad idea:  Have online Coop where you wait in spectator mode for 15 minutes while the active player finishes killing a boss, then they quit and you get disconnected.

Those are the big ones.  I figured you guys could use some advice from someone who actually plays video games.  If you want Remnant 3 to be an overwhelming success, feel free to follow my guide here.  Good luck in the future.

YOU DON'T NEED TO PLAY REMNANT 1, BUT IT IS HIGHLY RECOMMENDED FOR THE STORY. (I beat 1st one before playing)

   Quick Summary:
This game is a more story driven dark souls with FAR better multiplayer and easier difficulties available.

   This game... just wow: 
The trailer at the far right side of all the pictures on the steam store is one of the best god damn trailers I've ever seen. Still gives me the chills. Watch it.

   Extremely immersive world: 
Even just walking around is actually so fun just cause of the view and the scenery. It's so freakin' well done. 

   There are old friends and new ones too: 
Hearing people talk about their lives at home base is interesting and felt like a treat. Honestly felt like returning to a family after playing the first game.

   Gameplay felt really good: 
From improved basic movement (Identical except now you can jump off ledges [def better]) to the improved load-out system (yes, I was worried 2) I'm happy to say, "improved" is the right word. At first it felt weird not being able to upgrade armor, but after playing through the game on Veteran difficulty and completing a run, I looked back to realize the enemies that attack you scale in a way that "feels" like you ARE actually upgrading your armor as well as enemy difficulty increasing just the right amount. This as because all the foes you come across are actually relatively the same difficulty, but since learning how to beat them is the hard part it always feels like the right amount of challenge. 

   Difficulty recommendations:
-If you're new to the series or just want to enjoy the story, I recommend Survivor difficulty. ESPECIALLY IN MULTIPLAYER.
-Veteran is either for people that have FINISHED the first game, or experienced tactical shooters/Dark Souls players. If you start on Veteran difficulty and don't know what you're doing, you will get your ass handed to you ESPECIALLY IN MULTIPLAYER.
-Nightmare IS for players that have played through the game once before or people that hate their lives and want to hate them even more.
-Apocalypse isn't available until you beat the game once and is probably the game's final gambit at making you rage-quit.

   Dev's aren't greedy:
No battlepass, no cash grab dlc, you buy the game, and unlock the shit. For a decent price nowadays mind you. Just the way it should be. I bought Ultimate Edition cause I know I would buy all the dlc when it came out. There are a few bugs as of 7/28/2023 which are potentially anger inducing. However, Gunfire did say they were working on them. Yes, this is Epic Games, but they don't make you do stupid login shit like they usually do, so absolutely no complaints.
   
   Late game build potential:
This is insane. From a Thor, God of Thunder build that can throw an axe and summon lightning to smite hoards of enemies at a time, to custom builds like my life-stealing/teleporting/dual wealding assasin and toxic exterminator (where I turn being poisoned into a buff.) There are SOOOOO many posibilities that are fun to test and play as well as many meta boss builds to choose from online. Seems like every person has their own twist on how they like to play/build.

The downside is that since zones (and enemies) scale with your highest upgraded weapons, it can be expensive early on to try out different weapons unless you don't upgrade very much.

Enemy variety is also strong. Each biome has distinct enemies. The times are easy enough once you learn them, but feel unnecessarily punishing on initial encounters.

[h1]Fun buried under a buggy, inconsistent mess. Wait 1 year and see if patches/mods fix it.[/h1]

[h2]Gameplay: 3/5[/h2]

I like the basic gameplay loop, which is somewhere between ARPG, looter shooter, horde shooter (but with much less density), and Souls-like (but not really).

The puzzles and secrets add a good amount of replay value up to a point (it makes the first few replays [i]much[/i] better than replays/NG+ in other games). I suggest not spoiling too much for yourself, it's ok to experiment, try, and fail. Some things may take multiple tries or even multiple replays to figure out.

Onboarding is rough. The random world generation can be extremely unfun for new players. I chose the Handler (pet) class and got a world with only flying enemies that the pet couldn't hit.

The game itself isn't that complicated; the knowledge hurdle is mainly caused by poor UI and inconsistent descriptions. Say you find an item with Haste. The tooltip doesn't tell you what Haste does, that would be too easy. You have to equip the item, activate its conditions if any (e.g. use a skill or be under a certain % of HP), then open your character sheet and mouse over the tiny Haste buff in the top-left before it disappears. If there are 3 items with the exact same mechanic/conditions, you can expect them to be written in 3 different ways.

[h2]Story: 2/5[/h2]

There are 2 layers to the storytelling in Remnant: the lore and events of other worlds, as well as the overarching story of the protagonist and our world.

The other worlds are well-written, and explore a wide variety of sci-fi, fantasy, and horror tropes with some interesting spins. I love when games bring classic sci-fi ideas to a wider audience, even though some references are a bit too on-the-nose. I'd go as far as to say each of the worlds is rich enough to support their own games.

The main story however is Avengers wannabe, without the polish or pizzaz. Flat characters (including your own) make Marvel-style quips out of nowhere. Obvious parallels to various Marvel characters and plot points. [url=https://steamcommunity.com/app/1282100/discussions/0/4034725235919796743/2?ctp=2#c4034725235920481344](Spoiler warning) my comments about the ending[/url].

This is an actual quest entry (written in first person from your character's view): [spoiler]A giant ball of light told me to kill some powerful creatures to collect segments of the Index. Sounds important.[/spoiler] You're just too cool for the end of the world.

[h2]Performance: 2/5[/h2]

Far under expectations for the visual quality. I'm lucky it runs mostly smooth 60fps (with aggressive upscaling) on an RX 6600, though many others with better hardware have worse problems. I still get bizarre issues like an empty room with 1 light causing frame drops.

DLC and patches seem to introduce new issues for many users, so even if you're lucky now, it might not be the case tomorrow.

[h2]Bugs: -2147483648/5[/h2]

This game has everything: gameplay, graphics, sound, input, UI, networking bugs; random crashes; partial or complete loss of progress. Steam forums are filled with players reporting the same major bugs like crashes everyday, with no response.

Even their bugfix patches have bugs. The best way to discover new bugs is to check the patch notes; within 24 hours, someone will comment that the thing they fixed actually wasn't fixed or broke something else.

Bugs that give players an advantage are quickly fixed though!

Here's my own collection of bugs:

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3089569143

[h2]Other problems[/h2]

[h3]Inefficient patching due to large pack file size[/h3]

[url=https://steamcommunity.com/app/1282100/discussions/0/4039229863732541255/]See my FAQ on patching issues in Remnant II[/url]. Literally every patch, there are more complaints as people discover this issue.

[h3]DLC-only items dropping for non-DLC owners in non-DLC games[/h3]

[url=https://steamcommunity.com/app/1282100/discussions/0/4039229229050419198/]They did this in Remnant 1, then walked it back as a "bug". They've done it again in Remnant 2.[/url]

[h3]Anti-fun sound design[/h3]

There are various enemy types that hide in the environment. Quite a lot of rooms are obviously designed for ambushes. But, your character will randomly shout combat lines ("Here they come!") [i]before[/i] the enemies aggro or are visible, completely spoiling the ambush.

Similarly, one of the main combat mechanics is the dynamic elite spawns, which are supposed to add randomness to gameplay instead of fixed enemy placements. However, the sound design directly contradicts that by having the same non-directional alert sound for every elite spawn, which trains you to simply press your buttons when you hear the sound. You don't react to specific enemy sounds. You can't hear an elite patrolling the next room to prepare, because it doesn't exist until it "dynamically" spawns.

It's as if Bloodborne and Destiny 2 had a baby, but that baby came out smelling like sulfur with two middle fingers extended. This game is sort-of perfect. While it could explain things a bit better to beginners, the gameplay is sold and entrancing. You will run, you will shoot, you will loot and you will like it.

Graphically, "Remnant 2" is a feast for the eyes. The environments are beautifully crafted, with breathtaking landscapes that range from post-apocalyptic urban settings to otherworldly realms. The level of detail in character design and animation is equally impressive, adding a layer of realism that enhances the overall immersion. The lighting effects are particularly noteworthy, creating atmospheres that range from eerie darkness to vibrant explosions of color.

The narrative of "Remnant 2" is a triumph, seamlessly weaving a compelling storyline with rich character development. The world-building is meticulous, creating a universe that feels both expansive and interconnected. The lore is deep and rewarding for those who seek to delve into it, but the game also manages to maintain accessibility for players who prefer a more straightforward experience.

One of the standout features of "Remnant 2" is its innovative gameplay mechanics. The combat system is refined and satisfying, offering a perfect balance of challenge and reward. The introduction of new weapons, abilities, and enemy types keeps the gameplay fresh and exciting, ensuring that players are constantly adapting to new challenges. The inclusion of a robust multiplayer mode enhances the experience, allowing players to team up for cooperative missions or engage in intense player-versus-player battles.

The game's soundtrack is a true auditory delight, complementing the on-screen action with a dynamic score that enhances the emotional impact of key moments. From epic orchestral pieces during intense battles to subtle ambient tracks that heighten exploration, the music of "Remnant 2" is a crucial component of its overall success.

In conclusion, "Remnant 2" is a triumph in the gaming industry. It not only lives up to the expectations set by its predecessor but surpasses them in every aspect. Whether you're a fan of action RPGs, immersive storytelling, or simply enjoy getting lost in visually stunning worlds, "Remnant 2" is a must-play that cements its place among the best games of its generation.

It's probably okay for me to spoil a bit, since there is no breath-taking, deep story to begin with. 

[h2]The Full Main Story of Remnant 2 (Abridged)[/h2]
-> After a tutorial, you reach "Ward 13", the base of your operations in this game. 
-> You gear up and follow an old man (Ford) to an abandoned place. 
-> You and old man find a Large Floating Red Rock.
-> Old man touches rock and gets teleported away 
-> Woman (Clementine) appears out of nowhere
-> She gets dragged/kidnapped into rock and so you follow her in. 
-> Your goal for the main story is to find these two [b][Initial Goal][/b]
-> After exploring one world, you get taken to a place called "Labyrinth" 
-> You meet Woman and big eyeball [strike]god[/strike] who says a lot of things, just to say so little.
-> Eyeball talks like a Chat BOT that was asked to talk using only complicated words
-> Eyeball is really bad at explaining and talks a lot for a few minutes 
-> Basically, eyeball wants a companion because they're overworked. 
-> Woman was kidnapped earlier to become companion for big eyeball.
-> Woman's just chilling with big eyeball now.  
-> [strike] Who's Ford again? Nevermind, let's just call it a day since we found the woman [/strike]
-> Explore two more worlds to get shiny shards.
-> Shiny shards turn into portal to go to Earth 2.0, which is overtaken by root monsters. 
-> Apparently root monsters are a threat to other worlds so you must destroy them!!
-> Meet up with Woman and Big Eyeball at a big tree
-> Big Eyeball is now a humanoid with a quirky personality
-> There is big barrier blocking access to big tree with final boss in it
-> Woman yells and loses her special powers to remove barrier
-> You go in and kill final boss
-> Final boss can't die
-> Only way to deal with the boss is to factory reset the entire universe. 
-> Eyeball starts whining and can't bring themselves to do it.
-> Clementine takes factory reset button out of eyeball man's hands
-> (Best scene in the game), eyeball man yells "CLEMENTINEEEEE" 
-> Clementine presses factory reset button instead
-> World resets.
-> Credits Roll
 
{THE END}

[h3]Things I'm genuinely sad about the story [/h3]
- Character Development of the Eyeball man happens off screen 
(From ChatGBT to an awkward humanoid being with a quirky personality)
- Ford's just gone from the Main story. You won't be seeing him again. 
- Game treats it like there's countless worlds out there, but you only go to 5 in total.
- Each world has its own story, but most don't even connect with the main story line. 
- The story definitely had potential :(

I love this game. I loved the first one it was highly underrated. And the second improved upon it in every way. If you haven't played the first its lovingly called souls-like with guns... or a looter shooter.... mix in some third person adventure game and random generation? 

Things that are improved/great:
- Graphics/details in all of the worlds you travel to are so awesome and very distinct to almost feel like different games
- Extremely in depth RPG mechanics with an archetype to choose and many items/mods/abilities to equip so you can truly create a unique and powerful build thats personal to you. There are infinite combinations that are viable, seemingly, a huge step up from the first game. 
- There is the ability to change archetypes (classes) or try out a multiclass combination, without creating a new character, you can simply switch on your same character. This is much improved from the first game and lets you experiment with things more readily. 
- Fun and addicting gameplay. A few things were added from the first such as an ability to jump over gaps which is nice
- The random generation seems to have improved to provide even more options for each world so your playthroughs can have completely different stories. 
- Boss fights have been significantly improved. There are some amazing ones and they've removed the over-reliance on adds which were one of the main complaints of the first game. 
- Ward 13 hub world is easier to navigate than the first game. 
- There is so much loot to collect - but every item you collect has meaning and its own unique usage. There is none of this nonsense i hate in other games where you've got this weapon but now its  134 instead of 78. Each item has a unique usage. 
- Even more secrets than the first game, some so hidden. 
- Good story. Though the main plot is somewhat straightforward but decent (saving the multiverse). however the sub plots of each biome are fascinating, and the lore is rich.
- Fun co-op. The uniqueness of everyone's builds can lead to awesome co-op fun. You and your buddy's game playthroughs will likely have different dungeons, plots, and stories than your campaign. 

Edit: The one negative I really find to this game is the final boss. It's really not enjoyable and the difficulty spike does not match the rest of the game. The first games final boss was difficult but there was a strategy to learn and it wasn't the worst. This one is the worst. There's an area that's just so visually challenging to understand what's going on in this boss that I just could not understand. I had to get on discord to find a team to get me through this boss. I just did not like it. The other bosses in the game were mostly great and better than the first game.

Remnant 2 is an absolutely stellar game and deserves large amounts of praise. It's engaging, rewarding, and offers so much gameplay and lore behind each of the worlds you will encounter.

Performance: It runs well, but I also have a 4000 series card and new PC. Running on ultra using DLSS quality and the game feels great running at 110-144 fps at all times. No real FPS drops, no screen tearing, no crashes at all. 

Visual/Level Design: The game is stunningly beautiful, especially in the way that colors contrast and the world design incorporates the visuals of each of the worlds is masterful. The level design is amazing. Puzzles are thoughtful, difficult but rewarding. Loot actually matters and going off the beaten path will net you amazing rewards. Rerolling each world gives you a completely different run from your last. The story in each world can go a variety of ways and there are up to 4 different alternate deaths for some bosses, each giving a different set of items/rewards.

Gameplay: There are so many ways you can build your character. Archtypes are plentiful, there are an insane amounts of items like rings, amulets, and guns at your disposal. Gunfire games seems hellbent to making sure every item is viable. There is no real meta as you can easily use anything in the highest difficulties.

Story: The main story is okay at best, the real lore comes from each of the worlds in Remnant 2. Each of them has multiple timelines that you are plopped into with any reroll of your campaign or adventure mode. You can spend hours within each world feeling like a third party observer of the plights of each of the world's main characters and suddenly get thrust into the middle of their struggles. The story behind each world is insanely rich, and getting transported into the next world is jarring in a good way.

Remnant 2 is my choice for GOTY 2023. Tons of replayability, amazing level design, impeccable gameplay and lore.

A very smooth, enjoyable game with very distinctive visual style and audio design. 
Overall a very polished game out of the box.. if it wasn't such an intentional grindfest. 
If there was an award for 'best adopter of ingame grinding mechanics' this game would be the top contender for 2023. 
That said, this is still a better collectathon than Assassin's Creed games. 

The game is full of unnecessary mechanics that force you to replay the game multiple times in order for you to just have a CHANCE at obtaining certain items. There are also MULTIPLE in-game mechanics that are hardcapped by the passing of real-world time to force you to play a lot, and play often. 

And then imagine a slightly buggy, unoptimized game, and the first patch that hits you is one that removes an XP farm and balances (i.e. nerfs) weapons/abilities.. in a PvE game. 

This is my personal opinion but the developers absolutely do NOT respect your time and this is made clear to me by how they go out of their way to inflate players' playtime hours by prioritizing the elimination of "farm shortcuts" and "OP builds" (or "exploits") ahead of even basic bugfixes - those who have followed and played the game since launch would be well aware of this. 

The game is also not at all optimized for older systems and is constantly and consistently CPU heavy, so forget about getting this for the Steam Deck or similar. 
DLSS/FSR/XeSS is also required to comfortably run this, even on high end GPUs (RTX 3080/4080). 

TLDR; only buy if you have lots of time to kill and do not mind grindy mechanics - this IS a cool action game with lots of cool build synergies and very little statfa-.. stat minmaxing involved, relative to games like Nioh (no rarity mechanics or stat RNG - all players, items, weapons, abilities have the same stats).

It's Dark Souls with Guns and Friends! But for real it's pretty fun, since there is no block or riposte system the game is balanced around you switching between melee and shooting. You can just shoot if you want, or just melee but the game will be much harder. I can see the shooting is meant more as a defensive system in place of blocking.

The locations are otherworldly and gorgeous, and this game is MEANT to be played with someone though it does seem like you can play it on solo. This game is almost meant to be played multiple times, not just beat once. The main gameplay loop is about completing campaign runs, then "re-rolling the campaign" with your same character, stats, build, etc and it has a chance of completely changing each world. There could be secret areas unlocked, altogether new areas, new bosses, weapons, drops, etc. The game has 4 difficulties, Survivor, Veteran, Nightmare, and the unlocked Apocalypse. Enemies on each higher difficulty don't seem to have a huge number bloat for health, especially since you won't do the hardest difficulties until you have a better build. I do not recommend you play on Survivor though unless you want a more casual experience.

Survivor is the games easiest difficulty and considered "normal" while Veteran is considered the way the game is meant to be play. Veteran with another friend is still a bit easier than Dark Souls. Also this game's multiplayer is what it was built around. It is not like a soulsborne game where you just summon a  friend who can't do a whole lot in your world. Players share loot, can interact with anything they want, and some encounters even feel balanced around 2+ people.

The dodge mechanic isn't the best but it's definitely not the worst. You still have I-Frames, fast rolling, fat rolling, etc. There is poise, stagger, and all the regular souls mechanics in here. Just with guns and grenades as well as melee weapons. Also there is no "real" magic. Each of your weapons has a mod slot. Mods are crafted and sometimes looted items that you equip to your weapons that change the look of the weapon and add a special skill tied to that weapon. They are essentially the skills and spells of the game. Along with that each weapon can equip a "mutator" which can change your build variability immensely. Each class has 3 "ultimates" to pick from, from healing, buffing, tanking, damage, etc. Each character you make also can have two classes or "archetypes".

Any who bosses are fun and unique, and the game likes to spawn mini-bosses and mini-boss versions of stronger mobs which constantly keeps you on your toes. Fun game and I do recommend it is much more unique and better of the souls-like games.

Remnant 2 is a thrilling rollercoaster of a game that caters to both the solo adventurer and the cooperative duo seeking a challenge. The difficulty level is set just right, providing a satisfying test of skill without veering into frustration. The bosses are the true stars of the show, each a unique puzzle to solve with attacks that keep you on your toes. Learning their patterns is a journey in itself, and the satisfaction of overcoming these formidable foes is unparalleled.

Exploration is a breeze in Remnant 2, with a world that begs to be discovered. Unraveling its secrets and stumbling upon hidden treasures adds an extra layer of excitement to the gameplay. Whether you're flying solo or teaming up with a friend, the experience remains engaging and enjoyable. Co-op play, in particular, enhances the fun as you strategize and coordinate with your partner to conquer the challenges that lie ahead.

The music deserves a standing ovation, seamlessly weaving into the gameplay to intensify the atmosphere. It enhances the overall experience, making each encounter feel epic and every victory well-earned. The soundtrack is a true companion on this perilous journey, guiding you through moments of tension and triumph.

Remnant 2 masterfully blends elements of a looter shooter and a Souls game. The satisfaction of acquiring new gear and weapons is addictive, and the combat mechanics draw inspiration from the Souls series, providing a strategic and methodical approach to battles. This amalgamation of genres creates a unique and captivating gaming experience that keeps you coming back for more.

In conclusion, Remnant 2 is a must-play for those seeking a challenging yet rewarding gaming experience. With its gripping bosses, seamless co-op play, and a soundtrack that elevates the intensity, it stands as a shining example of how to blend genres successfully. Prepare for an adventure that will test your skills, captivate your senses, and leave you craving more.

You know, I had to think long and hard about this one. Remnant 2 is...interesting, if nothing else. It's been called "Dark Souls with guns" and I would say that's a pretty apt descriptor. However, ultimately, after 20 hours of play, you kinda learn why Dark Souls with guns is not really the best thing. For most guns I've encountered, reload times feel like an absolute eternity. Enemies close distance and engage with you very quickly, and while you can usually dispatch them or otherwise deal with them, constantly having to find breathing room for reloading is just...not fun. If you play Remnant 2, I would recommend playing a class which operates at a great distance, using guns which have the lowest possible reload time, and/or taking traits and items which decrease reload time.

I wanted to get that out of the way first because that's the biggest flaw this game has in terms of gameplay. But all that aside, there's just something about Remnant 2 which feels oddly linear and kind of...I don't know...sparse? It feels a bit "on rails", and I think the devs try to account for this by putting a lot of secret things in the game, so it *feels* more content-heavy than it actually is. Also, the unlockables are often very obscure, and while some people might enjoy the "looking stuff up online" thing when it comes to games, I've never been a huge fan. The game design is also a bit muddled in terms of this, too. Like I was trying to find the Atom Splitter melee weapon, and I must have spent 3-4 hours watching videos, reading articles, and going over certain maps several times trying to find this one particular telltale sign on the minimap to show that I could get the item. It turns out, after all of that effort, I simply got unlucky with my world generation and I was not going to be able to get the item. I can *sort of* understand why they designed the game this way; it ensures that you can't get every item on the first playthrough, but I would like to have the opportunity to do that at some point and without having to delve into articles and youtube videos in order to do so. So that's another frustrating aspect of Remnant 2.

Another frustrating thing is that enemy health seems a bit disjointed. In some places, the enemies will have a lot of health and you're dumping mag after mag into these enemies to progress through the level and it just kinda gets tiresome. At this point I've spent many resources to upgrade my weapons, but I'm still spending minutes taking down "alpha" enemies. Each level will typically have a mixture of mooks which die quickly (but are annoying and tend to close distance and harass you), and more powerful enemies which act as "captains". It's decent in theory, but as I say it becomes sort of laborious swatting away the mooks and trying to reload before you have to dodge to avoid some attack, sometimes you groan and just switch to your secondary and burn through your ammo to get some breathing room, then get to work on the captains...sometimes it just feels more like work than play.

The boss fights are pretty good, I must say. They're designed well. I usually had to burn most of my heals in order to beat a boss and oftentimes I would barely win, so that's cool.

I think a lot of these problems can be solved by playing with other people, and in fact it almost trivializes the experience of making your way through the level, so there's always that option when you're feeling frustrated. The bosses are balanced based on how many players are in a session, but I don't know if this also applies to normal enemies, so yeah, it'll typically trivialize getting to the boss (or maybe I just had players join my game who are well-equipped?).

There's a story, but I mostly don't care about it. The characters seem okay, but sometimes the writing comes off as trying too hard, and the characters strike me as a diversity checklist and they have these annoying personality types that you get in modern games - check out this Youtube vid called "Millenial Writing" for a good explanation of what I mean. I actually hated the first character you encounter in this game so much that I kept waiting for her to die, and when it seemed like she might die I was like, "Finally!". But then she doesn't die and I was actually disappointed. The good news is you can mostly ignore all the characters once the game really starts.

There's a lot of rings and amulets and such, which is good. There's also a decent selection of weapons, but as I mentioned it's often difficult to find out how to get them, and it's impossible to know if you even can without running all over the place and seeing if you lucked out on your world generation. But the weapons that I've encountered are all pretty cool and well-made.

So yeah, ultimately, this review is more like a "meh". It's too bad the game is so often unbalanced in terms of fun and frustration. They really did aim high with this one and I think they did pretty good, it's just...there are better Soulslike experiences out there, in my opinion.

A game worth picking up on sale, but absolutely not something I would be happy about paying full price for.

Story/Characters/Setting: Pretty cheesy and generic story. Characters are very bland and uninspiring and VERY cheesy. I hate the hand-holding your character does and the random cheesy pep talks that happen after fights. "Wooo! Heh.. yeah! Yeah...." or "Yeah, you ain't so tough now huh! Haha, wheww... whew!" The other voice acting is super corny too, like the girl who makes mods for you. I also find it funny that in an apocalyptic world, you just happen to encounter the last bastion of humanity and everyone's like, "Howdy, friend! Come on in!" 

The world building is amazing though and I find that the NPCs you encounter in different worlds and the little bits of lore you discover along the way to be far more impactful and interesting.

Gear/loot: I have a TON of amulets and rings, but hardly any weapons or armor to create a build surrounding these accessories. I've been using the same shotgun when I chose my first archetype and the first SMG I found in the beginning in a secret area. I just keep upgrading them, but it does nothing to make the game more fun/interesting. Equipping mutations and mods spices it up a bit, but after testing it out on a couple enemies a few times, it gets old quick.

Misc: The animations for this game are very long and drawn-out, and for what? In The Forgotten Prison, I have to wait in between doors... and it takes FOREVER. I understand that sometimes this is just a hidden loading screen, but what's the point when you enter the dungeon and the whole place is already loaded anyway?

Another example is when you attempt to open a locked door, your character pounds on the door... and you can't just roll out of it... Why? Another example (which is obv intentional) is walking around while you're in the middle of healing. Personally, I find it really grating.

Yet another example is when you've been struck hard enough to where your character needs to animate to get up. During this whole process, you continue to get pummeled by enemies. And it takes FOREVER to recover during this animation. The only option is to sit back and watch your character face tank hits until you can FINALLY get up. By that time you're pretty much dead, but if you're lucky enough to recover, don't worry! You still have to walk around nice and slow to heal.

This last example is when you approach a new world stone/checkpoint. You have to wait for it to light up and do its little song-and-dance and then you can finally interact with it. Just really small minor details like this that add up and bring down the experience.


Final thoughts: This game is a solid 3/5 and I'll continue playing it and can see myself completing it, but there are more times where it feels like a slog rather than an enjoyable experience. Overall, the game feels pretty empty and boring. Definitely not worth paying full price for.

As someone who played Remnant: From the Ashes, I came to this game with very high expectations, and it did not disappoint. The same great 3rd-person shooter, with that much more good stuff. Callbacks to the previous game are awesome, especially the way things played out during the timeskip. All the old characters are back and just as I remember, with a few easter eggs that make me like some of them that much more.
The infinite out-of-combat stamina is so much better when it comes exploration and back-tracking. Classes having defined abilities means you can more easily customize your play style and still use weapons with locked mods, and a greater variety in classes means more play styles to work with (and picking a class at the start actually matters). Having powers tied to classes and not armor sets means that armor is easier to manage as well (even if I miss the ritualist skin for the cultist set). Variety in relics was also fun, even if the Dragonheart is still one of the better ones for most circumstances (imo). Mutators are a fantastic addition to the game, and give that much more variety for what you're able to do with your kit; it also gives me an incentive to use my melee weapons, whereas before that was more a matter of pure resource conservation. Even if I'm a little pissed that they messed with some of the classic weapons from the old game, *cough cough* Spitfire and Fusion Rifle (or Hellfire and Savior, as they're now called) *cough cough* the variety of new weapons, accessories, armors, and mods are fantastic for customizing and tailoring builds.
Coming from FtA, it was disappointing to not have Rhom, Corsus, or Reisum, and it was heartbreaking to see Yaesha in such disarray (and it was infuriating to deal with the centipede-snake mobs again, who now shoot projectiles... I actually said 'are you f-ing kidding me' when I saw them for the first time), but I don't think what we got was any less than amazing. The visuals are stunning; The decayed, crumbling and often grotesque N'erud, the fascinating contradiction of the grand, sprawling, gothic-esk fae halls and the crude, run-down, Industrial Revolution-Era England inspired, Dran cities in Losomn, a ramshackle and chaotic take on the now-collapsing Labyrinth and... well, I don't wanna throw spoilers out there, but it's grand, dark, oddly vibrant and honestly not how I expected the game to end. The procedural generated map and all the secret locations of gear and class engrams means it's got replay value; there are a pair of locations I've never encountered in all my hours of playing and replaying.
They also fixed both the major issues I had with FtA's gameplay. First was the issue of not locking the mouse to the center of the screen, so no more non-responsiveness from clicking or keys, or starting to melee at nothing, when I mean to be shooting. The other was that hardcore mode considered game crashes as "invalid exits," which doesn't seem to be a problem here. It does have some issues with crashing when trying to engage in multiplayer, but so far it's a very rare problem for me and my friends, and the game files getting corrupted during a crash (something I've read about in other negative reviews for this game) has never happened to me.
Highly recommend playing this game, I had a grand time and look forward to playing more. And to checking out the DLCs they come out with.

The world level makes it difficult to understand why you should bother leveling in the first place, although the amount I "just so happened" to level while running from place to place seemed fine enough.

The boss design is immaculate though, with exceptions being the [spoiler]venom fight[/spoiler] (one of the only fights that managed to make my gpu chug, seriously there's too much rendering going on in this fight/arena, especially with the smoke particles) and essentially any fight that forced you to fight extensive amounts of fodder like [spoiler]legion or astropath[/spoiler]. Seriously, in single player the ammo should be dropped like it was in the [spoiler]final boss fight[/spoiler] , even in coop the fights with extensive fodder seemed to go way out of hand.

I didn't really care too much about the story, but it was pretty gripping even though I was really just here for the game-play, and it was pretty funny to see how idiotic the humans in the game seem to be compared to just about every single non-human character. I personally recommend the game though, nearly every fight was extremely fresh and had its very own rhythm of dodging (although... I wouldn't hate a parry system). The relief of defeating some of the most challenging foes definitely makes the souls-like tag fit.

TLDR: if you don't mind googling keywords, getting distracted by fodder and enjoy the idea of destiny mixed with souls, you'll have fun, hell, I did mind those things and still had fun. 8/10.

Edit:
Devs - Your RNG system is horrendous and you need to rethink it. It does not respect the time of your players and biggest supporters. We don't have an endless amount of time to game, since 99% of us have lives (possibly work, kids, loved ones, other hobbies, other games, need to sleep, etc...). This is coming from someone who put over 2k hrs into Destiny 2, but lets face it, this game doesn't have a fraction of the content Destiny 2 has.

Also - the Awakened King is not a new biome. You just added some new enemies to an existing biome and I'm assuming the same will happen for the next 2 dlcs. Very disappointed.

Players - The RNG is a nightmare. If you look up a build, good luck getting all the items some streamer has. I download a third party tool that just lets you know what your world looks like (what bosses, dungeons, items, events, etc.. have been populated in your worlds). This may sound like cheating, but you have no clue what your world rolled with and if you are looking for a specific item or event, you won't know until you get that far in the campaign and that might be 2, 5, 10, 15hrs later only to find out it's not there. Or even worse, you may need 2 specific things in a campaign and without this tool, you have no way of knowing without constantly rerolling your campaign just in hopes the first world rolls correctly only to speed run and/or use glitches to get to the second biome asap (still a couple hours most likely) only to find out it didn't roll the way you need it to. So I used this tool and saw that an event I had been hunting was on my adventure mode, so I got excited. I get to that event after searching for hours (I missed a crawl space and kept walking all over the map thinking I missed something somewhere else and to boot it's the ugliest biome in the game and just boring). I get there and the computer in the room scans me but won't open the door. So I know I need a piece of gear. I google what is needed and it says I need a specific helm from a rare enemy that may or may not even spawn for me in this biome. Just wonderful, rng behind rng yet again. I had 2 random players with me and as I walked away, they kept telling me to stand in a spot. I was getting annoyed and started to walk away again and just then the door suddenly opened. So I thought maybe they knew of a glitch to force it open. I walk in the room and literally nothing is in there. So either the items glitched out with the glitch, they didn't load into the world properly, not using the actual helm made them despawn, etc.... So now I have no clue if I can still get that ring in this run or not. This was the last straw after 45hrs of gameplay and things like this happening multiple times. 


Overall, the game was fun until it wasn't. I highly suggest picking it up on sale (possibly waiting for a deep sale) as it is fun for your first play through or 2. But don't get your hopes up on running the game on the higher difficulties unless you are willing to spend 100-200 hrs grinding for gear or picking up the world viewer app I did and still praying to rng gods. I luckily got this on the Black Friday sale, so I feel like I got my money's worth and will do the same for their next game. 



Original:
For the record, I hate the Steam rating system. This game is so hard to recommend or not recommend. I'm loving it, but also beyond frustrated with the design. 

Pros:
- Probably my favorite souls like game. They clearly did their own thing based on the souls formula and they knocked this part of the game out of the park.
- Weapons are fun and feel impactful.
- Graphics aren't the best, but more than good enough.
- Pick ups in coop are for everyone. This ROCKS!!!! Finally a dev that gets it. We don't like watching someone else get gear while we don't because maybe we died during a boss fight. Or accidentally rolled off a ledge. Etc....
- THE COMMUNITY IS AMAZING!!! Might be the best community so far. Clearly end game players who beat apocalypse difficulty have helped me and others out countless times. Showing up secrets, helping with puzzles and bosses. If it wasn't for the community being this awesome, I would have put this game down.


Neutral:
- Boss fights. Some are clearly designed with coop in mind and feel punishing as a solo player. Some I have pushed through and others I just waited for help. I wish the fight would scale better for solo players.


Cons:
- Controls can feel clunky, but not horrible. I had to remap melee, because it was throwing me off (if you aren't aiming down sights, you will melee strike by default. Then switching back to your gun takes time, so this alone can get you killed.). But after remapping, this was no longer and issue for me, but still the controls can feel clunky.
- RNG. OMG this is RNG from hell. This is the hate part for me. I get they want to promote replayability, but when you mess up a puzzle, that you had no clue was even a puzzle or that it existed because you moved on in the story, then pray to RNG gods that you find a multiplayer game that is in that area, the puzzle exists in their world, they haven't solved yet and they want to solve it. Some items are hidden behind how your campaign rolled, which is a horrible idea. With this, even coop won't help unless you intend on playing with someone who got that perfect campaign roll, which could be for hours on end and you won't even know until hours into their campaign. Example, one relic requires 2 biomes to roll with very specific criteria, but you need to finish the first biome to access the 2nd and 3rd biomes, and then you have to progress that 2nd one far enough in to even know if the area/dungeon you need is there. This just feels horrible if you get that combination but had no clue the item exists. Then only to realize that you finished a biome you can no longer access but had the perfect roll. Now you have to keep trying??? They need to rethink this level of RNG. I'm fine with weapons being hidden behind the most difficult content with guaranteed drops, but not just praying for rng.

All that said, I'm still loving the game, but there are plenty of times I'm just beyond frustrated seeing I missed something good because I didn't research the hell out of every item, puzzle, dungeon, biome, etc... before even starting it. I stopped playing Baldur's Gate 3 because I didn't want to look everything up so I wouldn't feel like I'm missing out since playing games isn't a full time job for me. This is very close to that and I wish they would change this.

[h1]First things first:[/h1]

[b]THIS IS A DAMN FINE GAME![/b]

Ok, so... what is it you're looking for? Cause here you get A LOT of different, well rounded specs out of a single game.
You get:

- A damn fine [b]Single-Player Campaign[/b].
- A very well polished [b]Co-op experience[/b].
- A scratch on your [b]SOULS-like[/b] itch.
- Random generated worlds with metroidvania-like possibilities.
- Into Roguelikes? Once you get the hang of the game you can go Hardcore mode!
- [b]Metaprogression[/b] (through gear and character leveling and traits).
- Immense [b]replayability[/b] potencial due to the World building mechanics (different sorylines and/or events in each run).
- A lot of Build possibilities due to the [b]characer Multi-class system[/b]!
- [b]Secrets[/b]. A lot of them.
- Simple yet welcoming puzzle solving for a change (they´re mainly not necessary for story progression. For those who don't like them).

[h3]Gameplay:[/h3]

Remnant 2 is a fairly fast paced, though not frenzied, action game. The movements are well measured and the gunplay is very smooth and straight forward. Though I struggled a bit to reconcile the "mouse 1" clicks for melee and the combo "m2+m1" to aim and shoot. It's not a bad system. Just one I was not used to.

Traversing biomes feels ok, more so because of the revamped stamina system (only used when in combat), though sometimes a bit janky. The auto-jump function is sometimes unreliable in the sense that when you land (depending on the map and ledges layout) you may struggle to keep your char from falling into the abiss! Most of the time you falling is your own fault, though !!

[h3]Graphics:[/h3]

Well, images speak for themselves. But, I found it very pleasing! It is a beautiful game. And up-to-date with the modern standards.

[b]Sound:[/b]

Sound is a very important part of Remnant 2, for without it you would miss dodge queues most of he time. So, not only it is important as it's also a tip here for you people going into it: [b]pay attention to the sound queues !!!!!![/b]

As for the soundtrack... I couldn't tell. I find music in games mostly distracting so I usually turn it off or leave it really low.

[h3]Story and Lore:[/h3]

Remnant 2 is a fallow up from Remnant from the Ashes story (which I didn't play). Still, from what I gathered and experienced it's very well written. Characers have personalities and voices are well dubbed. Extra Lore are there in form of dialogues and letters and books scattered throughout the worlds. Each world have many substories and one can only experience them all by playing the campaign (or advenure mode) multiple times, for the world building will only spawn a fracion of the huge assorment of tiles for each Biome. 
I ended my first run in about 40 hours. I took my time. You can do it faster, or slower... depending on your playstyle.

[hr][/hr]

All in all, I bought it very reluctantly for it's high price but I think it was (and is) worth the trouble. More so if you have friends to play with. And, if you don´t and still want to run it co-op, you can always join Remnant's Discord Channel and get into a lobby there.

Good things about this game:
1) Exceptional gun play. There's a good variety of weapons and they all feel good to use. The upgrade system really locks you into one weapon for the first chunk of the game, but after you play a bit resources will accumulate and you can start to try other things. Good times. 
2) Cool bosses. They are difficult, but they are for the most part fair (except for maybe the bizarre last boss). It felt great to be facing off against a major boss and to have my two lame allies drop before the guy lost a sliver of health and then go on to beat him using the power of my expertly timed dodge rolls. 
3) The first area of the game is based on Bloodborne and is very cool. If the whole game were at its level, this would be an all-time classic. 

Bad things about the game:
1) After the Bloodborne area, the maps are kind of shit. There's a swamp that's mediocre, a space station that sucked and some kind of post apocalyptic place that was underwhelming. Hordes of dudes come at you for ill defined reasons and I had no idea what any of their problems were. 
2) I don't know why they keep putting in puzzles and 'find the key' shit in this game. It's a multiplayer coop shooter. Who wants to stop their multiplayer shooting battles to do a puzzle? Answer: No one. 
3) There is a class whose primary function is having a dog. 

Overall rating: 7.29/11. Better than the first one, but not by much.

"Remnant 2," the eagerly awaited sequel to the hit game "Remnant: From the Ashes," cranks up the action and hilarity to a new level. Imagine a world where interdimensional travel is as common as ordering a pizza, but instead of pepperoni, you get a horde of nightmare creatures! Our heroes, armed with weapons that look like they were made by a steampunk enthusiast with a penchant for monster movies, travel through these bizarre worlds. Think of it as a cosmic road trip, but instead of stopping for souvenirs, you're collecting strange artifacts and blasting every monstrosity in sight.

The game's monsters seem like they've been plucked from a fantasy enthusiast's fever dream. The bosses? Oh, they're like the big, bad bullies of the monster world, but with more tentacles.

Co-op gameplay brings a whole new level of chaos. Imagine trying to coordinate a strategic plan with your friend who can't stop laughing at a monster that looks like it ate too much spicy food. And the loot system? It's like the game's way of saying, "Sorry for the nightmares, here's a cool hat."

In short, "Remnant 2" is a whirlwind of bullet-flying, monster-slaying madness that feels like a wild, interdimensional roller coaster ride, with a side of dark humor. Perfect for those who enjoy their apocalypse with a few laughs!

This game has everything that makes a souls game great, specifically a dodge mechanic and bonfires.  But they've taken the formula to a new high by adding bullet sponge enemies ala Halo, and meandering nonsensical maze-like procedurally generated levels.  It even has ammo!  And the story is even better than some of the best games out there, like 7 Days to Die and Fortnite.  Also, cowboy hats.

Highly recommended to any FPS lover that wants to feel like they're playing Dark Souls, without actually having to play Dark Souls.

It's Outriders, but Dark Souls. Lots of classes to unlock, lots of guns and mods for the guns to unlock, and they are all the exact same stats as anyone else's. No hunting for the perfect god-rolled stats on weapons or armor, they are just there. But, the world is RNG every play through, which makes replayability so much better than other games. First time through and you make the decisions you want. Second, you could be faced with a completely different story arc than before and have a brand new look on the game. This, coupled with the ability to freely and quickly choose which 2 classes to play (yes, completely free and completely whenever you want) gives ths game massive replay appeal.

Overall i recommend this game, especially with friends:

Pros: Amazingly tight shooter, combat feels really great, exploration is fun, the co-op with friends is a blast and solo is just as good. It's a total upgrade from remnant 1 in my eyes. I love the selection of weapons, mods, mutators and skills available within this game. Some of these boss fights and choices are really well designed and you can tell a lot of thought was put into keeping the replayability of these areas fun and interesting, even after multiple runs. I think Remnant achieved these goals really well.

Cons: this game can be really challenging at times, which is to be expected from a game with some soulslike elements within it. Sometimes it can border on frustration. Some maps have incredibly long traversal paths packed with enemies and a lot of environmental hazards that can wipe you out, having to essentially restart the area hoping to make it all the way this time. this isn't felt as hard in co-op since you have a partner to assist with revives, but unless you are running a particular archetype, if you go down in solo, you restart from your previous checkpoint, which is essentially the start of a dungeon. This game was also one of the most poorly optimized games on my CPU. They have released some patches for this that have helped, but some of the loading screens can take a serious amount of time, and the initial start screen freezes and stutters every time i load it. Thankfully it no longer crashes out like it used to for me, but it is something to be aware of. I will say in game where moment-to-moment REALLY matters, these issues do not pop up often if at all (at least not for me.)

as a small gripe, i really wish there was a better way to locate rings with certain traits/abilities in your inventory. i have so many rings and going through all of them to find a certain stat/bonus can be a real pain sometimes. Again, small gripe and something I hope the devs may offer in the future, especially if expansions plan on adding even more weapons and rings/amulets into the game.

All in all, really good game, really glad i picked this up and i always look forward to the next adventure mode/run.
