Great game, all the other reviews highlight the good points, but the public multiplayer experience is a mixed bag at best.

This game offers no incentive for sustaining the matchmaking experience. Hosts will often kick players or end sessions rather than be inconvenienced by teammates, and it's difficult to tell who the host is when you have a full team of 3. It's very rare for a public session to last long. Repeatedly loading back into the game to join a new match can get tiresome if you're just trying to enjoy some multiplayer action.

There's no leaver check. Using the quick play button, you'll get connected to people who set their sessions to public and go AFK.

Overall the game is very fun and has good design choices. In common souls-like fashion, communication is limited, in this case to gestures and pings. This probably contributes to the lack of co-operative charm that some other games overflow with. The game's mechanics make moving and communicating as a team very doable, if not intuitive and easy.

Also, there are still some multiplayer session-breaking bugs in the game, but I expect those to get polished out. Overall, this is a great game. Thanks for reading. You should read the other reviews, too!

Remnant II might be harder, better, stronger than its predecessor "From the ashes",  but my computer is getting old now. Bulletdodges on a pixel screen doesn't look cool. The game is harder for me on so many levels and I guess it's the fact that I play on below minimum recommended hardware. Or.. maybe I'm the one that's getting old!?

 ("Don't blame it on sunshine, don't blame it on moonlight, blame it on Frames per second.)

That being said - I really like the game! Looter/ shooters when done right is so rewarding and Gunfire games have hit the right spot once again on so many levels. It's just too bad that I can't fully enjoy the scenery and atmosphere because my graphics card's a Roy Batty- contemplation from the movie Bladerunner.

+ When it comes to gameplay R2 is on par with RFTA. The Movement & mechanics were good! Still is! no need to change it and the developers haven't let us down. *thumbs up*

(+/-) The narrative might be a slight upgrade perhaps. It's the same ol' save the World angle that is OK but not that exciting. In R2 the story is mainly told via Not playable characters you encounter in your home base and around the post-apocalyptic wasteland. Lore in form and shape of pergaments and books help with solving puzzles aswell as giving background and perspective.

+ The boss fights are impressive and challeging. The loot consists yet again of Necklaces, rings, weapons and weapon mods and there's a plethora of builds that you can experiment with. You can also pick up upgrades for your weapons in the form of so called 'Mutators'. They can be obtained by the NPC in Ward 13 or dropped from enemies or bosses. A cool feature!

+ Now. Archetypes, - (your character's role/class), Oh boy, what fun! Especially when you can combine two of them and benefit from both. There are many combinations to choose from. Initially, I started as a gunslinger. Now that I've leveled up 5 different types of Archetypes, nearly 7, it's fun to mix and mash and costomize your character and dps-build. 

- The game has improved a lot since launch but there were some crashes and lag issues. I'm not sure I Should comment on this due to the obvious fact that I'm playing on a piece of garbage machine.. but in that regard the fun and hype isn't there as much as in Remnant from the ashes. 

- One thing bugs the hell out of me though. Something I pointed out in my review of RFTA.. You still can't choose the amount of quantity you want to sell or buy to an NPC in the Ward. Sure you have the option nowdays to sell ALL of your precious metal, thanks I guess! But not an exact figure. So if you don't wanna sell everything you need to spamm the living ham out of your mouse button. Come on Gunfire games - please no more torture - ok?!

Look, I don't need every game I play to be a 200+ hour Elden Ring. Remnant 2 scratches the itch immensely well, and about 80 hours in now, I mostly just play to join people's games and help them out. There is a TON of variety in gameplay with different classes (archetypes), guns, mods, and consumables. The game isn't super long but you can have a lot of fun with it, and the worlds you visit are unique experiences with multiple possible stories they tell - which is a great concept for replayability.

So yeah, I recommend it. On sale is great, but even full price it's worth it. As for flaws: needs a better inventory UI. By the time you get most of the items, scrolling through looking for a particular ring gets ridiculous. The upgrade system is very grindy, especially in the first 30-40 hours. It makes it difficult to try new gear and merely serves to impede enjoyment of the myriad of awesome weapons in the game. But it's not a deal-breaker, and some masochists out there may even... like it?

Multiplayer can be a blast, although I've had connection issues at times. The story is pretty good honestly. It feels a little disjointed at times and doesn't spend enough time connecting you to a certain someone and thus caring about them before they're whisked away - but Remnant 1 & 2 tell a pretty darn cool and unique tale. It's pretty bug-free for me too. All in all, it's a solid souls-like game that you can easily get 60+ hours out of.

A sequel that maintains all the low points of the original, and changes things that worked in Remnant From the Ashes unnecessarily. The trait point cap leads to a far less rewarding grind than the original, interesting weapons/armor are sparse, scrap is even sparser (making it a slog to try new equipment), and the boss fights are hit or miss, more frequently a "miss". The final boss is a visually confusing fight that I just can't justifiably call a good conclusion. The fact that they carried over the ham-fisted scaling system, where upgrading your gear never feels as rewarding as it should, is also just disappointing. The game is also still riddled with bugs, regardless of how many hot fixes the developers release. One of the handguns, Sorrow, makes an incessant ringing noise in my cooperators headsets after using its mod power, and does not stop until I swap it out of the handgun slot and back in. 

To the games credit, the archetype system is a fun addition, and Losomn is my favorite area in both games by far.

The game is short, and the only point in carrying on is to grind in a way that is just... worse in every way than the original. Completed the main game in roughly 12 hours, and continued playing only to have my opinion of the game worsen the more I played; not exactly what you want in a game that touts its infinite replayability. As a big fan of Remnant From the Ashes, all I can say is I found this game insufficient in filling the shoes of the original.

Very disappointing for many reasons.

First, the game is way too easy and none of the enemies or bosses were memorable except for the last boss of the game. I spent the entirety of the game wondering when there would be a good fight with interesting mechanics and I never got one. I am aware that there are multiple difficulties, but all they do is make the boring fights longer.

The level design is also extremely boring, and this is exacerbated by the lengthy animations. Opening doors, activating checkpoints, climbing ladders, jumping, and so many more animations take way too long. Then I have to run through levels filled with nothing? The enemies are also extremely basic, and it's just sad to see. Oh, and did I mention that the equivalent of skill points, trait points, are only as items on the ground? It's such a chore to explore such a boring world, but if you don't do it. you'll be missing out on a lot of stats.

This game is so short (I have completed it at the time of review, with ~5 of these hours spent in co-op in a friends world, not progressing on my own), and they try to make it longer by locking certain areas/items behind completely redoing worlds. First off, ridiculous and grindy; second off, not fun. Half of the game is hidden behind what is basically NG+ mixed in with RNG. The method to getting some items and fighting some bosses is "reset this area until you RNG the one you need." 

Finally, my smallest complaint is that it takes way too much grinding to upgrade weapons/buy items. Scrap, the game's currency, is too rare. I didn't have enough to upgrade my weapons even though I had enough materials, and I was only able to buy one secondary class. I also had enough items to craft more relic (estus) uses, but not enough scrap. I picked up a lot of weapons and potential boss weapons and mods, but I wasn't able to try any of them because I didn't even have enough scrap to upgrade my previous weapons, let alone the new ones. Obviously the solution would be to sit and grind currency, but then what? I try weapons to fight these boring bosses or run around areas with nothing in them?

Overall, just way too poorly done to justify the price, even on sale.

This is a solo perspective from a non-hardcore player who plays maybe 4 times a week for 2-3 hours a session.
TL;DR: If you're going to solo the game and are an average player like myself, I would caution you that it may be a frustrating and short experience since you may not be skilled enough to advance.
I played the first game, but I could not beat either of the first 2 bosses. I saw that this game had less 'adds' on bosses (a big reason I couldn't beat Shroud or Gorefist) and I liked their varied designs, so I decided to give this a chance on sale because I liked feel of the shooting so much.
I played this on Survivor as Handler, solo.
Like I said: I *really* enjoy the feeling of the shooting mechanic in this game and the world design/aesthetic so I really wanted to try my hardest to improve so I could enjoy it, but there are just too many times when there are too many enemies' attacks to manage.  Skillful/tactical play will still result in cheap loss of life which I can't find a way to avoid.  I played handler just for the dog to aggro, but that only does so much; snipers, for example, will shoot 3 projectiles/each at you, and you can walk-strafe and shoot them as you avoid them, but you end up getting shot by another 2 at your 4 o'clock so you lose that life anyway.  Try to bottle-neck them in a doorway, their shots track you through it with a slight arc, while yours are constrained to a straight path. So they actually end up with the advantage.
I do hope that Gunfire someday allows less skilled players to enjoy the game, as well, but from skimming the boards, that doesn't seem likely.

This game brings you suffering, and then joy, then it gets your hopes up and makes you feel strong, and then it reminds you that it can and will kill you, but only if you deserved it even a little bit.

The beauty of this game is that it is brutal and unforgiving in the GOOD way, this is a game that after about 30 hours I think does difficulty the right way and I can safely say I love it for that. Too many games make challenge to mean bullet spongy enemies and cheap tricks, but Remnant 2 has interesting, deadly enemies that have [i]clever[/i] tricks. Some enemies, or situations at times feel a little bit too much, like there was no possible way for you survive which is in a way true, although almost always you look back on it and realize that something you did put you in that situation. Then the next time you go through you know more and it feels satisfying to get through it. It's still not for the faint of heart though, if you're not okay with a game that is going to make you own your mistakes than you won't like this (but then again you won't like any game similar to this either, that's not really the games fault, so I'm glad they stuck to the games vision still)

The bosses are going to kill you and make you suffer fighting them, and then every time you die, you [i]learn[/i] and you get angry, and more clever, until you beat them and it feels [i]good[/i].

The souls like element are definitely present and they're done well, in a sense it is like dark souls with guns but in another sense it almost feels like a (yes that's right, I'll say it) better version of Destiny in the genre of Dark Souls. Weapons feel viable and satisfying and it looks gorgeous. And good lord, kudos to the artists for the things they came up with in this game, the creativity is off the charts and gives that wow factor in some many places. You know the feeling where you enter a new area and just stand there for a second and say, "Huh....this is cool," yeah that happened a lot with me.

The upgrade systems, progression, is all there and works well, the ability to re-roll and replay areas feels good as well and is an interesting take. Whatever is procedural generated here feels good and real, not bland and boring. It might get that way after a lot of runs, but that's inevitable, given how satisfying the combat is though I can't dock it for that.

Overall Remnant 2 is probably one of the best games this year and feels hugely underrated to me. It does so many things so well, with very few misses. It's clever, interesting, and satisfying. Easily a near perfect 9/10 for me and strongly recommended.

And to address the co-op versus solo angle, honestly, it's fantastic either way. If you have hesitation that it won't be fun because you aren't playing it co-op, don't be. It's still fantastic no matter which way you play. The fact that it works so well in co-op is a fantastic achievement but it doesn't require it to be good - exactly how it should be and an example of good game design as a whole.

Do you enjoy dying over and over again to the same boss? Good, This is the game for you.

A great Souls-Like experience. Especially fun to play with a friend. Various builds, bosses and area's allow a wide variety of game play.
The general 'run through' is highly entertaining because there are so many ways and possibly hidden loot which could turn out to be some great item which fits your build perfectly.

Boss design is great, lots of variety, each boss is completely different and requires learning all the basic dodging again while getting blasted by several new attacks.
Some minor issues are little bugs here and there, certain skills put you stuck in place such as overcharging the 'rage' skill on the challenger class. This normally makes the player invulnerable for all attacks, as you can't do anything during that moment. However sometimes you get attacked and still take damage.

AOE's are VERY difficult to dodge as some builds require you to be zoomed in for a longer period of time to do more damage and so on. Bombs get thrown at you from high, but you can't see it until the last split second.
Certain attacks can be launched at the same time but hit you at slightly different rates. You'll dodge the first but second already comes faster than you can dodge a second time causing you to eat the hit.
After focusing much more on every single thing thrown at you, this gets easier to deal with but could use some patching. As my current build demands constant shooting for a 10 second window to deal high dps it's a bit annoying.

There was also one boss upon a platform throwing grenades and what not to you. It's placement upon that platform with no way of getting to that level, he was very annoying to play. He'd sit in the center, ok fine run to the center, nope he moved to the side again, ok move to the side. Nope he went back all the way across now. Not a single hit can be given during these moments.

The good/more fun weapons are locked behind bosses which you can't complete right away. Certain weapons/items/classes are locked behind finishing the game once. Where's the fun in that? 
Let me run around throwing black holes at  halfway the game, makes the next play through more fun as well.
I can't be bothered running around for hours until i've found that one secret hole where it could be. Something could be done here, like a skill or pet that sometimes points things out.
Still the overall atmosphere and setting of the game are fun

Leveling up and upgrading skills and weapons is a part of the game which is good. But it could be better.
As it is, you sometimes get through area's and face a certain boss, but at halfway HP you realize you're just not strong enough to finish the fight. So you'll have to go back and rerun the same previous maps/bosses to find more items and loot and XP to get more damage or support out of your first run build. Especially on the second hardest difficulty this gets a little tedious rather quickly.

A longer more streamlined way of getting build items/rings/amulets/etc, to then slay a boss according to your level across more maps would be a better experience. You'll get a sense of accomplishment better than just rerunning area's until you're  strong enough to take it on.

Certain drops are RNG based. The challenger for example can be both ranged and a great melee class. Therefor most relic drops are melee based. But what if a player prefers ranged on the challenger because of it's static buffs?
Why not give the choice for the Melee or Ranged relic version on pickup?

While my review may sound negative, these are only things i'd like to see different.
Overall i have a great time in the game and doing all sorts of bosses and trying to find certain items is quite fun.
Currently i Burn and explode everything i see alive (even the children at Ward 13 (ingame)) But i'm curious about a more sniper based class or perhaps Alchemist. Once unlocked.. :)

Remnant 2 is my GOTY. It truly hits everything that I want in an ARPG and SoulsLike game. When Remnant: From The Ashes came out, I felt like it released out of no where and it was a solid game. Gun Fire games blew all my expectations out of the water with Remnant 2. 10/10 for me this year. Lets cover why. 

Archetypes:
I love the archetype system and the freedom to mix and match and try crazy class combinations, mixed with the myriad of items to choose from there are truly endless options for builds, the 500 hours I have put in a is a mix of just exploring every nook and cranny and trying different archetypes and truly learning the pros and cons between them. This is such a fun and robust system even between DLCs it keeps me coming back.

Items:
The items that you are rewarded feel purposeful and useful. While some are stronger, build into a meta and just down right OP. There is a ring, weapon, amulet or relic that fits into some type of play style. Again the builds are endless. I am still farming to complete all 100% of the base and DLC items and I cannot wait for more. 

Combat:
If you played RFtA then you know the combat. Tho Rem2 feels much cleaner, more responsive and over all just high adrenaline rush while in combat. The combat is fun and engaging keeping you on your toes especially in higher difficulties. The boss fights are a blast, i enjoyed them very much. My biggest complaint in combat is the Apocalypse modifiers on bosses. These can stop your build dead, and then you either just push through it or find away to adapt it. Probably my biggest pet peeve with modifiers and I would love to see them add an option to turn them off when re-rolling adventures/campaigns. Otherwise combat is amazing. 

World:
The worlds this time around are amazing. Probably my favorite and among the many others is Losmon, the Bloodborne English Elvin setting just feels amazing. Root Earth, while a royal pain in my arse, I love the design and feel of it. Yaesha was just a typical jungle and Ner'ud my least favorite in terms of enemies but my favorite in terms of aesthetics. Only Gun Fire Games found away to make all these unique worlds work together. They are blast to explore (except Ner'ud, cause vomiting is always fun) and the randomization does add some fresh play to the worlds on each new role. 


Weapons/Mods/Mutators/Skills:
This is where the game shines, the Weapons/Mods/Mutators/Skills are unique, thought out and just fun. Turning into a lightning overload that can teleport while dishing out constant lighting building up crit dmg while your turret has infinite ammo and a fire tornado is spinning around killing all the enemies it pulls in, never felt so good. GunFireGames did an outstanding here and while some guns do lack punch or fit into a build, they are all fun to just play around with and see what works where. 


Performance:
This is where the game has issues, and its really tough on PC. I run a 7950x with a 7900xt and 32GB of and Samsung SSDs across the board and I could be consistently at 120FPS then just walking i drop to 15 FPS for no reason. I have played with so many settings, I actually ended up turning off AMD Smart Access Memory and this help stabilize the fluctuation of my FPS and instead of dropping down to 15 from 120, i drop to 60. There is for sure much work that needs to be done here, as I do not encounter this in any other game.  Hopefully the devs can figure it out and optimize the game. 


DLC:
The DLC for me was a blast. All though short, I beat it in about 5 hours, the lore of Lomson has been fabulous. The fights are awesome and I am still discovering secrets as I go. I 100% recommend the DLC, even tho i feel the release of it hindered the performance of the game even more.

Overall:
Remnant 2 has struck some many cords over the other glaring issues it has, performance, some design choices and other little annoying factors like buggy items (Brewmasters Cork) otherwise this game is a 10/10 for me and shows that if a company actually cares and has good leadership and not chasing the games wallet amazing games can be made. I look forward to the future of Remnant and the DLCs and  hopefully some neat game modes.

Bottom line:

This is an amazing single-player FPS RPG. Because the network implementation for coop is peer-to-peer, you should not buy expecting to play a soulslike with friends.

Main considerations:

- the gunplay is varied and uniformly excellent, and the melee is pretty good. I'd say the physics feel not quite as good as Destiny 2, but that is imo the highest bar for gunplay - this is still incredibly satisfying to play on a visceral level, and a noticeable improvement over the first Remnant game.
- core "loops" within the game like ammunition management, gun upgrading, archetype leveling etc. feel good. There's a lot of room for balance and other improvements, but this seems like an area where the dev team will continue to make good progress over time.
- the core "souls-like" elements are generally great; it's a big, ambitious game, so of course there is no shortage of stupid boss mechanics, broken hitboxes, scripted trash mob spawns, etc. that will kill you in utterly unfair ways. But for something like 70% of challenging encounters, I would win after 2-3 tries and be left with the feeling of having solved a very cool puzzle and improved my mastery of very satisfying movement and shooting mechanics.
- the worldbuilding is generally great, and the mini-stories of each world you explore pair very well with the art and overall tone of the game. the procedural generation of maps, while it often feels gimmicky, does in the end add somewhat to the replayability, which is no mean accomplishment as most games that try this don't reach that bar. the world variety is currently too small by about half, but this feels easy to improve over time and generally reasonable to ask players to pay on the order of $10 per year for more of.

- the game was shipped with huge, devastating bugs, most notably ones that will erase all of your character progression and can irreparably (as far as we know as of now) corrupt your save.
- the devs are present on discord and reddit and twitter, but their presence does not seem to be paired with any meaningful community or product management, so there is no bug tracking, no organized triage, no way to know when bugs that are preventing you from playing might be fixed or even if they are being investigated (unless they happen to make the weekly reddit announcement).
- the idea that this game is "multiplayer" is probably misleading. It has a small feature set built around coop, but leaving aside myriad big but solvable problems with that implementation, fundamentally the combination of a soulslike game, that relies on carefully studying animations and dodging damage with invulnerability frames, with a peer-to-peer network architecture just does not work.
- only caveat to this is it's possible that if you're very geographically/network-topographically close to the people you want to play with you might have a good experience--I haven't tried but it does seem at least theoretically possible, depending on how consoles/Steam handle such a setup.

Overall Remnant 2, just like the first game has been amazing. It has a abundance of secrets and alternate boss kills. Enemy AI seems relatively smart in most instances and can be rather aggressive which is good to see. The final bosses which their are multiple of for each world have been amazing in design. It's also clear that the Developers do absolutely love this game and are trying to listen to feedback. I would highly recommend this game to anyone. ALSO, you can pet the dog from the Handler class.

HOWEVER, friendly AI for summons and the dog is horrific to the point that they will sometimes genuinely just stand there in front of a enemy and not attack. Certain bosses or enemies do have attacks that can stun lock you into a cheesy death on occasion. 

I DO HAVE TO BRING UP THE ENDING AND FINAL BOSS OF THIS GAME... the end boss fight of this game genuinely feels awful and gimmicky... It's essentially a THREE PHASE FIGHT that feels anything but enjoyable or fair especially when compared to the design and difficulty of every world boss prior. I didn't feel challenged by it or enjoy it; a final boss of a game shouldn't make you feel relieved that it's finally over or see it as a final chore to be completed each campaign run. The ending cinematic of the game does have me worried; it very much gave the distinct impression that this story was written purely with DLC in mind. Still absolutely GOTY. What a marvelous masterpiece.

What can I say about Remnant 2?

Well let's start with my biggest and only real complaint about the game is the limit to only 3 players. Now considering that as my only real complaint is something that most people could just write off, that says a lot about what I think of the game.

Remnant 2 is the first game since Spyro Reignited that I even considered wanting to 100%, and I actually did successfully 100% it, at least until the DLC released. There are practically no games where I actually attempt to 100% the game.

As a friend has reviewed this game and only using a single sentence of his review, "You can easily play through the entire game with just the starting weapons and still face a fair challenge." and quite frankly I love how he puts that, because many games make it so you have to hunt down specific weapons just to have a chance at beating the game. Remnant 2 developer Gunfire Games seems to strive for a game where all options are equally viable, or at least such within reason.

The fact that the game story is designed in a mix of somewhat randomly generated maps where not everything will be available with every run, they do however have a way to make every piece of content playable on a single character, so you don't have to worry about that. The main story content is setup in 5 parts, first you play a world that is of that somewhat randomly generated stuff, then you get a set-piece, followed by 2 more with the generated stuff, and finishes with a final set-piece.

The DLC is fun and seems to be setup, so any character can play the DLC immediately via Adventure Mode.

Overall, I have had a blast and expect to put way more hours into the game. Worth noting that in the 1st month of release I put so many hours into the game, way out of normal for myself. I even picked up the game for a few friends of mine.

[h3] First Impressions [/h3] 

I went into this blind, never having played the previous games. Given what I had seen in 30 seconds of trailer footage, I thought this would be a Souls-like game with guns, set in a Bloodborne-like universe. I was mistaken in all the right ways.

Don't get me wrong, I love Souls games, and the comparison isn't far off, but needless to say my initial idea of this game doesn't fully capture the essence of Remnant 2. After about 15 minutes of gameplay, the scope of the narrative opened up and I was HOOKED.

 [h3] Story & Environments [/h3] 

What Remnant 2 offers is a story with lore on a generally similar scale and aesthetic to Souls games, but with less of FromSoftware's signature ambiguity and vagueness, which I sometimes find difficult to get invested in. It features lots of interesting characters with fantastic writing and performances, alien worlds, and beautiful vistas.

The environments boast meaningful visual variety that's still surprising me 30+ hours in. Enemy variety is also quite good, with each environment featuring new enemies with cool visuals and unique behavior. Weapons and armors look so cool too, which matters a lot if you're playing for fashion. The gunplay is very satisfying, and the game encourages a variety of playstyles and builds.

 [h3] Playstyle Variety [/h3] 

Forego traditional healing and only heal from weapon mods? Melee focused? Summoner build? Sniper glasscannon? It's all possible, and encouraged.

Resources work so that you can always completely change your build at a very low cost. I've already shifted my character's focus multiple times as I stock up on interesting equipment, and it's been refreshing to have the freedom to redefine my playstyle so easily.

 [h3] Difficulty [/h3] 

Another way Remnant 2 differs from Souls games is that it isn't as punishing. Death is not as big of a deal, you can often respawn very near a boss gate instead of having to run through enemies to retry a fight, and all in all it doesn't feel as difficult. I don't think this is a bad thing though, it keeps the momentum going, and there's certainly still enough of a challenge to keep me invested and focused.

 [h3] Exploration & Discovery[/h3] 

Beyond all this, however, the part that really appeals to me is the exploration and discovery. The world is full of secrets, hidden passages, puzzles, and challenges. There's a plethora of items to collect, with high content replay value (and replay systems that make this super easy and comfortable). Some randomness introduced here and there keeps things fresh, too.

With the exception of a few especially obtuse secrets, the exploration is super satisfying. It feels like there's something cool to discover and collect around every corner. And it's rewarding on an intrinsic level, it doesn't hold your hand and map everything out for you. Unlike many publishers who see potentially missable content as time wasted on development, Remnant 2 is indeed a lot like Souls games - not at all afraid to see large chunks of its content missed if you don't look for it. And that makes discovering it all the more sweeter.

I absolutely loved the first Remnant and played through that one several times. After comparing this one to the first, I can say that the second one is sort of disappointing. So to start the graphics are nice and the gameplay felt smooth for me. I enjoyed some of the added features as well. 

However, this game falls flat with some big components. The first one being that this game is way shorter then the first one which was kind of a bummer. The second big issue is the upgrade system overall, they added a trait point count at like 60 which is weird considering the last game was like 600 or 700. You don't even really earn trait points like the last game too so it makes farming and replayability pretty much nonexistent. You basically find trait points laying around and sure you earn a couple here and there, but its just not the same. They for some reason took out armor upgrading which is weird, because once again that just decreases replayability and farming. It makes visiting recent sections pointless and it shortens the game a lot. 

The story in the game kind of sucks. The main villain which are the Root hardly show up in the game. You see them in the beginning and you see them in the end that's it. Don't get me started on the ending its pretty much this vegans wet dream where the groots were too powerful and grew out of control and the only choice was to Thanos wipe everything which was just lame af. For some reason too this Clementine character is more or less a god with all this mystical power for no reason lol. The story is whack just put it that way. 

Now I can forgive them cutting out a bunch of content that adds to replayability and I can forgive a dumbA$$ story with SpeD characters, but the meat and potatoes of Remnant are the bosses. We come here to battle some muffuggin tough and cool bosses and the bosses in this game are dog water to the first ones. The first game had a larger variety of cooler more unique bosses compared to this one. Not to mention that the bosses in this game feel way easier then the first ones. I don't know how to put my finger on it, but when I played against the first boss in the first game this Gorefist guy I got rocked by him like 13 times before beating him. In this game I pretty much dusted every boss first or second try. [Excluding the final two bosses]. 

This is not to trash the developers and im not saying Remnant 2 is bad, but its a downgrade in a lot of ways compared to the first. 
Im sure there will be more content that can be purchased later so we will see the end product at some point.

Archetypes are a welcome addition to the game and the worlds themselves are way more interesting and much more varied than the first game, however the story continues to be lackluster. It's incredibly apparent in this title as well, almost as if the base game's story was intentionally left hollow to leave room for the DLCs.

The game itself plays a lot like the first game, with a reworked trait system that has a hard cap on usable trait points to encourage making builds instead of just endlessly grinding trait points to eventually max out everything. The archetypes play very well into this system, and being able to mix them gives some very decent build variety. Melee is also not complete garbage in this game due to some new incredible trait bonuses. Unlockable archetypes also add a lot to the game's replayability, and I'm very excited for the new DLC archetypes and what they will bring to the table.

Overall, if you enjoyed the first game, you are essentially getting much more of it along with some shiny new abilities/weapons to play with. Is it worth full price? Unless you are a hardcore Remnant fan, then no. For new players, I would definitely pick it up once it's gone on sale. It plays much like the first game while adding enough gameplay variety with archetypes to keep the game interesting.

Remnant 2 does exactly what Remnant from the ashes did, but better. The Game looks absolutely amazing, the weapons are cool and fun to use and most of the Areas are fun as well. 

The Game however has some flaws. The first of them being N´Erud, fck N´Erud, this area is absolutely unfun.
While the Idea and Lore of the area is pretty cool, the experience isn´t. Large open areas, locked by poisonous mist that animation locks you, as well as tons of Zombies and Drones shooting you. The Dungeons are either Hallways filled with bugs and other crawling creatures or Towers with the same Robot enemies all over the place. But hey, at least the bosses in this area are kinda cool. 
The Second Issue I have with this game are the FPS Drops. My Hardware exceeds the recommended stats, and yet the game sometimes freezes or drops down to below 20 fps. This Issue made the Endboss into a double fight. Fighting the boss itself, while fighting FPS Drops and input delays at the same time. 

Despite these Issues I´ve beaten the game three times and had mostly a good and fun time. Co-Op is also where this game really shines. Playing with friends can make this game a lot easier, or harder, depending on what your friends are doing. When not taken too serious, friendly fire can cause some hilarous moments, where Rotten Arrows or Firestorm knock you around or suck you out of the map, just to fall free bird style for 30 seconds. Despite the performance issues (please fix them gearbox) the game is good and fun, grab a friend and give it a try.

Better than the first game, and I liked the original; this is probably the most fun I've had in multiplayer co-op with friends.

The game-play is enjoyable, there is a decent amount of enemy variety and different ways to approach combat. 

The bosses in Remnant 2 are infinitely superior to the first, the original just had the bosses swamp you with enemy waves, in this sequel the bosses have more interesting mechanics and far fewer or no minion spawns.

Progression is also a fairly pleasant experience, the traits available in Remnant 2 are generally more meaningful than they were in the first game. If there was an issue here, it's just the trait point cap; base game the cap was 65 I think, which I thought was very restrictive. The new cap after the first DLC drop is 85 and this is substantially better, but I would still like maybe 10 to 15 more points.

The two main things holding the game back is writing and lack of biomes.

Writing doesn't matter too much, it's not why I play Remnant 2, but it's largely not much more than serviceable. There are certain quest-lines that are actually pretty fun when it comes to the writing, but the main campaign is nothing to write home about. Arguably, the ending of the mainline story is outright bad.

The issue regarding variety when it comes to the biomes is something I'm hoping DLC can resolve, adding two new worlds/areas would go a long way. Currently, even with the randomization and numerous secrets, I don't think there's enough here to keep things from getting stale beyond a handful of play-throughs for me.

There are still more minor issues, heavy armor doesn't really feel very impactful on higher difficulties cause you'll probably get blown away in one or two hits anyway, but these sorts of things don't detract from the experience to have me list them out.

The idea of a more gun-heavy Bloodborne style game already intrigued me but I only fell hard for Remnant when I saw the trailer for the Ritualist class, and I bought and played the game within the hour.

The game certainly has a steep learning curve like most Soulslikes, but there are a selection of difficulty modes if you're the type to get frustrated easily. I started off on "Veteran" mode, the second of four because I'm somehow worried about some invisible force judging me for starting on "easy mode" and found that difficulty to be quite a solid meaty challenge that wasn't too rough for the most part but still had a few bosses and areas that took quite a few attempts to beat.

The gameplay is fun and fast paced, and as you might expect from a Soulslike quite difficult. The selection of classes are varied and there are lots of fun and viable playstyle, though certainly some classes are much stronger for solo-play than others.

The levels are stunningly detailed and most are beautiful with gorgeous backdrops, though there are one or two areas that are less impressive than the others. I didn't have the experience of the earlier games, and while the game does give a little exposition much of the world is left unexplained. The usual Soulsborne type worldbuilding through item flavour text is in effect, though the lore did feel spread quite wide and thin, perhaps something that you wouldn't feel if you'd played the previous games in the serious.

If I had to critique the game I'd say that some of the classes can be a little more esoteric to unlock than it feels they really should be. The game does reuse some standard enemies with beefed up health as boss encounters which can feel a little disappointing. But my main complaint is being restricted to two abilities. I suspect having more powers might mess with the game's balance which is understandable, but it always felt like I should be able to use three or four abilities so that I wasn't constantly waiting on cooldowns. Even just being able to use two abilities from a single class if you don't have a second class equipped would have been nice.

Other than that though I'd say the game is definitely worth your time. The story didn't grab me as hard as Soulsborne titles did, but the gameplay was just as addictive, with plenty of buildcrafting to be done.

In a perfect world there would be no need to review Remnant 2. In a perfect world, good taste would be a universal virtue and everyone would have already bought and enjoyed the masterpiece that Remnant 2 is.....but we all know this is not a perfect world.

Let me tell you something about Remnant 2. We are talking about one of the most polished and amazing games ever made. Gunfire broke the goddamn mold and this is no longer a "souls" with guns....this is Remnant 2 baby, and Remnant 2 now has its own game category. 

The unparalleled and  extremly satisfying third person shooting action is the main reason to buy this game right here and now but of course you...(the reader of this review) want more than that and belive me when i say you shall get it. 
Im not going to bore you with details and a wall of text but will just say that the game feels totally different depending your "loadout". As a loadout im not only talking about your archtypes or weapons....ooooh no hoho. Also ring, traits, amulets and more, game feels completly different and equally entertaining. So dont even dare to think this is a simple game at all but at the same time not unnecesary complex. You can face the challenge by yourself or with friends in true co-op action, reanimating your fallen comrades while you run towards them as fast your character legs allows it. All of this with massive bosses and monsters in the way, raising hell every second forcing you to constantly think your next move and avoiding harm. There are various difficulty levels designed for basic or more advanced characters but all of them provide a balanced and extremly challenging experience both solo and co-op. 

Now...graphics..this is ART. From the jungle of Yaesha to the derelict docks in Losonm everything looks perfect, after all we are talking about a Unreal 5 game well programed. So bear in mind that you will need a "decent" computer with a proper GPU and not trash like a 3070. Boss fights are breath taking...everything in this game is.

Sound. I think the guys who picked the Game of the Year award nominess are totally tone-deaf in every sense of the word. Mr. Rob Westwood composed one of the best soundtracks ever made......i consider a CRIME this game was not nominated for this particular thing...but i guess there are some philistines left  (even in 2023)

Anyways go and buy the damn game already. Treat yourself with the best action game of the year, alone or with friends you are going to enjoy every second of your time played, so dont miss it!

Oh one last thing. There is people who consider hot garbage like Sekiro the hardest game ever made. They think they are some "superstarts" for beating a damn game about a one handed hobo with a katana (LOL)....you guys are nothing more than fluffers...KINGS who killed the last boss alone or co-op in  apocalypse difficulty are the real stars here. So if you want a real challenge buy Remnant 2 RIGHT NOW.

Remnant 2 has easily become one of my favorite games of all time. Here's the short version as to why:

Exceptionally fun tactical gunplay, mechanically fun and unique spectacle-style boss encounters, secrets galore, weapons, and loot that are beyond cool and fun to collect, all bundled together with a really great skill and level system to make you always feel like you're making progress somewhere. I can't recommend it enough. It's some of the most fun I've had with a game in years, and I hope more people get the chance to appreciate it.

The long version: It's surprising even to me that I'm singing such high praises. I never played the original Remnant, and haven't heard of Gunfire Games either. Perhaps more interesting, is that I am not the biggest fan of FromSoftware's souls-like formula. I don't particularly seek out punishingly difficult games. To come from that background and enjoy Remnant 2 this much, as a game that's marketed as 'Souls-like with guns', I think that's worthy of including right at the beginning here.

To get some of the weaker points of the game out of the way, some of the narrative is a bit uninteresting. Some of the art direction is a little bland and uninspired. Maybe some of the music is lacking character. Definitely hated the puking in N'Erud. Some other negligible nitpicks not worth mentioning. But those are my only complaints.

I've technically played through the game almost 3 times over and I'm still having a blast. I can't stress enough how important it is to go in with the expectation that you will have to "replay" the game and when doing so you will *SEE* some similar things as this game is lightly procedurally generated. There are 3 main areas, each can generate one of two different world bosses. Within those areas, you have a certain number of dungeons, that are also randomized in their inclusion. Then within the dungeons themselves, the tileset is scrambled to a degree. So in my 3 playthroughs of the game, it feels like over 70% of all the content I'm seeing is new dungeons. New bosses. Always new mini-bosses. It's always fresh! A mechanic that is done super super well. Because it's all randomized if you want to play with a friend, it's likely that you'll see or experience something you've never seen before making this (what I presume to be) a really cool multiplayer experience).

So let me be even clearer -- You're going to want to beat this game twice. But understand: more than 80% of everything you'll see on your second time through will have different paths, leading to different dungeons, bosses, and different loot, with a different overarching story for each. Even beyond the two playthroughs I recommend, there are multiple ways to kill bosses or complete areas, which also determines the loot you get so you may find yourself as I am now, meticulously searching the game for the coolest weapons in the most hidden of secrets, and doing the alternative boss killing methods.

I think what really made a huge difference for me in making the Souls formula bearable is you don't lose anything when you die other than progress since your last checkpoint. There's no crap mechanic where you have to go grab the currency you accumulated through the whole dungeon after you die to a cheap boss move, or fall off a cliff or whatever. It was a constant relief to have that area of my brain available to focus on the boss encounters and have more unabated fun.

What glues it all together is certainly the gunplay and the light RPG systems. I did have to fiddle with my DPS to get it just right, but once I got comfortable with aiming, the rest of the game felt so good to play! Weapons feel excellent to use, and some pack a wallop of a punch, visibly staggering or even knocking over weaker enemies. The animations in this game sell the vigor of combat as your bullets penetrate your foes, especially as you hit weak spots. In that sense, the gunslinging you do can really fulfill some great power fantasies. But the guns, ESPECIALLY the ones hidden away in secrets are SO cool, some overpowered in their own right, and everyone is fun to use in their own right.

I also loved the level-up system in conjunction with the skill and perks. Besides your two guns, and single melee, your character class (or classes as you equip a second class later in the game) has 3 variations of an ultimate ability that you can use to spice up combat. Each character class has 10 levels as well, and all have passive bonuses that you accumulate. The skill tree is a little more vast, with a total of 65 levels (at the time of writing) that you can attribute to various little bonuses here and there. But it all comes together and makes you feel like every encounter, every action has meaningful consequences helping you advance and progress through the game.

I need a paragraph for the secrets in this game. There are many. Some are hiding behind methods so far beyond the normal human understanding it is insane. My advice? Beat the game once through blind. In your second playthrough, try and hit all the world bosses you missed the first time and while you're at it, look up a guide on how to unlock all the character classes. Archon alone will probably add another 20 hours to your playtime. Then really open your third eye and watch some YouTube videos on how to get the best weapons. See how far the rabbit hole goes. There was a minute where I kept getting recommended Remnant 2 videos on my TikTok for you page, and out of the 15 videos I found, they were all different weapons, behind different secrets, that I had never seen before. There is so much that any average player just won't find it all. Don't feel bad about watching or reading how to find some of this stuff! I promise it is still a challenge to get to, even if you know where you're going.

And one little section about the boss encounters. Some of the most interesting and variated I've ever played in a game. Period. Some of them had attacks and moves that made me have audible yells, and many prompted shouts of victory after I finally had defeated them. They are truly some of the best parts of this entire game.

Overall, Remnant 2 is an incredible package of a game. Even at full price, which is cheaper than your average AAA game, it's a compelling package that makes every second of your time within it worth it. You always feel like you're progressing in one way or another, and it's always fun. I can't wait for more people to play it, and experience the depth of its secrets, and exceptional combat. Thanks, Gunfire Games!

If you loved Remnant: From the Ashes, then this is it, but with new worlds, more in depth RPG mechanics, new stuff, it's Remnant but more so it's awesome. Otherwise, if you like the idea of Souls-like with classes, guns, actual co-op and option for higher difficulties, with built-in path randomizer, this is a great buy. 

Character building isn't centered around attributes, instead you get traits that improve your mechanical stats, but you have to find and unlock most traits. You get classes which you can combine two of, with skills and perks and you can put more skills (mods) on weapons to use. Rest comes from your amulet, rings and "healing flasks" which can do other stuff than healing. Gear bonuses range from buffs, to changing how things work so great variability. 

You get campaign mode which can spawn you different locations from a pool so potentially each playthrough is a little different plus maps are somewhat randomized in layout, but you also get adventure mode so you can just play through each world separately and look for stuff you need for your dream build.

Graphics and lore are beautiful, big draw of this game I think are the very varied biomes and different themes that come with them, from dream-like forest and ancient castles, to old "London" and post-apocalyptic earth, with some alien deep space sci-fi shenanigans, but you definitely have more random lore than consistent story.

Edit: The DLC is exactly what I like to see here, new maps, new meta story, new class, new items. Keep them coming because it was a lot of fun!

Great game, finished the story multiple times by now and had a lot of fun sofar.
The story telling as well as the design of the games locations and enemy variety has noticeably improved in detail and scope compared to Remnant 1.
The amount of ingame-events, as well as the number of different dungeons has increased and the new archetype classes are an interesting addition that further enables the diversity of possible playstyles.

Most mechanics known from the predecessor can still be found although there have been some changes which, combined with said new archetypes, seemingly aim for a greater diversity of playstyle as well. Such would be the moving of set-effects from armor sets to the increased variety of rings, amuletts and Dragonhearts.

That being said, compared to Remnant 2 does have some "flaws" as well.
To promote the variety of different builds the game does have an upper limit of trait points you can aquire which is not as high as one might suspect. Where in Remnant 1 you would (as a long time player) max out your traits at some point and 
be able to run through high difficulty maps in record time, in Remnant 2 that is no longer possible.
Not only are traits limited in the amount of points you can aquire but some traits known from the 1st game have been removed entirely, mostly those that increase damage dealt.
In addition the games locations now scale heavily align with the powerlevel of your character.
Meaning, the strength of a locations inhabitants depends much more strongly on your powerlevel the first time you enter it
than the difficulty you have set.

The combined trait-level cap and said enemy-scaling make it extremely hard to level your character to a point where it feels like you can evenly fight enemies on high difficulties.
Therefore except for aquring some nice moves by leveling archetypes, leveling sometimes does not feel like its improving your characters capabilities in comparison to the opponents you face.

Another "flaw" is the way the developers have been patching the game ever since its release.
As it often rather pushes the players towards  certain playstyles, such as reducing the maximum possible damage reduction
provided by armor whilst increasing the disadvantages of waring heavy armor, implementing new hardcaps on stats
or reducing some archetypes damage output.
A good example would be "fixing" a bug that occoured whenever a player managed to create a 100% cooldown reduction
build by hardcapping cooldown reduction on 65%. (Which is more like not fixing the broken top shelf and putting up a "do not use" sign instead of just repairing the shelf)


Overall the game is still a lot of fun, especially if you have played Remnant 1 as you can really see the amount of love the developers poured into its details. And I highly recomend it as a coop game.

However if you are looking for long-time fun with your niche-builds and are easily aggravated by developer patches affecting your thoroughly created favourite build, you might want to consider whether you want to buy it for full price or not.

So far its been a really great coop looter shooter. Gunplay is super fun, going through dungeons is engaging, and the 2 player dynamics are great. The game is very clearly built to avoid problems with playing both single and multiplayer, and doesnt seem to have issues with overleveled teammates ruining the fun for others (an issue i had with borderlands). Playing through the main campaign with my bf (love you babe) has been really *painless.

One of my favorite parts is how not a single part of your build is really locked in. Rings, Amulets, Relics, Weapon Mods, and even your classes can be swapped out at any time (not even at a checkpoint!), so trying out tons of stuff is super easy and doesnt require any amount of grinding or finite resources (*ahem* fromsoft). Skill points do require you buy an item to reset them, but theyre not super impactful and said item is relatively cheap, infinite, and immediately available.

The story and characters arent really anything to write home about, but i find it mildly interesting and some of the character designs are fun (we both love dwell).

So far we're having a blast playing it, and i totally recommend anyone who wants an RPG hoard shooter.

*ive noticed some iffy netcode and delay, but he personally doesnt notice it across continents so it hasnt bothered us :P

I bought it based on the high praise from other players, as most trailers and gameplay videos to me did not clearly showcase how exactly the game plays, but sold something that looked fun, I bought it.

The game is definitely souls-like. The bosses are intended to be difficult. I'm playing on first difficulty but they can still become an issue. However so far I feel it is due to clunky controls rather than actual difficulty. 

You improve your gear by finding pre-determined loot in the open world and by upgrading enchantments on your gear by using boss-organs. Sounds fun right? I thought so too, but somehow wasn't enjoying it too much. Maybe because compared to Elden Ring, you don't actually get different looking/behaving loot. Or if you do is infrequent enough I haven't gotten to it yet.

Gunfight is nice, but why am I constantly out of bullets? This is my number one reason to rest - and respawn all the trash -. I thought about doing melee, but you get penalised so much doing that it is not worth it.

The game offers infrequent puzzles to solve. They're so fun, without fail they make me wish I was playing something else. I'm now at a spot where I just can't be bothered to figure out where to go next, as I'm not interested in clearing the trash for the nth time to get exactly back where I am now.

I'll see if I end up trying more, as my refund request is denied. So, a fair warning: 2 hours provided is not enough to decide if you like the game or not.

A marked improvement in essentially every single way over the first one. While I'd call From the Ashes an interesting but ultimately mediocre niche game, this one is absolutely worth your money if you a fan of the genre.

By now a lot of the rough edges of it's troubled release have been sanded away, though it is not without it's remaining issues.

The graphics aren't actually that good if you look at them in detail, but the design carries the entire visual presentation easily, while the music has some serious unexpected bangers in there.

About half the bosses are somewhat boring reskins of existing mobs, but unlike the first one, the other half vary between pretty w/e and absolutely incredible (the final boss in particular is one of the best bosses I have ever seen in my life, which is doubly ironic considering how bad the final boss of the first game was).

Class and gun variability keeps this game fresh far beyond it's assumed shelf life and while you start noticing the basic layouts of areas very soon, the randomly generated worlds, different final world bosses and especially the, at times, excellent special events are worth repeat playthroughs if you enjoy the core gameplay.

The game is of course hardly perfect and there are a few things you might want to be aware of before you start:
- Melee only does not work in this game despite what everyone including the developers of the game tell you; most bosses are designed with range clearly in mind and some are flat out impossible to melee because they are flying enemies
- In true Soulsborne(TM) fashion, the game is absolutely crap at explaining some fairly important gameplay concepts
- Some of the random boss modifiers are just actually asinine and turn otherwise properly designed fights into a dumpster fire
- Pet/Summon classes trivialize 90% of the game, while they just don't work at all on the remaining 10%

But honestly this game, especially for its lower than usual price and how often it is discounted, is an absolute steal. If you like Souls-likes and third person shooters, you should get this.

Not half as good as Remnant From the Ashes. Scaling and level cap are the main issues in Remnant 2, remove scaling and you'll have a near perfect game. Skill points are capped at 65, unlike Remnant 1, you can't max out every trait, but there's a mod that raises the cap and one that increases trait levels from 10 to 20 so you can get traits to feel like they do something.
Scaling: 
-You'll have fun as long as you don't level your weapons past lvl5. You'd think a lvl20 weapon with 300dmg would one-shot a basic enemy but it'll take 5 shots, the same weapon at lvl3 60dmg could 2 shot that basic enemy. Oh, and scaling is based on your inventory, not what you have equipped, so that lvl3 weapon is going to fall off if you have a lvl6 weapon in storage... In Remnant 1 Scaling was based on the Difficulty, World, and +1lvl over player gearscore. Your weapons do more damage at max lvl than at lvl5. In Remnant 2 it's claimed scaling works the same as the first game but that's just not true, lvl5 weapons do more damage than max lvl20. Enemies at gearscore 12-14 feel balanced, you can do good feeling damage but can die just as easy, at gearscore 20 a common enemy has so much health you'll empty a mag from a gun that should 2 shot the fucker. Forget about bosses, you can learn the attacks and strats to take no damage but you'll empty all your ammo before you see 1% dent in the healthbar, it'll make you wonder why you leveled your weapons at all. But that same boss vs lvl5 guns will be easy. Many Faced God boss on Yaesha Nightmare (Hard) takes me less than 2m to kill with my lvl5 guns but the same boss on Adventure (Easy) with max lvl20 guns took almost 30m to kill.
Story:
-Not as good as Remnant 1, they tried to make the cast of Ward 13 interesting with some cutscenes and making some of them central to the story. it didn't work. Just like Remnant 1, all the good story is in the notes and characters you find in the different worlds, but they took interesting characters you only read about in Remnant 1 and brought them to disappointing life in Remnant 2. The Dreamers you read about in Remnant 1 are now part of the Ward 13 cast and have just a little personality as the rest of Ward 13. Ford, Clementine, that dude that gives you new classes, they should have just been reading material because whoever wrote all the notes and books from Remnant 1 was a great story and world builder while whoever wrote the cutscenes and player dialogues with these characters for Remnant 2 probably came from Netflix if you know what i mean. -World building is still here in the notes you find in the worlds so it's not bad, just missed the intrigue that was present in the first game. Overall would have been better if things continued with our player from Remnant 1 instead of doing a massive time jump and a new hero with a partner that takes no part in anything and taking characters of mystique and making them into some teen drama. It's good that Ford just fucks off for the whole story cause one lame scene isn't going to ruin him but Clementine is the main story, reading about her in Remnant 1 is like reading Claremont's X-Men, watching her scenes and listening to her player dialogue is like watching Fox's X-Men Dark Phoenix.
Gameplay:
-Stunlocks, there are loads of common basic enemies that can stun you, even halfway through an attack, heal, or skill animation. Stuns stack, you can get stunned before the stun animation is done and before there's a window to dodge out of the next attack. You can not stun enemies out of their attacks like in Remnant 1 or any other Souls type game.
-The floating enemies, robots on the Nerud and triangles on Yeasha, are uninspired boring nothings that belong in Destiny 2.
-Aberrations; there are many times through the game where a normal enemy or special unit is designated as a miniboss with a red corruption/glitch effect that sometimes does nothing other than make it a miniboss and sometimes shoots energy orbs of debuffs and elemental status at you with tracking, AOE and cast spam. I guess it's explained as the root corruption of the labyrinth leaking into the worlds? The effect and its energy attacks are dumb and look out of place in every world except the one it's never used in, the one it supposedly comes from, the Labyrinth. It's also lame and lazy to give normal enemies boss sized health and damage and call them a miniboss, yall didn't even give them animations to go with the corruption effect/attacks, they are 100% regular enemies doing nothing different from their normal version.
-Bosses, some good Souls bosses but most Remnant 2 bosses are very large arena types with ground and energy highlights that feel more like an MMO event than the Souls bosses of Remnant 1. Only a few lame bosses, they're the special units with a bigger model and more health.

Updates can be a bit iffy if you don't have an Epic account to link to your Steam.  One such update broke online for me until I made a dummy Epic account, linked it for less than 5 minutes, and then unlinked it again.  Until I gave in and did that, trying to switch my world to online or friends-only would immediately crash me to main menu.  I haven't had problems since, however, and they claim to have fixed the root issue in a recent patch.  I can only assume the root issue is Epic Servers being as Epic Servers tend to be.

If you want to play in offline or have no problems having and linking an Epic account, this shouldn't matter to you.  Outside of patch-specific connection weirdness, this is a better version of Remnant: From the Ashes.  However, I can't properly review the offline experience, as I learned my lesson from getting bodied by Remnant 1 bosses in solo and I didn't even try this time around; it's been with friends exclusively.  Beyond that, they took the formula that worked last time, iterated, polished, and presented the world again.  It's a nice nostalgia trip if you particularly liked Remnant 1; you can see how worlds changed after your last character finished going through and committing atrocities in them in the name of performing a raid on a lighthouse on Earth.  There's some hints at what became of characters, others return wholesale, and it all comes together to a point where I feel like you may legitimately be missing out on content if you're jumping into the series at this stage.

I feel the dungeons might be the game's strongest point.  Moreso than the first game (at least moreso than I remember), the optional dungeons have a number of puzzles gating off optional content.  They vary in obscurity, ranging from "what symbol do I put in here" to "if I shoot this barrel, it may bridge the gap in between two wires, temporarily completing the circuit!"  My main complaint on this front is the inspect mechanic has never not felt like bullshit.  There's no strong indication that an item needs to be inspected or interacted with in the inspect window for progression.  This led to a frustrating moment where I knew an object was a key I needed to progress, but my character wouldn't utilize it at all, leaving me trying other things for way too long.  I even thought to inspect it, but found nothing until I finally gave in, looked it up, and found out that while I was technically right, the key wasn't recognized as a key until I inspected it and maneuvered the camera to a VERY finicky location that prompted me to press a button to turn my key into a key.

This is a tentative recommend.  I'm enjoying my time with it and it's difficult to describe the sheer joy I felt when my melee build finally got the equipment it needed to click into place without ending up on a list, but I'd be lying if I said I wasn't still salty about having had to cave in and attach my email to an Epic account just to play the game that I bought on the promise of online play, and which I wouldn't have bought if there had been a "Requires Epic Account" disclaimer.

One of my favourite games!
Souls like hybrid with 3rd person shooter and elements of procedural generation for maps make for an interesting time. Even better with friends.

I suspect it's better in co-op than solo, but it's a hard sell considering all the better coop games on the market.

The gameplay quickly devolves into an exhausting slog on par with Daikatana. Most of the enemies are flying and all enemies input read, causing enemies to dodge midair when you aim at them. Remember how fun those brain slug infected elves were to kill in Remnant 1? That's completely missing from the game, with all enemies being some combination of aim-trainer "hit the white cube to kill" or teleporting flying creature that shoots homing projectiles.

Leveling weapons is a nightmare, given how stingy the game is with scrap. The gameplay loop necessitates a serious amount of grinding for basic upgrade materials and currency. As such, you get forced into simplistic builds because it's just too damn expensive to upgrade a new weapon from scratch.

If you played Remnant 1, then you know not to expect a story. Thankfully, you can just skip through all the painful dialog. Blah blah blah last human settlement blah blah blah the root is a threat to all worlds but somehow not the humans with quantum immortality running around looting tombs and massacring gods. Italian comics published in Heavy Metal have more coherent plots.

All in all, it's a 5/10 game carried by the gorgeous environments, rewarding exploration, and some clever puzzles but finds itself completely sabotaged by its worst failings. Combat, menus, UI, and character progression are laughably bad.

It is perhaps true to say that no mistakes are forever etched in stone for the stone into which Remnant 2 was carved has itself been transmuted offering a message of hope to those who have ever erred in their judgement. If you played and liked Remnant: From the Ashes, then this is more of that with a touch more polish. I also frequently see the devs in the Discussions actually communicating with people about upcoming changes, features, and bugfixes, which warms my heart.

[b][i]The replay value is extremely high due to the game's world being randomized every time you reroll.[/i][/b]


TLDR: It's exactly how a successor should be done. Gameplay wise not all too much changes, but simply better in almost every aspect and deepening the core mechanics. More and better puzzles and secrets. The build possibilities are deepened very much with up to 132 class combinations (12 classes which can be combined into a dual class with different effects depending on your first pick), more weapons, more skills, more rings and ring slots, more amulets to choose from and so on.

It's still Dark Souls with guns and some bosses only have adds in certain stages (not like in the first game where almost every boss had adds the whole fight, with the exception of the DLC-Bosses).

[b][u]Story[/u][/b]
As in Remnant - From the Ashes the Root are still the main threat in the story, but due to some random and unforeseen interactions with the world stone you also end up in different worlds with their own problems and factions.

[b][u]Gameplay[/u][/b]
While the gameplay still mostly revolves around combat with your Estus flask (relics called hearts), ammo restricted long and hand gun and melee weapon. The soulslike typical dodge roll also returns (determined by your armor's encumberance).
Every enemy type has a different move set and different weak spots. Like the first game with enough practice the whole game can be beaten without getting hit once.
Ammo and relics can be refilled by interacting with the world stone or a crystal bonfire but doing so respawns - in Dark Souls fashion - every non-Boss enemy.

[b][u]Items[/u][/b]
You have four armor slots, three weapon slots (long gun, hand gun, melee), three mutators (which are equipped on your weapons and change their behaviour, e.g. %-chance to refill ammo on hit or % damage per round missing in the magazine), four rings, one amulet, up to three different weapon mods, one relic and three different passive stat bonuses on your relic (e.g. more health, more damage mitigation, faster reloads, higher critical strike chance).
This time there are already more than 50 guns (more to come with updates and DLCs) which are vastly different in their designs and functions. These weapons range from classical repeating or levering rifles to fully automatic ones to bows and crossbows and sci-fi guns which shoot gas, lightning, fire or black holes.
The amount of melee weapons got bumped up to more than 40 and also got very creative ones like a light sabre, an atomic powered hammer or magical throwing axe and so on.
Weapons can be upgraded to deal up to three times their base damage, mutators can be upgraded in their power and unlock a new additional effect upon reaching their maximum level.
For balance sake armor cannot be upgraded and leads to you being able to swap to new or other armor without having to upgrade it to the previous armor's level.
The weapon mods are skills for your weapon and can embue your shots with fire or poison, summon minions, grant auras or shields and much more.

[b][u]Character Customization[/u][/b]
When creating a character you have a small editor for your character. You can change gender, pick from some predefined faces, choose scars if you want to, and pick a colour for your hair, eyes, facial hair and/or makeup.

[b][u]Build Customization[/u][/b]
You have up to 132 class combinations to choose from (12 classes, you get to pick two and get a different prime perk depending on your first pick), multiple armors sets, 4 ring slots, 1 amulet, 2 active class' skills, 3 weapon mods, 3 weapon mutators, and are capped at 85 trait points.
While the trait points are capped this time, their changes are bigger and you need to priorize their effects, like health, stamina, stamina regeneration, dodge distance, weapon range, etc.

[b][u]Bosses[/u][/b]
At the time of writing this review there are 30 bosses. All of these bosses are very different to fight due to vastly different move sets, boss sizes, arenas which can also change during the encounter. Somes Bosses have some adds during certain phases and the boss' move set and behaviour change depending on your actions and their health. On harder difficulties the bosses also gain some mutator which change their behaviour and/or add some skills.
Additionally there are random minibosses which are stronger default enemies with even more mutators to choose from to spice up the experience.

You usually encounter up to half of the bosses during a playthrough.

[b][u]Difficulty and game modes[/u][/b]
The game has four difficulties to offer (Survivor, Veteran, Nightmare, Abomination). The hardest difficulty is locked behind beating the final boss the first time.
The game offers Story Mode and Adventure. Story Mode is - surprisingly - the story (which sub-stories also change per playthrough) and Adventure let's reroll 3 of 5 Story regions (the 2 Story regions which can't be played in Adventure are not randomized).

Remnant 2 is Dark Souls with guns & overall its a very fun and challenging game. Character classes (Archetypes), areas, boss fights and weapons all feel very unique. The ability to switch between your campaign run and an adventure run is also a great quality of life feature that allows you to farm levels, materials and loot perpetually. 

There are a few things in the game that annoyed the hell out of me, such as the worst gimmick boss ever the Labyrinth Sentinel & a certain parkour area that took me an hour to get past because jumping and vaulting can be trash sometimes. Im also not a fan of the changing worlds system. Basically theres 3 worlds and each gets randomily generated except for the starting/ending points which are linked. Now this system does add a bunch of replay-ability but the issue is if your trying to get specific loot from specific encounters you may end up clearing half the world before realizing your world didnt roll with the dungeons you needed and now you have to replay the entire thing again and pray that you get the dungeons you need. With that said the good still heavily out weighed the bad.

I highly recommend giving this game a try if your a fan of the souls games or are just looking for a challenging rpg experience.  Rated 9/10

The amount of content is the key to every roguelike game. With a plethora of levels, puzzles, and bosses to choose from, the game could generate a unique journey with mysteries to be uncovered.  

 

Unfortunately, many of the roguelikes out there failed to deliver a meaningfully lengthy yet varied gameplay. What they usually do is just repeat early-game enemies and bosses (maybe do a reskin or have some minor tweaks to their move set here and there) in the late game. By doing so, the playtime is artificially lengthened, and people are misled to think that it is a great game of value. But most of the content is just grinding on the repetitive levels and monsters. Making the game unnecessarily grindy. 

 

Remnants 2, on the other hand, suffers no such issue. The fundamental reason is that the contents crafted by the developer are just so abundant and it is not possible to be depleted fully in the first playthrough (in fact, not even close). The puzzles are creative, the bosses are well-designed, and the challenges are fun in general. And there are countless of secrets well-hidden and waiting to be found. (The best secret digging gameplay I have seen in an action game). To summarize, it is a first-person shooter with roguelike randomness and a souls-like combat mechanic. If you like souls-like or roguelikes. You should definitely get this masterpiece, or you will be missing out.
