TL;DR: It's Remnant, too - but not too Remnant.

I could say the standard stuff about what I like, but it would end up sounding a bit games journalist-ish, and then everyone would wonder if I'd managed to get out of the first zone yet.

Overall, this is a very good game, though some aspects annoy me.  

+ Very very good character customization.  This allows people to have very customized setups that fulfill various roles when playing co-op, while also allowing a variety of approaches in terms of solo play.
+ Enemy variety is very cool to see, and quite well done.
+ Gunplay and melee both feel good to use.
+ Very nicely-crafted different areas, each of which is very, very different. N'Erud is a great example, as are several others.

But...

- The game isn't great in terms of performance, at least on PC.  Still playable of course, but gets some major FPS and performance loss on pretty good hardware.
- Each of the areas are beautifully done, but having them be different, with different quests and a different layout each time is both a good and a bad thing.  
It's a good thing in that it offers a fresh experience of the same areas, with a different overworld, and different stages of progression, and different dungeons each time. But, it's a bad thing in that there is no real feeling of being able to explore every nook and cranny of an area and call it explored - only explored for this runthrough.  It feels as if one is visiting one parallel version of that world each time, which is... kind of cool, but it should have been explained in game somehow.
- The writing and plot is... basic at best.  Honestly, the first game was about on par; great environments and good souls-like gameplay, but mediocre storytelling.

Honestly, it's a pretty good game overall, despite my nitpicks.  You're not going to buy it due to the deep and existential writing, but for being able to get and use weird and cool weapons on a wide variety of things that want to eat your face, in a variety of interesting places.  Between the items you can equip and the classes you can equip as primary & secondary, a player gets many, many options for how they want to play.

My final score is 8.5/10.  If they hire a good writer for their next game to help tie everything together, so much the better.

I had some fun with the game, I played much like how I did before in the first game which I sunk in a rather ungodly amount of hours, this game is almost better in every way, visually and mechanically, with bosses being for the most part, interesting. It was kind of fun looking at various pieces of equipment and rings and trying to get weird builds that completely change the way you play, like decreasing health while using rings that apply shields at low health, made in an interesting game of cat and mouse. Regeneration builds were fun, and when you maximized to struggle on the highest difficulty, it was, for the most part, fun. 

I quickly plateaued, and hit the max trait points, and then it started to get monotonous. New rings, weapons, or armor weren't as interesting, and if they felt useless at least if I could continue leveling up, I would continue to feel like I was being rewarded for playing, like it was with the previous one.

With a build set, and nothing really to strive towards, I just sped through to beat the game to get it over with, and move on. I don't think I can recommend this one too much, you'll pretty quickly hit the top and have nowhere to go. I understand the reason for removing uncapped trait points and I disagree with that design philosophy. Continuous positive reinforcement was what hooked me into the original, made new traits always a joy to find, no matter how minuscule their effect may be. It would have also encouraged me to max out every class so I could combine all the class perks together. It's fun to get stronger. It's fun to be rewarded. Even helping against bosses you've already beaten were rewards in themselves until you're maxed out. Now it's monotonous.

I don't think they'll be changing it. But I don't think I'll be getting back into it unless they do. Ahh well. Guess that's how the cookie crumbles.

If you liked the first game, you'll like this one. If you didn't like the first game, you can probably still handle this one if you're in need of a co-op shooter. I like the archetype system, and some of the guns are neat. I genuinely enjoy finding some of the secrets while exploring, and I actually find myself mildly interested in the story this time around. But without someone asking me to play I doubt I would continue.

The same slow, clunky movement is back, as well as the tedium and frustration that often accompanies procedurally generated levels. During a couple boss fights, my co-op partner's game would freeze and crash, leaving me to fend for myself and leaving them without the loot drops. 

The map is actually usable this time around but the number of irritating design issues push my patience beyond its limit at least twice a session. Why do I need to backtrack through another load zone and then back again to find the answer to a small puzzle that I need in order to progress, the completion of which again takes me BACK to the original zone...? Why does the map indicate a wide pathway to an area that I've already been, yet if I try to take that route I start to choke and die from the out-of-bounds mechanic? While we're at it, why are the checkpoint map and in-game map completely different so that I can't tell where I need to go in order to explore an undiscovered area? 

Remnant 2 is an improvement over the previous entry, but an overall mediocre third person shooter that I would recommend to someone if it's on sale and they need a decent co-op experience. 

If you want to play an actual soulslike game that isn't made by FromSoft themselves, check out Wo Long Fallen Dynasty instead; combat is satisfying and fun, and it's got a much better co-op system than Dark Souls.

Remnant 2: A Masterpiece!

I can't even begin to express how utterly thrilled I am with Remnant 2. As a devoted fan of the original, my expectations were sky-high, and I'm elated to say that this sequel has not only met but exceeded them in every conceivable way!

From the moment I fired up Remnant 2, I was captivated by the stunning graphics. The attention to detail in every environment is mind-blowing, and the character models are so lifelike that it's easy to become emotionally invested in their journeys. The art team behind this game deserves a standing ovation!

The gameplay mechanics have been finely tuned to perfection. Combat feels even more visceral and satisfying, with a vast array of weapons and abilities that cater to every playstyle. The addition of new enemy types and challenging boss battles keeps the adrenaline pumping, and the level design is a true work of genius, offering a sense of exploration that's second to none.

But what truly sets Remnant 2 apart is its storytelling. The narrative is gripping, with twists and turns that had me on the edge of my seat throughout the entire game. The characters are beautifully developed, and their interactions are filled with depth and emotion. The choices you make along the way have a real impact on the outcome, adding layers of replayability that I can't wait to dive into.

And let's not forget the incredible soundtrack, which sets the mood perfectly and enhances the overall experience.

To top it all off, the developers have shown an unwavering commitment to their community. Regular updates, bug fixes, and a clear roadmap for future content ensure that Remnant 2 will continue to evolve and provide countless hours of enjoyment.

In conclusion, Remnant 2 is an absolute triumph, a testament to the dedication and passion of its creators. It's a must-play for anyone who appreciates exceptional storytelling, immersive gameplay, and breathtaking visuals. Thank you, developers, for delivering a sequel that has left me absolutely awestruck. This is gaming at its finest, and I can't wait to see what the future holds for Remnant 2!

The gun play is really smooth which is great, but it's hindered by a gross weapon scarcity. My experience is basically being stuck with the trash default gun for the first 6 - 7 hours, and the few I have picked up aren't much better. They're either slightly better than the default, or have some kind of weird jank where the feel of the default gun is better than the newer weapon. Weapons also tend to either be extremely well hidden to the point even a thorough search of the map is unlikely to discover them, so you will be limited to pre-determined boss drops if any even drop at all. Frankly, I'm surprised some just didn't end up going entirely undiscovered for years after release. 

The boss design for the most part is very well done with multiple being puzzle boss fights. There are a few stinkers though. Some bosses will fill all available space within the room with homing exploding projectiles, while possessing a very aggressive melee moveset. While some puzzle bosses will not have a reasonable solution in sight. Specifically, The Chimney's roots midway down the gauntlet.

In normal levels the enemies do materialize out of thin air and often behind you, so you cannot plan out how to take on a room. Some bosses and enemies do tend to be bullet sponges as well. With how well many things are hidden, and with how some boss fights are designed you'll probably need to have a guide open, or someone who has already beaten the game along with you.

Don't go into this expecting a looter shooter. All pick ups are resources or rings/ mods with small power ups. Stuff like +1% health, or a conditional regen like 5% lifesteal up to 50% of max HP.

I can't say much about the story, but the NPC merchant dialogue is outright annoying and will either force you to wait for their animation to catch up, or lock you into chat when you just wanted to see what they're selling instead of listening to them complain about you breathing air near them.

TL;DR:
The good:
Most bosses are well designed
World design is creative and genuinely interesting
No AAA baby hand holding and no cluttered interface
Smooth gun play


The bad:
Barely any guns to use
Open world surface levels feel empty, lots of aimless walking
Occasional bullet sponge enemies/ bosses
Occasional over designed bosses
Awful NPC dialogue that also obstructs shop UI access

I'll start this off saying this; I was a huge fan of Remnant From The Ashes, with around 500 hours logged, and 100s of clears on campaign, it was the first game I started speedrunning, and was one of the best shooters I ever played.

Normally there is a TL;DR at the end, but I'm putting it here. Good/Bad at the end.

TL;DR: if you were a fan of the first Remnant, just buy the game. It's the same game, but more refined, polished and with double the content, maybe even triple.

With that out of the way, the rest of the review [i](hopefully limited on spoilers.)[/i] 

[h1]Presentation[/h1]

The game, like the first, starts you out in a short tutorial section; however this time you have a team of 3 others with you. It is a very short section, with a small boss fight that immediately hammers home just how important patience and dodging is. The NPCs also regularly introduce you to the friendly fire mechanic to prepare you for Co-op play, because I have yet to go more than 5 minutes without being shot in the back of the head. Fortunately there isn't anything in my skull I need.

Visually the game is breathtaking. It runs on Unreal 5, so this isn't a surprise at all, however what flabbergasts me is how absolutely gorgeous every item is in the game. You can now fully inspect the models and they are [i]stunning[/i]. I am convinced Gunfire has the best art team in the business. I don't know how you manage to make 100+ rings all look not only unique but incredible visually, but damn, they did it.

Maps are beautiful as ever. The worlds were my favorite part about Rem 1, and my lord does this game ramp it up. The areas are oozing with subtle story telling, and feel very real and lived in despite being completely alien. Every corner has been nothing short of a pure joy to explore.

On the note of exploring, most areas have a ton of secrets or puzzles, which the puzzles are absolutely incredibly well done. Solving riddles, deducting codes, extrapolation of incomplete data, the puzzles are fantastic, I'm not a very smart girl, so I needed a wiki for a fair bit, but anyone of average intelligence will eventually get it. Well, except [i]that one puzzle...[/i]

Anyways, you have multiple worlds.

[b]N'erud[/b] - A desolated alien wasteland filled with robots and abominations; I love this place despite the pain it caused me, it feels so lonely and it's so easy to get lost in, exploring it has been a lot of fun, getting the items I wanted, not so much.

[b]Yaesha[/b] - Yaesha returns; and I still hate traversing it, even more here now that the game has puzzles and now I'm agitated by the hostile truffles rolling into me for 50% of my health, while having my intelligence insulted because I always skipped family pictionary night. Place is friggin' breath-takingly beautiful as it always has been.

[b]Labyrinth[/b] - Ah yes, Cubes. But now fueled by hate. I love the area but I've spent so much of my time there I have developed Cubophobia. This was my bane during my Hardcore Apocalypse runs. Every Reset was here. It's not even hard. I just really suck at Rubik's Cubes and pattern recognition.

[b]Losomn[/b] - This might need it's own section; Holy. Hell. This might be my favorite area in gaming as a whole. Victorian London, with british elves to fight?! A CASTLE?! WITH A MILLION SECRETS?! AN ASYLUM!! And the best character to boot (Faelin, my beloved...) What an incredible experience Losomn is as a whole. I think I can live without Bloodborne on PC because of this area.

Anything more would be spoilers, so I'll leave that for you to find.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]

Okay, done gushing over the visuals. Guns, yes, combat. It's the exact same as Remnant 1. But, like, better.

There is about the same amount of weapons, but they're mostly different, though a lot of fan favorites return, and the new ones are ABSOLUTELY AWESOME! They really went a long way in polishing the already excellent gunplay, the addition of Bows has made every combat encounter so much damn fun, I have 100%'d the game nearly, and I just run around sticking idiots with arrows, I can't STOP and I need someone to HELP ME. 

My only complaint about the gunplay is [b]Mods[/b] are much less interesting and even less effective than they used to be, they are still helpful, some are quite strong, but a majority are easily forgotten, obvious exception being Blood Draw. I love shooting an idiot with a harpoon, and dragging them to the barrel of my shotgun. Better than therapy, honestly.

[b]Mutators[/b] largely replace the Armor Sets that were present in the base game. These are placed on weapons and are Upgradable. This is a good change, I can look like the deranged hobo I was born to be without losing out on cool stats like Infinite Ammo, Bleed Bullets, I Just Crit More Bro, and I Just Crit More Bro, But On A Tuesday At 7:33PM After Eating Taco Bell.

[b]Classes[/b] are a thing now too. There is 10. There is technically 11, but if you play without a walkthrough, there is only 10. You'll never find the 11th. It's not real, it can't hurt you. (It can and will hurt you.)

Each class has 3 skills to pick from, 4 passives that gain power as you level to the cap of 10 per class and a Prime Perk, which is an ultra powerful passive, you can only have 1 of these at a time. 

You can mix and match 2 classes. This is how you break the game and clear HC-Apoc with a +3 Huntmaster M1. Skills are useful for filling gaps where gear can't, or compensating for bad plays, or to show off how many times you can die in a boss fight. Mine is 13 times, I hope nobody beats that because it wasn't intentional, I just never had a Bop-it as a kid.

Now that I'm done talking about the good, let's talk about the source of my androgenetic alopecia; Rings. Jesus, they look amazing but there is so many. I know what ring I want but I can't find a drop of water in a damned ocean. This game seriously needs a search function because god there is so many rings. Ringnant 2,000, because that's how many rings you have after the first 20 hours. I know you can favorite rings, but that goes away after you restart the game.

Please Devs, let us search for keywords like Weakspot, Bleed, Bulwark, etc... 

[h1]Audio[/h1]

Normally don't care. This is an exception. The music is so damn good, the sound is so damn good, absolutely nothing to complain about here, go enjoy the OST, it's great. The Huntress is my favorite.

[h1]TL;DR - Ringnant: Ultimate Ring Edition[/h1]

[b]Good[/b]
+Extremely satisfying gameplay all around.
+Absurd build variety.
+Progression is good, despite some rough spots with resources and scaling.
+Awesome enemies.
+Some of the best boss fights in the genre.
+Concerningly accurate hitboxes.
+The best level design I've seen in many, many years.
+Incredible replayability.
+Excellent visuals.
+Superb Audio.
+Just buy the game at this point
+Decent story, though cryptic.
+Lots of puzzles and secrets.
+Lots of upcoming DLC.
+Games actually complete and not selling cut content as DLC or MTX.
+You can fight British elves.

[b]Bad[/b]
-So many rings, we need a search or sort option, I can't take it any more.
-Co-op is very janky, and often times the latency will kill you, if the ridiculous damage scaling doesn't.
-Performance issues, namely on 30xx series nVidia cards.
-Cass never shuts up. Just let me buy your garbage, please. (Timebased RNG shop, no premium currency crap though, just an annoying NPC.)

Picked it up on the advice of a friend, and this game has grabbed me by the brain stem. It's satisfying, fantastic fun with friends, and the devs actually listen to the community. It's fantatstic.

It can be incredibly hard if you want it to be (especially on higher difficulties), but the lower difficulties are totally workable (and I say this as someone who's a complete souls-like noob), and the penalty for death is minimal. The same friend who got me into Remnant tried to get me into elden ring, but I'm not the biggest fan of the "drive-by the spot where you died and run like crazy" gameplay loop.
In this game, you get respawned at the spot where you last checked in, and all your enemies respawn too, but you don't lose anything. It's fantastic. You have the freedom to experiment with builds and do weird things, and the game doesn't punish you for it. Speaking of which, the build diversity is excellent, you can find all sorts of weird, wacky, and fun builds to smack enemies around with.

Half of the boss fights would begin with me thinking that it's literally impossible, and then 10-30 minutes later, I'd have learned what I needed to and had it beat no problem. It's the same feeling of playing Dark Souls for the first time back in the day; you can try again and again and learn more every time, and that's something that more modern Souls-like games have really been lacking in my opinion. 2023 was a tough year to compete in gaming, but I would like to say that I had some of the most fun with Remnant II. It is one of the most responsive games. Each choice a player makes in-game or strategizing with their characters is given explicit feedback that feels impactful and important. And the more you play, the more the layers of that character building slowly unravel themselves.

Over time, you are given so many tools that you begin to develop a generalized intelligence of the game's systems, and utilizing all the weapons, armor, amulets, and rings, not to mention mods and mutators, is so rewarding.

When you reach this moment is when you realize just how deliberate and intentional the game is.Everything feels like it was iterated on and playtested to its limit. These are not just good ideas, but ones implemented rationally and effectively to produce good gameplay.

It's such a solid experience. If you enjoy games like this, and especially if you have willing friends, this might be the action cooperative experience to beat for some time.

Remnant is often descried as a "soulslike with guns". This is a deeply unfair description, as someone who dislikes souls-likes and LOVES both Remnant games. It does have souls' strengths of challenging gameplay (so you can't get cocky), and learning boss' attack patterns. What it DOESN'T have is the obtuse UI issues or reliance on janky inputs for difficulty that are a mainstay of the genre.
In addition to this, Remnant II doubles down on the first game's biggest strengths:
-Multiple unique, gorgeous worlds to explore, each with their own stories and lore.
-Huge amounts of replayability with variations in both the maps, storyline, and events that can occur in eahc world. Doubly so because some of these have multiple possible outcomes. 
-Fantastic hidden easter eggs throughout the game; including events behind secret walls, and environmental features that reveal hidden rewards under the right circumstances.
-Immense build customisability. Between unlockable weapons, gear, classes, and traits there are so many options for different builds, whether you're playing on normal difficulties to do random fun things, or trying to optimise for Apocalypse mode.

DLC update: The obvious content of the DLC is fairly neutral, it's more of the same, worth the money, but nothing to write home about. The additional hard-to-find elements are a really nice touch though, if you put in the work, there are more great hidden gems to keep an eye out for.

With the inclusion of the First DLC, I can summarize the experience of Remnant 2 as one of the best co-op game of 2023.

Although there might still be some minor performance issue due to the complexity of UE5 and optimization, the current version of Remnant 2 outshines many of the big titles this year in terms of fun, depth and variety. Even after collecting all the achievements, the structure of the game encourage subsequent playthroughs. To the point that you can just say "why not? let's just go for another run" or "another co-op session" and the game remains enjoyable.

I also like how the game toned down from 100% procedural generation and settle with 'randomized injectibles' where you randomly get a selection of crafted section of each maps instead of 100 AI generated content. In the current landscape of procedural generation games, I heavily prefer this kind of randomness in a sense that you still get a package of crafted stage which enable players to detect pattern and learn, instead of just accepting the 100% chaos of randomness.

Although I highly recommend it as a co-op game, it is still 100% enjoyable playing solo. Do not miss out.

This game represents the current pinnacle of 3rd-Person Shooter Dark Souls. It's wrapped in a skin that's best described as a post-apocalyptic inter-dimensional fantasy sci-fi romp. If the setting sounds like a convoluted mouthful or an outright confusing mess even, that's because it is. The over-arching main story comes across as superficial, generic, and even cringey at times, however it's juxtaposed with surprisingly deep and well-written side-stories that are embedded in the lore and the somewhat tedious NPC dialogs found within the individual worlds. These 'worlds' act as the games main levels, the procedural combinations of which, provide endless replayabilty. But questionable story exposition choices aside, everything else on offer here is utterly sublime: Super tight gun-play and melee combat, gratifyingly deep build-crafting and RPG mechanics meshed with a ridiculous amount of items and secrets to uncover, a staggering number of satisfyingly complex puzzles to solve... the list goes on. Remnant 2 is top-tier soul-food for the souls-like connoisseur. A must play. Also, my personal favorite for several Steam Awards 2023. ;)

Mods fixed that for me, but after the new update the game can't even be launched. This isn't a new issue. This is an ONGOING and UNRESOLVED issue.

Edit:
I've managed to get the game working, by essentially double uninstalling the game; Delete the remnants 2 folder physically, any trace you can find, then uninstall from steam. Re-download, try to run and fail- Verify, find one missing file, run and fail- By some grace clicking the play button non stop actually worked.

Edit 2: With fixes out and changes, the game is back to working as mostly intended. The review can be positive now, but only as long as it continues working.

Remnant II builds upon what the first game had and makes it so much better.  Remnant: From the Ashes was a great game but it did have some slight issues like running in and or out of combat would always deplete your stamina, causing world traversal to be a chore, classes didn't really have any set identity other than the armor and the skill set with it, your starting weapons and your first mod, and overall the boatload of traits that you never really used as some didn't seem useful at all.    Remnant II fixed those issues and made each class have 3 separate abilities you unlock with a set Prime Perk and passive perks.  Prime Perks are for whatever your primary class is and only one can be active due to how powerful they are.  For example, the Handler class has the ability to revive themselves with their dog using a relic charge, or another teammate using their relic, the other downside of it is it only heals you to half health but it helps you or the other person to focus on fighting rather than reviving as long as that perk is off cooldown.  The variety of weapons and modifications give the player extreme freedom to express themselves not only with armor and skills but even their weapons and what mods they use.  The Bosses in Remnant II still keep their alternate kills to give different rewards and are still extremely fun and more challenging to the player.  With the First DLC as well it has been a joy playing through it and I'll update this review for each DLC that comes out and give a spoiler free review of it when I beat them.

Remnant 1 and 2 are often described as 'Dark Souls with guns' - while there is some merit to this statement, the games very much stand as their own thing. The gun play is excellent, the game play is challenging (with extra rewards for engaging in harder difficulties and perma-death mode), the co-op is a hell of a lot of fun and the new archetype system in 2 makes character progression feel rewarding and exciting. There are puzzles but these are almost all optional if that's not your thing. There's only one that I can think of that isn't and calling it a 'puzzle' is an overstatement (the solution is literally in a book 30secs away). The levels/maps have certain set piece locations which are connected by procedurally generated areas, the side dungeons are also randomly generated from a ready made pool. This makes each run different and keep the game throwing unexpected things at you for longer. Eventually you will see it all of course but that takes a while.

As far as I'm concerned this is game of the year 2023 for me. I almost never write reviews but this one really deserves the positive shout out!

At the time of writing this review the game is 30% in the Autumn sale which is an absolute steal. If you're really not sure, my advice would be to pick up Remnant 1 (I think that goes on sale very cheap these days) and see how you get on. If you enjoy 1 then there's a very high chance you will like 2. If you don't like 1 then at least you won't have lost much.

Can't wait to see the rest of the DLC and what Gunfire Games has planned for the future.

First: Yes, I have played all souls games including Elden Ring, and I enjoyed and finished all of them. I am a big fan of challenging but fair and fun games.

However, If you are coming here for a souls experience I should say that after finishing this game all I got was that the devs only understood "dark souls is a hard game" from the souls series. This game attempts to imitate something that its devs do not understand.

I'll start with the good: the visuals are very good. Although they don't tell a good story like in the souls games, they are visually pleasing.

that's where the good ends.

here are the bad things:
quest markers, and the map in general are abysmal. The worst I've ever experienced in any game. I believe this has been intentionally designed poorly to waste your time (by making you go through the same areas multiple times to find the damn main/side quests). Way too many times I randomly got to an area which was locked behind some random sh*t I didn't have (and no, not on my way to some quest, but on a long ass diversion). If you don't want to guide the player at least you should let them roam around freely (maybe with the rare "you need x to get into here"). Not respecting your time is the big sin number 1 of this game.

The second big sin of this game is input reading (i.e. NPC's instant reaction to your clicks). it is as old as the gaming industry itself (MK2 comes to mind), and is a cheap way to make NPCs of a game look "smart". However, it is nothing but frustrating for the players. It kills a big portion of the fun. Weirdly enough, I think this input reading not only has made the NPCs annoying, it also has created a notable delay in how dodges  and other actions are executed, which if you have played any of the souls game you would understand how much worse they would be if your inputs were delayed all the time.

The 3rd sin of this game is the poor boss design. I will try to avoid spoilers but I will mention the bad design choices here. Take the last boss for instance (this is just an example, applies to many other bosses), beside input reading, it is a giant monster which moves all over the place faster than I could move my mice.  Entire battlefield was filled with random stuff, so it was hard to follow it around and random projectiles spawn and hit you from other places on the field (which because of all the random stuff are hard to see). Keep in mind that all of this is happening on a relatively small battlefield which heavily limits your movement. When you go to phase 2, it gets much worse. Some attacks are intentionally delayed (the boss holds them for a few seconds before unleashing) and some execute faster than any boss in the souls series with little to no visual indicators. The boss goes back and forth between the two phases in an instance after some point which is also horribly designed since it makes it impossible to dodge some attacks that are mid air while the phase shifts happen (yes, the phase shifts are horribly timed)! I killed most bosses the first attempt, but a few were very frustrating for the wrong reasons!

And the last but not the least of the sins: The progression in this game is horrible. I had a set of armor that I got at the very beginning, guess how many times I got a good armor set or piece to replace my starter armor with (I did the main story and a lot of the side dungeons)? Zero! None! why the hell would you add armor slots if your game has zero armor variety besides the original classes? Oh yes, we are imitating some game without understanding it... This also applies to weapons, although at least you have 2-3 options per weapon type there (which is still abysmal for a shooter game).

Summary: this game imitates souls games without understanding it. It severely mistakes "challenging" with "annoying/frustrating". I do not recommend this game, since it does not respect your time. I would not write a review for this game, if it wasn't for the hype it gets and truly does not deserve. I wish someone would tell me these problems before I started playing it.

I can confidently say that Remnant 2 has not only met but exceeded my expectations, showcasing a remarkable evolution from its predecessor, Remnant: From the Ashes. The improvements are so substantial that it feels like a whole new gaming experience, making it an absolute must-play for fans of the original and newcomers alike.

1. Visual Marvel:
Remnant 2 takes the visual fidelity to a whole new level. The environments are breathtaking, with stunning details that immerse you in a world teeming with life and danger. The lighting effects are nothing short of phenomenal, enhancing the overall atmosphere and creating a more immersive and visually captivating experience.

2. Streamlined Gameplay:
One of the most notable improvements is the refined and streamlined gameplay mechanics. The controls feel more responsive, and the combat has been fine-tuned to perfection. The fluidity of movement, combined with a diverse range of weapons and abilities, makes each encounter a thrilling and dynamic experience. The balance between challenge and reward is spot-on, keeping you engaged without becoming frustrating.

3. Expanded Lore and Storytelling:
Remnant 2 takes the intriguing lore of the first game and expands it into a more immersive narrative. The world-building is top-notch, and the story unfolds in a way that keeps you invested from start to finish. The addition of new characters and factions adds depth to the overall narrative, providing a richer storytelling experience for players who love to uncover the mysteries of the game world.

4. Enhanced Co-op Experience:
The co-op aspect, which was already a strong point in the original Remnant, has been enhanced even further. The game encourages cooperative play with seamless drop-in/drop-out multiplayer, making it easier than ever to team up with friends or join forces with other players. The synergy between team members is crucial, and the shared victories feel incredibly rewarding.

5. Diverse and Challenging Enemies:
The variety of enemies in Remnant 2 is impressive, each requiring a different strategy to overcome. The AI has been noticeably improved, making battles more unpredictable and satisfying. From hulking monstrosities to nimble and elusive foes, every encounter keeps you on your toes and contributes to the overall excitement of the gameplay.

6. Expanded Arsenal:
The weapon and armor options have been expanded, offering players even more choices to tailor their playstyle. The addition of new mods and abilities adds strategic depth, allowing for more creative and personalized character builds. Experimenting with different loadouts becomes an addictive aspect of the game, adding to its overall replay value.

Remnant 2 stands as a shining example of how a sequel should improve upon its predecessor. The developers have not only listened to player feedback but have also demonstrated a clear commitment to delivering a gaming experience that exceeds expectations. If you enjoyed the first Remnant or are a fan of action-packed shooters with deep lore and cooperative gameplay, Remnant 2 is an absolute gem that deserves a spot in your gaming library.

If you're on the fence about getting this game, I'd say just give it a shot. The story isn't really a shining part of this game, so there's nothing that would keep you playing it if you didn't enjoy the gameplay. If you end up enjoying it, you're in for a treat, because the replayability of Remnant 2 is insane. There's two versions of every main area, and there are a variety of dungeons that randomly generate throughout these main areas. You'll find yourself wanting to play through it again after beating the game, only to realize that you'd need to replay the story a few more times AT LEAST just to discover everything. This might be a pain if you're a completionist like me, but I, for one, enjoyed the grind.

Pretty much an improvement over the previous game in every single way. If you liked the first Remnant game, well... this is just more Remnant- but better. Couldn't recommend it more. Didn't put it down since I started playing in the early access window, pretty much.

I guess the only caution I would give, is that the game does seem to have some performance issues. I was able to get it playable by just using DLSS, but it'd be nice if it didn't require it to run smoothly, especially on above average hardware at 1080p. While I was able to get it to run fine, other's mileage may vary- that just tends to be how these things work. A few months after release and this issue still exists, where it's only really possible to get an really good frame rate by using DLSS, even on high end hardware.

Despite that one issue, and with the addition of the new Awakened King DLC, my stance hasn't changed, this game is still a big improvement over its previous and a ton of fun.

If you've played Remnant 1 and are wondering about this, ~80% of the changes are great QoL. They doubled down on puzzles/secrets in lieu of rng drops around the world, and it's worth your time to check it out.

If you're new to the game, my personal opinion is you should know two things: do not use a guide (at the start), and experiment. This game is built on discovery, secrets, and having those "WHAT!?!?" moments. If you play with a step-by-step tutorial on what to do, where to go, and how to get everything, you're going to end up with no gameplay. There is no end game; once you've unlocked everything, you're done. Its predecessor had a survival mode, but you had nothing unlocked, and while it was an enjoyable end game experience, the story, atmosphere, and thrill of the hunt is what makes Remnant stand apart. When you feel stuck or like you need a guide to make progress, then by all means---no judgment here---but do know that this is not a conventional RPG where you're trying to get super powered and then do The Thing™. Finding the super powers *is* the experience, and if you keep that in mind, you'll find yourself enjoying the iterative playthroughs, the campaign-spanning hidden quests, and feel rewarded for your time. As for experimenting, this game does a good job letting one build shine, only to take away its advantages the next fight. Keep an open mind, shuffle your loadouts when you get stuck, and enjoy the weird puzzle shooter in a souls-like world.

[h1] Remnant 2. [/h1]

• [h3] It's so good. [/h3]
A [b] "Souls-Like" [/b] game on Steam that finally deserves its place... a souls-like that does not aim to gate keep me with absurd difficulties or awful movement and combat when paired with a Keyboard\Mouse. Featuring secrets and treasures around every corner, exploring each tile set feels incredibly rewarding. A wonderful blend of looter-shooter stats and gearing to make build-making and endgame min-maxing feel diverse at every stage of your playthrough. Randomly generated world layouts to make every single player's first play-through completely different from someone else's.

Every core system of this game is incredibly well fleshed out, requiring some level of attention and knowledge from the player to help in learning build making, boss fighting, and world layouts.

• [h3] 'Dark Souls with Guns' [/h3]
As cringeworthy as this statement is these days, it does work as a description: Adding shooting to the genre really aids in the experience as a Keyboard\Mouse player, as I am always sick of the clunky movement and combat for the Standard Souls franchise. A classic gun and crosshair allow for another layer of game mastery and overall skill cap, which will be familiar to a lot of players. Remnant features a smooth and responsive gun playground for you to dodge, roll, and shoot things to your heart's content. Gun balance seems relatively well ironed out after the first few patches, and for your first few playthroughs, each gun shouldn't struggle with getting the job done until you are finally battling with Power Level 20 or Apocalypse Difficulty.

• [h3] Randomly generated dungeons and loot! [/h3]
Every playthrough will consist of five main areas. [spoiler] Yaesha, N'rud, Losomn, The Labyrinth, and Root Earth [/spoiler] as well as your main base of operations, Ward 13. Each 'world' has two main layouts, each with a set final boss. The journey towards the boss will be different in some way each time (bosses, loot, side areas, secrets, and side quests). Everything will be shifted around and repositioned on each playthrough. [u] Please understand. The game is meant to be played over and over again for full enjoyment. [/u]

• [h3] Build Engineering [/h3]
After my full time with the game, certain builds and formats saw repeated use of certain rings, and archetypes saw constant use compared to others, especially in the higher difficulties. But testing and making builds for your play style is entertaining and relatively in-depth for those willing to dig deep enough. But the topic of gear does push me towards the weakest aspect of the game, and that is in its comparison to the first game. Remnant [b] 1 [/b] Featured unique and interesting armour sets that granted bonuses depending on the amount of pieces equipped, they added just enough excitement and build diversity to make them worth looking at, but in Remnant 2 armour feels boring and thrown together poorly with nothing but a 'Weight\Armour' rating, with almost every player using either the lightest they can find or the heaviest with almost nothing in between. I truly hope armour gets more exciting down the line.

• [h3] Something for everyone [/h3]
I'll start by saying here that I don't often find myself enjoying Souls-like games for their awkward way of gatekeeping fun by locking the enjoyment behind dying to a boss 50 times over because of insane twists and absurd mechanics that one could only learn through experience, or a locked difficulty forcing you to play the game way all the time without the ability to mess around on an easier setting or without the ability to challenge yourself further. Remnant 2 offers four difficulties: [i] Survivor, Veteran, Nightmare, Apocalypse [/i]. I highly recommend starting this game on the lowest difficulty offered, especially if you want to play with friends, as the multiplayer scaling and latency can often be far too annoying to have to deal with a new mechanic on a higher difficulty. HP scaling is as follows: [i] 100%, 150%, 250%, 275% [/i] and damage scaling is: [i] 100%, 165%, 350%, 450% [/i]. As you can see, difficulties will spike your challenge dramatically, and the game itself recommends you only play on Nightmare+ if you have strong boss knowledge and build functionality. 

- 150 Hours Later
• Multiple Survivor Difficulty Runs
• Veteran, Nightmare, and Apocalypse Completion
• Hardcore Veteran Completion
• 100% achievement completion

7/10. Enjoying the game so far with a number of gripes.
I have about 100 hours in the first game and love it to death. Even 100% it. But doubt I will try the same for this one.

Pros:
Beautiful graphical makeover from the first game.
Improved movement and combat flow, especially melee.
Archetypes and dual-class system are fun to experiment with to fit anyone's play style (handler + challenger is pretty fun so far with a lot of rooms for errors).
Guns, melee, relics, mods have a lot of interesting and fun effects to play around with. 
Addition of mutators on weapons allow for even more customization.
Shooting range, finally.
A lot of familiar faces if you play first games. Glad to see some of them living better lives now.

Cons:
QoL... equipping, unequipping weapons, armors, mods, mutators is quite a hassle still.
Cannot compare items stats side by side in shop or inventory screen. Why??? This is like the most basic feature to have in item-based games.
Secrets, way too many of them now. Some are so convoluted and extreme I don't see myself bothering anymore. Hidden items, I can understand, but some archetypes are even locked behind them. Such key game-defining features should not have been hidden like that. Never felt I had to google so much on a game before.
False walls with 0 indications. You almost have to stumble on them by sheer luck.
Clues (or lack thereof) are super convoluted. Stuck in the first visit to the labyrinth for hours. 
(How should I know I have to shoot the center of the first door to open it? How do I know when to jump through the portal and not die?) - I have to google stuffs way too often and really kills the flow of gameplay sometimes.

Now some potentially controversial takes compared to first game:
I wish they didn't remove armor set bonus.

Sure, they can argue that adding mutators and relic fragments, class skill/perks, allow for more customization. But here's the thing, why not do that, and also keep armor set bonus?
May be reduce the number or dumb down the effect of the set bonus a little to prevent it from being too build-defining. Or just make the bonus for 2 or 3 pieces only to encourage mixing stuffs together.

Now armor is just...cosmetics. You cannot upgrade them. Once you find the balance you want between armor rating and weight (which will happen very soon), there's no more reason to buy/craft anything else. There's no point experimenting with different armors anymore.

Also a minor gripe, I hate to see some of the iconic weapons from 1st game getting locked behind completing campaigns at max difficulty instead of normal unlock through world roll.

It is one of the most satisfying shooters I have played and the ability to customize a build is massive. Right now I am enjoying shotguns that I have setup much more like a sniper rifle.

After sinking over 100 hours, obtaining almost every item, finishing apocalypse difficulty and getting almost every achievement, I honestly feel dissapointed with this game more than anything. And while I can confidently call it a good game overall, I cannot consider it a good sequel.

This is what this review is about. Let me start with positives first:

[h1] Good [/h1]

[h3] Secrets: [/h3]

This game has some of the best secrets and puzzles I've ever seen in a non-puzzle game. You will have to inspect your items, resident evil style, you will have to manipulate the environment, and you will have to actually think. Beware though, a lot of the puzzles are designed as time wasters. If you engage them directly, you'll just be wasting time. Those puzzles require you to ignore the obvious solution and think outside of the box. Also, there are quite a few puzzles that can only be done in coop. So be aware of those.

I just wish they were better spread out, because in jungle worlds, you basically find a new puzzle in every other dungeon, but in sci-fi world there are basically zero of them (there are two technically, but calling them puzzles is being VERY generous), and bloodborne worlds has only few. So since I started in the jungle world, I quickly became burned out by the third puzzle. 

And yes, I will call the locations using the code words (jungle - Yaesha, sci-fi - Nerud, bloodborne - Losomn), for those who haven't played the game.

[h3] Bosses: [/h3]

Bosses are a massive improvement over the first game. Most bosses are really good, with many of them being at least okay and only few of them being straight up bad (one of the bosses has a one-shot mechanic. If you fail to dodge it, it's literally impossible to survive. Simply fuck off with that). Otherwise, bosses have been a pleasant surprise for me. I enjoyed most of them in my time (fuck abomination though) with this game and this is a clear improvement over the first game.

[h3] Build variety: [/h3]

There is a massive assortment of items. There over 80 guns in the game (all of them unique), more than that of rings and 11 classes, which are all fun to play with. 

[h3] Exploration: [/h3]

This game is very rewarding for people who explore every corner. Every location has one randomised item and one level up book, so it's always worth exploring everything fully. Don't forget any loot that is specific to the location itself. And on top of that, every location has few chests with money and upgrade materials which are quite important in this game

So, in short, this game values exploration quite a lot and your curiosity is greatly rewarded

[h3] Map menu: [/h3]

Mini-map is fantastic. I never understood people who complain about having to fiddle with the 3D map. Go back to the first Remnant and dare to tell me that a 2D map is better

[h3] Verticality: [/h3]

Added verticality is awesome. You can now jump when pressing dodge near a ledge. The timing is very forgiving, which is a good thing. Makes exploring vertical locations so much more dynamic.

[h1] Bad [/h1]

[h3] Randomisation: [/h3]

Randomisation of the world was a big selling point of Remnant 1. Everytime you replayed a world in R1, it would change how it's structured and their layout. You would get different dungeons and structures each time. I'm not gonna pretend like the system was perfect, because there was way too little variety in those locations, but it helped with replayability nonethenless

This is pretty much the case with Remnant 2. However, there are few massive differences. First of all, the locations themselves are always the same. The way randomisation works in this game is that you get two versions of overworld. Each has it's own storyline and final boss and visual theme. That's pretty cool. However, the worlds themselves do not change in any way (except for randomised items on the level) and dungeons, which also seem to be always the same with few corridors that randomise

So that means that randomisation was severely downgraded compared to the first game. I understand why they did it, because it's immensely difficult to create randomimasion system that provides layout even half as interesting as manually created content. However, I still find it dissapointing that they simply gave up on the idea of randomised layouts instead of trying to improve on it somehow. 

I wouldn't call it a big deal, however it's still something I thought worth mentioning 

[h3] Optimisation: [/h3]

The game had AWFUL optimisation on launch. Many people couldn't even launch the game, and many people, like me, had to play on lowest settings. The worst part is that some people had perfectly reasonable performance, so it's not even consistent. Even to this day, the game's optimisation is rough. They're making it better with every patch, but the game is still not in the shape it should've launched in.

The worst part however? The game was disagned with use of AI upscaling in mind. I don't like using statements like that, but whoever thought it was a good idea to do that deserves to be fired. Every self respecting programmer in the industry will tell you that designing your game around AI is incredibly stupid idea; And you could see why with the state this game released.
Not only is it stupid because using AI does not make your game run better (so you still have to optimise it), but also because people on older hardware (or any hardware that does not support AI upscaling) will not be able to even play the game.

With recent patches, the game is now playable without AI upscaling turned on (if you were to turn it off at launch, you had to endure actual slideshow), but the game's optimisation is still rough. I'm forced to play on lowest settings despite the fact that my hardware far exceeds recommended requirements.
Not to mention is that the game often crashes for many people. For me, personally, it happens only when I minimize the game

[h3] Artstyle and visibility: [/h3]

I'm sure you've noticed that this game looks very differently compared to the first one. That's right, now instead of somewhat cartoonish bright artsyle, the game has shifted to pseudo-realistic one. 
Now, don't get me wrong, it would be foolish to say that, on the fidelity side, the game looks worse than the first one. However, with the shift in visuals, the game also lost a lot the first game's unique identity. 

The second game is still carried by it's art direction, but the art style itself was turned into generic pseudo realism. This transition made Remnant lose it's visual identity. Artsyle for the first game was very memorable to the point that you now can import a random pseudo-realistic model from sketchfab, and it wouldn't look too different from the rest. With the original Remnant, you'd have to spend a very long time trying to find something that looks similar in artstyle.
I really liked how R1 artsyle struck fantastic balance between being visually diverse and colourful but also keeping the atmosphere of dying, worn out world.
I bet that in few years you will see people making fake bloodborne 2 trailers and using remnant 2 footage for it. Something like that would be impossible with R1 artstyle, but remnant 2's pseudo realistic style is convincing enough, While From fans are quick to recognise their style, a lot of casual players may be fooled.

While you may disagree, which is fine, there's also one major consequence that came from this. The visibility of the game is a lot worse now.
I really liked how clear the visuals were in the first game. Sure, it wasn't perfect, but in R2 it's difficult to see anything even when there's nothing going on. Jungle world is especially bad at that. The second area is way too dark, with red lighting, making it really painful on the eyes to be able to see anything.

Excellent game, perfectly expanded on the first one. The game is filled with depth, each campaign/adventure will be slightly different with variant sections of the same maps and dungeons with loads of secrets so even if you come across the same dungeon on a reset you may find something you missed the first time. I found 3 secret areas in one dungeon across 2 runs, literally secrets in secrets.

The game is souls-like, as is the first, although I didn't find it too hard even starting out on Nightmare. I found it easier than the first game, but there is also Apocalypse difficulty which unlocks when you complete the game, this may be as hard as Nightmare was in the first, haven't tried it yet so not sure.

The multi-player wasn't as polished as I had hoped, I felt as though there was delay that shouldn't have existed, with enemies hitting me before their animation showed they would. I fought the same boss as a host and a client and it was noticeably more delayed as a client. If you plan to play single-player there really isn't an issue, but be warned multi-player may get a little frustrating due to the networking.

If you liked the first you will almost definitely enjoy the second, it is less brutal but the new archetype abilities and perks are super fun to mess with, enabling much more in-depth character builds than before.

Currently at the final boss of The Awakened King DLC, it is a pretty good fight so far although I guess it might be different based on what choices you made throughout the DLC. Only downside I have for the DLC so far is the length, I played 6.1 hours of it and I am currently at the final boss, although there may be dungeons I haven't seen and are definitely some items I haven't obtained, it doesn't seem like it would be more than 10 hours playtime to fully complete it. The new archetype is pretty great looking, haven't fully utilised it yet, but I can definitely see some fun builds already.

All in all, I would suggest this game (and DLC) to anyone who likes souls-like games and anyone who played the first game. It truly is one of the best games to release this year. This is also a pretty great gateway into the souls-like genre as it isn't as harsh as some of the other games in the genre.

The fact that you can also change what kind of relic you have is another phenomenal change from the first game, with a lot of diversity in how they work.

My one real gripe is that it feels like the devs were scared of powerhouse ranged damage so only a few guns are actually worth using on higher difficulties, everything else is basically useless. Skills and Mods overperform in this regard, with some truly nutty builds out there with bonkers amount of damage being pumped out; if they added in more ranged damage specific items or adjusted the numbers on some guns and rings/amulets then it'd be just perfect.

The story is okay. I was pretty happy with the story all around, it wasn't super invasive or anything but there were certain decisions that were made that are just so cheesy and/or questionable. Some missed opportunities as well. I suppose that since there's 3 total guaranteed dlcs coming out that maybe one of them will expand upon certain avenues that the base story didn't explore, but I still feel like that's first and foremost a very long shot since the first one only expands upon side story business and doesn't relate to the main story at all. I suppose only time will tell.

To finish this off, I really do recommend this game, its a blast to play especially with other people and its already provided me with hundreds of hours of entertainment. If you like difficult shooters, then this is definitely worth checking out, especially since the difficulty tiers made me want to blow my brains out while I completed them all. Veteran is probably the highest difficulty you can go while having dumb fun, but Nightmare and Apocalypse are definitely demanding of a strong build and knowledge of fights/game mechanics. So, you know, be prepared. The replay-ability of the content is quite high since there's a lot of gear combinations to experiment with and people can just be a delight to go on a journey with. You can learn from others, and others can learn from you, and I honestly think that's one of the most beautiful things about this game.

Thank you for taking the time to read all of this (if, in fact, you did!) and I hope this has persuaded you in some small way to give the game a try.

Remnant 2 was a bit of a surprise for me. Just like the first game I've sunk a bit under a hundred hours into it -- about eighty at the time of writing -- and have seen a large chunk of the game through two full playthroughs at various difficulties and a lot of adventure-mode content. Here's why this game surprised me though; Remnant: From the Ashes was a good game -- emphasis on good rather than excellent, amazing or any permutation thereof. I've sunk almost a hundred hours into it to get a little over 90% of the achievements just to say that I did and I enjoyed my time with it, but it hardly ranked into a favorite regardless. Remnant 2 provided a much more well rounded experience throughout, and a host of improvements in every single department that has catapulted it into one of my favorite games, and easily my favorite game of 2023. 

Remnant 2, for the unitiated,, is a souls-like that differentiates itself by having a large focus on ranged combat with guns being a strong focal point. It's somewhat more linear than games like Elden Ring, but far less linear than other choices. What makes the Remnant series extremelly replayable however is the level layout; outside of a few "hub" maps, much of the content is randomly assembled together. It isn't a crazy amount, but it's enough to keep gameplays fresh and incentivize multiple runs through the same biomes to collect everything, fight every boss and go through every story. Lastly, I have to mention that there is zero penalty for death which I don't always condone, but in the case of remnant encourages riskier plays and really pushes you to just keep going to the next checkpoint even if you aren't completely topped off. This is highly similar to the first game and nothing too new to make Remnant 2 stand out however.

What does set the second game apart however, is in the details. For starters, each of the five biomes are distinct and have their own palettes, styles and overall "mood". Some are more fleshed out than others -- but more on that later. The sound design is solid and guns feel impactful, enemy sounds are distinct and immersive, and the voice acting is above average across the board. Weapons mostly all feel really good to use, and almost every choice can viable to take through the game (although you can and will struggle on the highest difficulty if you don't optimize things to death). Lastly, every class feels really fun to use, unique, and with the exception of Archon (more on this later as well), is really fun to unlock. Maps are well assembled, flow nicely into one another, and no biome ever feels like it's going on for too long. Bosses rarely feel cheap (a big improvement from the first) and always reward something useful for at least some builds. All around, there's very little I can say about the core of the game that's negative at all. Personally, I really enjoyed the multiple "puzzles" and interactions you can have by repeatting playthroughs -- things like owning a certain medalion you get from one version of the biome into a specific map of another, unlocking a secret treasure room with unique loot. The game is utterly jam-packed with hidden interactions that don't rely on moon-logic to figure out, and reward you with cool, interesting loot, traits and additional trait points.

A few minor gripes however;
- It is far too easy to get staggered halfway to death (looking at you, little spiky jungle balls) with very little recourse if you aren't careful about spacing. 
- Some biomes are leagues behind others in terms of interesting lore. N'Erud feels .. kinda meh in comparison to the beautiful Losomn. Hopefully future DLC adds some more fun in this case.
- Yaesha is kinda recycled from the game. It doesn't feel new if you've played the first and it's kind of disappointing to see it reused this way.
- I won't lie, some builds are just downright overpowered and remove almost all the challenge from the game even at extreme difficulties. The difference that a few missable traits and items can make in a single playthrough is astounding. 

All around, Remnant 2 is phenomenal and a very high recommend from me. It's extremelly fun alone, even more fun with friends, and easily has a hundred hours of content at the time of writing with The Awakened King DLC.

While it did have a few teething issues at launch it is an excellent game overall.  It's still not perfect, and no game is, but it's certainly a game I'd recommend picking up, especially when it goes on sale.  Given the content of the first DLC, I'd also recommend picking up the Ultimate edition just to save a little more money vs. picking up DLC individually.  The game certainly plays better with friends, if you have some to bring, but it's still quite enjoyable solo (and you can always join randoms if you're so inclined).

----------------------------------

Cons:
There is one fixed boss fight (around the 1/3 mark of a story campaign) that I vehemently hate because it's not skill based, but instead feels more like a puzzle boss or quick-time event . . . only one error kills you, no matter what.  Once you know the patterns it makes it a truly trivial, annoying, and tedious matter; but until you fully know the patterns it is infuriating.  Thus, the end result is a loathsome boss fight that I wish was reworked or removed.

Some secrets and event interactions are obscure to the point of absurdity . . . however on the flip side this plays into the greater social aspect where some data is truly meant to be populated to friends, group play, and (most likely) an internet search.

Not everything can be done solo; and on top of that a lot of the game seems particularly balanced towards group play.  While this isn't a big deal for most people, if you are exclusively a solo player it means there is some content you cannot access (puzzles, items, etc.).  Regardless, as mentioned in the beginning, it's still quite playable solo, you're just missing some content and it may feel a little unfair/overtuned at times.

There is some content (items) that cannot be accessed without playing hardcore modes and higher difficulties.  Only mildly annoying for a filthy casual like myself (especially because it doesn't have much that I'm interested in acquiring), but the first game still had the Glowing Fragment store that felt like a better compromise to this concept, as higher difficulties and hardcore mode offered greater Fragment rewards.  However, for anyone that cares, this does not prevent you from getting 100% achievements (as I can directly attest to).

Pros:
The game is loaded with event interactions and secrets.  These will keep you going through adventure runs or giving you reasons to reroll your story mode campaign just to try and find them all.  Whether it's alternate boss kill techniques, specific item interactions, or acquiring a certain relic that requires very specific boss rolls for multiple realms to be in the same story mode.  Some of the interactions are as subtle as new dialog lines for wearing specific equipment when interacting with some NPCs.  As a HUGE boon for the new DLC, they have extended this into the DLC not just via interactions within it, but also via interactions with NPCs and items from the base game.

There is much more build diversity than the first game; and it stands as one of the hallmark improvements over the original.  No longer are build-defining choices locked behind wearing certain armor sets.  Now you can mix and match armor, for aesthetic or practical purposes, with mutators, more accessory slots, and relic fragments providing that special refinement to your build.  While trait points may be limited (the first game let you eventually grind enough levels to max every trait), it actually helps push players in the direction of defining a character and build, rather than just grinding points.  Also, with the purchase of a very cheap item available from the beginning of the game, respecs are unlimited and free (after your initial tiny investment).

Of course the baseline for defining builds, the dual archetype system and all of the choices offered therein actually helps your character feel more like it's playing an actual ARPG ROLE instead of just another variation of the same bullet-spewing character everyone else has.  Whatever you want to play, the system has you covered.  What's even better, however, is how they interact.  You'll get the "Prime Perk" of whatever is your primary archetype, along with all of it's other benefits; meanwhile you'll still get the archetype trait, basic perks, and chosen ability of your secondary archetype.  In addition, because of the character defining abilities of your "Prime Perks", a character using the same two archetypes can play vastly different just by changing which is the primary archetype.  That decision can then influence all of your other build choices to create completely different characters. 

Most importantly, the developers care.  Nearly every major complaint about the game has been addressed in some form or another.  While it's impossible to make everyone happy, I'd argue that nearly everyone is at least happy with some change the developers have made since launch.  The only major nerfs came from grossly overtuned items, bugs, and unintended interactions.  Everything else has been some kind of buff to bring undertuned items/skills/perks/traits closer to the intended baseline performance of a given slot.

----------------------------------

As a final note, if you enjoy the souls-like concept of play, die, learn, improve, and eventually feel the satisfaction of winning, you can't really go wrong with Remnant 2, or even the first Remnant; and I only discovered that underrated gem shortly before the sequel was announced.

Hopefully this review has been found helpful.  Thank you for your time and consideration.

Remnant 2 builds on the foundation of the first game and brings more action and intense boss fights than ever before. I thoroughly enjoyed playing through the mainline campaign and discovering the many secrets hidden throughout the realms. I still believe there is much for me to discover. 

What's great too is that there is an Adventure Mode that promises even more replayability, and the procedural generation of dungeons and various locations are well done enough to make multiple runs feel like unique experiences. Joining in someone's game could mean a pretty different experience from your own.

The archetypal progression system is a welcome new feature and a second archetype can be acquired in tandem, although it is pretty nuanced to obtain. This is a pretty hardcore game in terms of difficulty, gear building depth, and exploration, so it's not the most friendly game for someone looking for a more casual third-person shooter experience. This is indeed like you've heard many times over, Dark Souls with guns.

I would like to point out however, some of Remnant 2's shortcomings. First and foremost, performance mileage may vary. My RTX2060 gaming laptop runs the game just fine, only with occasional hiccups especially during segments of intense combat. If you have a beefy system, you run the risk of optimization issues. My biggest gripe about this however, is Steam Deck performance. I think Steam is too laxed on allowing developers to implement Steam Deck verification when performance on Steam Deck is poor. Remnant 2 is no exception.

Really the only complaint I have outside of Steam Deck performance is the lack of an in-game chat feature. This is a bizarre game design decision, as matchmaking is the prominent means of multiplayer functionality. That means you will pair with random partners unable to speak to them in any tangible way, but by means of a few emotes and a pinging feature. Why is this? I don't know. I have been told this is a staple of Soulsborne games, but it seems like an unnecessary exclusion from the co-op experience. A chat feature would allow you to communicate during boss fights, talk about points of interest, explain what your objective is, make solving puzzles more efficient, discuss gear builds, or even just socialize. Personally, I'd like to see this feature added.

Those are the only gripes. There is an insane amount of gear building experimentation to do with weapons, mods, mutators, archetypes, and more. I have always enjoyed the unique and weird enemy types in Remnant and there are plenty of different enemy types, some more inspired than others, in Remnant 2. I am always excited to step foot in a new realm or location and discover a new wacky set of enemies. The boss fights are engaging and fun to play, some down right infuriating, but satisfying to complete. (Looking at you Annihilation) Locations are brimming with secrets and things to explore. There is no hand holding when it comes to some of these features. Puzzles are cryptic and obtaining quest items can be very obscure, but I think that's part of Remnant's charm. It's full of mystery.

Ultimately, Remnant 2 is worth your time and a delightful upgrade to the original game. 9/10

Remnant: From the Ashes was one of my favorite spins on the souls-like genre that I ever came across in recent years, and Remnant 2 has only been an amazing improvement on an already excellent formula. The worlds are just as, if not more diverse than those of the first game, and the bosses are a truly spectacular step up from an already amazing impressive streak of challenges featured in the first game. 

The game also greatly expands on and explains the lore in a natural way, leaving new players with a solid drop-in point without needing to have played the first game to get the "whole picture." (though I would still absolutely recommend doing so as the first game is a great experience)

There's amazing combat, an interesting and varied story, as well as inventive and rewarding puzzles that one can find all across the game. 10/10 and easily my personal GotY for 2023..

I really wish i could leave a slightly mixed review because the game is great, but it has one very big problem,

First the good: The game is very fun, the enemy types are varied, and the bosses are all quite unique, even if some can be a bit frustrating at times. The landscapes are beautiful, and the random generation is a neat gimmick to give you unique experiences on each successive playthrough.

And now, the bad: The random generation can make it very difficult to get specific instances of specific areas, making acquiring certain items very grindy and obnoxious, I personally don't really mind this, but if it would bother you, now you know. The main problem i have with this game, is whatever they are using to process online connections, because it really doesn't work that well. When playing online, if you are not the host, you will have input delay, and a significant amount of lag. At first i thought it was just on my end, because i have Starlink, but the person i've been playing with also tested this by joining other random people through matchmaking, and the connection was just as bad every single time. Statistically, this means that it is not just my internet or his causing problems, it is something on the end of the developers making the game not play as well online as it could, because it was bad for both of us no matter what we tried, and he has fiber internet. The high amounts of lag also cause frame drops for both of us, but i never got frame drops when doing even more to the game when playing solo, so there's that too.

I do very much enjoy playing this game, but it is very annoying to play online when confronted with the amount of lag that the game currently has. I hope it gets addressed eventually, but until then i don't think you should get the game if you plan on playing online more than solo, but playing solo is perfectly fine.

Solid souls-like shooter game with a very active dev team who have planned for more DLC and are adding free QOL updates to the game, but with a few major caveats to consider before getting the game:

1. Runs are randomly generated, don't expect everything to be hand-placed like in Fromsoft titles because it won't be. This includes bosses having modifiers (from health and damage increase to new abilities/teleportation).

2. The RNG nature means the game will not respect your time. For instance if you want a certain ring/amulet, you may be stacking RNG on RNG (e.g. re-rolling your world to have a chance of having an area which has a chance of having an area that has the item you want; re-rolling a world to get two certain zones to spawn which takes 60-80% of the run to confirm whether the zones spawn or not).

Remnant 2, sequel to Remnant from the ashes, which was the sequel to the VR game Chronos later re-released as Chronos before the ashes, is a souls like game that can be fairly challenging but is also set to let you build your strength over time. You don't have to worry about losing currency, or items you've collected, unless you turn them into something else (and even then you can get the items again with a bit of luck), multiple worlds to explore, with two stories for each and and third story recently added to one of the worlds with the first DLC The Awakened King. The game comes with 4 starter 'archetypes' which you might traditionally think of as classes with the recent DLC bringing the total to 12, but the actually number you have is larger as each archetype can be combined with a second for many different and fun ways to play. Supplementing these archetypes with their built in traits are other traits you can invest into with points you'll accrue as you go through the game, two guns (one long and one  short) and a melee weapon, 4 rings and one amulet as well as customizable  Estus flask equivalents. Basically lots of build opportunities, and this is absolutely a game to play with your friends. Give it a try, it was on sale recently and may be again soon, absolutely worth it along with it's prior games, though chronos is  the odd duck comparatively.
