Remnant 2 is an amazing game that is full of content for you to explore and many secrets to discover. It brings me back to my childhood days where developers actually cared about what they were making and weren't focused on money or deadlines. Each world you encounter will last you an average of 6 hours on your first run, with replayability that will have you going through it at least two more times. There's about 5 worlds for you to explore with more added via DLC. I've logged over 100 hours already just casually trying to collect and level everything. I don't usually leave reviews, but this game deserves it. Hands down my favorite game because the developers are passionate in making this game enjoyable for their players.

[Gameplay]
Remnant was described as a soulslike shooter, and it does it pretty well. There's difficulty modes that caters to varying skill levels so you can find your comfort zone and adjust as you get better. Enemies and bosses are challenging but not impossible to beat as long as you learn to adapt and overcome. Some bosses have really unique fights that will test your mettle. As you progress you will find and unlock many equipment and archetypes (classes) to create a loadout that speaks to you and changes the gameplay to your tastes. If you play with friends things can become even more fun as everyone has their own role to play as well as a few encounters to find. I wish there were more games like Remnant as I can say it is unique in that it does so much right when it comes to gameplay.

[Story]
Remnant 2 leaves off from the first story so I very much recommend trying out the first game which is equally as enjoyable. As per usual souls-like games the lore can be scattered within the worlds via enemies, bosses, books, etc. which you will piece together. Compared to the first game though I find the cutscenes and characters are more prominent so you can get a general idea of what is happening in the world. The story is honestly the only thing that has me a bit "ehhh" as it can feel pretty short/simple and didn't hook me too much, but I guess it's still more than what I'd see in souls games. The beauty honestly is within the worlds and lore you discover. Each world also has its own story to tell and questions to be had. "What happened here?" is a constant thought.

[Worlds (Ranked High to Low]
-Losomn is what my friends refer to as "The Bloodborne World", it has the coolest design and atmosphere set in a medieval style kingdom with a ton of story behind it.
-??? I'll keep this one a secret
-Yaesha brings you back to the good ol' forest world of the first game and has my favorite scenery, cause who doesn't like a land of lush biomes and ruins to explore?
-Labyrinth is a neat and interesting place, pretty simple but the aesthetic is very pleasing and cool.
-N'erud...The story behind it is rather intriguing but I personally disliked the map itself, or at least the overworld. It's an empty wasteland full of annoying monsters. My least liked but I won't say I hate it. Remnant 2 randomizes the map you start in and I'd say reroll your campaign if this is what you get.

[DLC - One True King]
I LOVE THIS DLC. What it adds is so good and very enjoyable, which easily outweighs any possible downside. The only bad I can say is that it reuses a few parts of Lonsomn, but that's why I say it's more of an expansion. It adds alot of extra lore and bits to explore. The new areas are very beautiful and refreshing to see, by far my favorite scenery in the game. The bosses in this DLC are also insane and so enjoyable to fight. My friends and I got wiped quite a few times but we learned and managed after a few runs (and it didn't get annoyingly hard). I'm happy to say the first DLC delivers and I'm happy with the 6+ extra hours of gameplay. 

[Conclusion]
Like I said, I don't usually review games...but this one deserves it. I can't recommend it enough. It's a game made with love and care from the developers. My favorite game that I will always support. I hope you all enjoy it too. When pre-orders were available me and my friends did not hesitate to buy this.

I had gone into this game knowing very little about this franchise or even anything about the game outside of an elevator pitch a friend gave describing this game as souls-like with 3rd person shooter elements set in a post apocalyptic world. Over the course of me playing this game nearly everything I came across, may it be the realms you enter bosses, mods, weapons, and sometimes armor (I wish there was more full sets for fashion purposes and having some more unique benefits but thankfully it didn't detract from my experience) made me more and more hooked with each passing discovery. I have had some issues with performance even with a rtx2080 and needing to use DSLL to make sure my computer didn't overheat (though I'm going to chock it up to me having an oldish cpu which is an intel i7 6700k), but the game for me runs at 60 for the most part on a balanced power setting for my computer and even if it didn't I'd still fully recommend this game. I'll list some detailed thoughts about the game following this, I'm not really the best at describing specifics or rating things on a scale. 

*The asking price of 50-70 dollars is well worth the playtime you should get if you love the game loop of replaying the realms (both with the campaign and in adventures). I've yet to see every encounter or boss yet in the game even 50 hours in and even if you repeat some of them there could be alternate rewards and you still get resources like scrap among other crafting materials so it never feels wasted to do things again. There's also a lot of secrets on top of this, some hiding really good weapons or even classes (I'd suggest looking them up after completing an initial play through of the campaign but I ain't stopping you if you want to get them earlier) so it's always good to be curious about finding secrets or checking things that look out of place.

*I've beaten the game on survivor (the easiest difficulty) and it did still provide some challenge here and there. I'm running the campaign now on apocalypse now and it's really tough/punishing, but I've been enjoying it even when anything could demolish you on a whim if you aren't careful. I'd probably recommend people experienced with souls-like games play on Veteran, and if it's too hard (or easy) you can re-roll the campaign at at any point, you will lose progress story wise but will keep anything you've already gotten.

*Gun play feels great, normal and special weapons both feel useful in their own way due to the mod system and the mutator system really helps to build into how you'd personally prefer to play. While not every mod is insane, I do enjoy experimenting with them and trying them out on different weapons to see which ones pair well with most. You might not see the full extent of it early on since the starting mods are alright, but there are some insane weapon builds you can perform especially with fully upgraded mutators. 

*Classes are all really varied and each feel fun to play (melee feels a little weaker compared to gun play but I still need to play the challenger class). You only start with 4 classes with the remaining 7 being secret classes you unlock either naturally as you play the game or through finding some hard to find secrets that'd feel at home in most souls games. There's more traditional classes focusing on direct combat or through support with providing healing or buffs to allies,
but there's also classes relating to summons, having a dog, focusing on mod energy (which is underselling the class but I still need to get it as of this review), deploying turrets/heavy weapons, running the hell through areas while providing increased material rewards and resources for yourself and allies, and even a class that focuses on evasion and providing decoys to draw enemy attention. That's already a lot, and with each class having multiple active skills to chose between, the game's multi-classing where you can use any two classes you've obtained the engrams for, and adding in the rings and amulets you can equip to further experiment with, there's a lot of opportunities to make great or even weird class combinations that let you play nearly exactly how you want to.

*Enemy combat is fun imo, there's only really one boss I've fought that I'd consider to be lackluster, but overall every enemy and boss has felt enjoyable to learn and I never felt like any single one was unfair or frustrating to fight against. This is the area where I'm not the best at describing what is objectively "good" in terms of encounter design or enemy attacks (even with my experience with Bloodborne and Elden Ring) but at the very least I never felt annoyed with anything. Yes, this includes the final boss which was hard but once I got it down it wasn't so bad (apocalypse will 100% test me and I'm looking forward to it)

*Aesthetically this game has some of my favorite locales in anything I've played recently. This isn't a major point but it did really help pull me in as I continued to play seeing the enemy designs and getting to experience the worlds thoroughly and being intrigued by them, even if individually they aren't as in depth compared to other games, but I just thought it was neat.

*Music is great too, Rob Westwood did an outstanding job on this ost and even if you don't play the game at least give it a listen. He's still uploading tracks to his youtube so it's not all on there yet, other people have been posting rips from the game if there's any that's missing that you want to listen to specifically but his masters are extremely well done.

*In terms of things I wish that were better, the overarching story was serviceable but not my favorite, but it was nothing that detracted from my experience as I enjoyed the smaller stories from each of the worlds and was still intrigued by learning about the lore of the series regardless. That and the relic fragment system could be better explained for upgrading them, but otherwise they're still providing benefits so it could be worse there. Hardware limitations might be the limiting factor for being able to play this game, but if you're okay with using DSLL or any other means to help performance, I think it's worth it, and even with DSLL this game still looks great on balanced and even performance mode (just try not to use high performance mode as that does look wonky at times.)

Overall, I think this game is fantastic, I know I wasn't overly critical of the game and this sort of game isn't for everyone, but I'll admit this game feels like it was made for me specifically as it provided an experience I've been missing from games recently like with Destiny which I have nearly 4000 hours in. If you are still on the fence, buy it for $50 since the deluxe armor isn't game breaking, it's purely for aesthetics as those are from the first game and if you enjoy it buy the dlcs by themselves. If this game does interest you long term at all, I still think $70 is still worth the price and what you get since that will come with the dlcs as they release and if they do keep their word about them being the quality of the worlds already in the game, they should be outstanding. As of now, this is now one of my favorite games I've played in a long time and even as a newcomer to the series, I hope other people enjoy it as much as I have.

Fun Game. You can call it a souls-like, but it is quite forgiving on failure. If you die you just get sent to the last "bonfire" and have to retry the area. Combat feels alright. Using guns feels good and the melee weapons I've used feel impact. Dodging feels great, it is a little worse when you are not the host in multiplayer but I was still able to through attacks pretty consistently.

Plenty of randomization per run to keep things fresh for a bit. After a couple runs it does start to get stale. You start seeing the same areas and you've picked up most of the randomized items. If you liked the 1st game, just buy this. You don't need to play the 1st game anyways.
- Graphics, gameplay, boss fights and everything else are just better. (Less adds in boss fights compared to 1st game, more tactic focussed gameplay)
- They added even more puzzles/secrets into this game, it'll probably take a while for community to find every loot and secret in this game. You just miss like 90% of the loot while playing without checking wiki/youtube.
- You need to restart your campaign or adventure mode to find other dungeons&loot. You can't get all loot in one playthrough. Sometimes it takes hours to find a specific dungeon. This is time consuming. If you like that kind of grind, this is a game for you.
- I still miss probably half the loot but for now I can say that most weapons are meh. Weapons with special mods are fun but only when the mod is active. Most special weapons have bad dps, they're only strong when mod's active. Developers will probably deploy a balance patch later on cause the game is new.
- I haven't encountered any game breaking bugs(Started playing 2 days after the launch) But these are problems I currently have and it seems most people have these;
[i] Played on high settings + 2k resolution / PC specs: 3060ti, i5 9400f, 16gb ram, 1tb hdd, windows 10 [/i]

*FPS drops in certain locations
*0,5second game freeze when looting relics/lumenite crystals or other special loot. This happens 50% of the time.
*Similar 0,5s-1s freezes in some boss fights. They occur randomly, not when boss does an ability or else.

[b]TLDR[/b]
------
-Great game(8/10). If they make some weapons more fun, my score will be 9/10 for sure.
-Hundreds of hours playtime cause of randomly generated world and loot. Worth the full price.
-If you like shooter games with puzzles/secrets like Destiny 2, just buy this now. [spoiler] There are some Destiny influenced weapons in Remnant 2 - Atom sword(Black talon), Enigma(Anarchy) [/spoiler]
-It's more fun in Co-op so bring some friends if you can :P

Tl;dr - If you liked Remnant: From the Ashes, this game is a hundred percent just more of that. I say that as a positive thing. If you did not like the previous game, you won't like this one, but if you're like me, and loved the first, you'll love this sequel too.

Pros:
- High amounts of customization in terms of your equipment and build, with the ability to attain traits individually, slot in secondary classes to broaden your playstyle, and equip your weapons with slottable abilities and modifiers. Your main healing item has varied versions with different abilities now as well, with its own modifier slots.
- High amounts of replayability with the randomly rolled level layouts that you, yourself, can reroll at any given time without risking your progress. You can even roll a separate one-shot version of worlds you cleared, for bonus loot or bosses you might have not fought.
- Art design is excellent. Environments are gorgeous, enemies look varied and cool, as do your equipment.
- Music is borderline surprising in how great it is; so much so that it can feel TOO heroic for some fights.
- Exploration is rewarded, and there's fun side paths, secrets, and puzzles to find and solve for goodies (including entire playable classes you can unlock for your current and subsequent new playthroughs).
- Controls are nice, snappy and responsive.
- Probably the most candid reactions I've seen out of a protagonist ever in this type of multiple-dimension spanning story, and it's bizarrely comforting to see.
- Incredible amounts of worldbuilding, which, considering the theme of visiting a variety of worlds, is just even more impressive.
- Lots of difficulty options to choose from to finetune the amount of challenge you'll face.

Cons:
- Resources can get sparse to come by, and unless you plan on leveling one single set of weapons without ever branching out into others, you'll be kind of expected to do reruns for upgrade materials and currency.
- The story gets incredibly hard to follow as there is a lot thrown at the player, and the game seems to expect at least cursory knowledge of the previous titles. All the visited worlds having their own things going on only adds to the confusion and creates a narrative tonal whiplash every few hours, unless you can at least partially detach yourself from it.
- Game still suffers from "but what if there were six million adds bumrushing you" syndrome in a lot of bossfights which still feels a bit cheap.
- Some elite enemies may get buffed to become minibosses, gaining a distinct boss healthbar and seemingly randomly rolled buffs. These minibosses often prove to be worse than actual level bosses, mostly due to placement and the traits making them less a fun fight and more a damage-sponge endurance run. (When a big axe guy spawns in a water-filled thin corridor and spawns rats you can't see from the water, which also makes you unable to dodgeroll, you'll get what I mean.)
- There are reports of performance hitches at inopportune times, though I'm assuming these won't stick around after patches or hotfixes.

All in all, if you enjoy third person shooters and Soulslikes, Remnant 2 is perfect, just like Remnant: From the Ashes was. It can be a hit or miss, but if its a hit for you, then it'll be an extremely long-running, fun one to experience.

Fantastic improvement over Remnant 1 in pretty much every way.

Much better boss fights.
More ring/amulet choices that are usable.
Much better world design and exploration with creative and interesting secrets to discover everywhere in the game.
Actual class variety (that can be freely swapped mid-game) with multi-classing as well.
Great side-story/dungeon content.
Actually good use of enemy mini-boss variants.

Downsides:

Not too many traits this time with a low trait cap, and no free re-spec (the only thing that isn't a free re-spec for some reason). Having to choose is nice, but I kind of wish you could get a weaker version of all traits to give something long term like in Remnant 1. Especially with some of the very use-case limited like "movement speed out of combat" or "weapon handling".
No armor abilities this time around (or mutator slots like guns have now), so they are just for basic damage resistances and roll speed.
Only 3 main worlds that actually re-roll, so though there is a ton there, the visual variety throughout the game takes a hit.

The actual main story sucks and Clementine seems like a mary-sue. Ends on a crappy cliff hanger; thankfully the side worlds are much more interesting.

Performance is bad. I have the newest AMD card and it still has some framerate issues.


Neutral:
The post-completion difficulty still just obsoletes too much of the games design with builds...  but thankfully it doesn't seem to give anything, so it's completely for funsies.
Edit: it does have unlocks, whoops. Thankfully, not as obsoleting as I thought. Unfortunately the "neutral" stays here, as you need to re-beat the entire campaign in the hardest difficulty, as well as separately in hardcore on any difficulty (cube boss makes this a risky chore), to unlock them all. Not a huge fan of that with how collect-it-all themed the rest of the game is.

Final boss is cool but a massive difficulty spike, and not that fun to fight (also no melee for you melee builds, again).

Re-roll variety is neat, but it seems like there are only two real setups for each world. Still good, but with only 3 worlds it's a bit of a shame.
4 base classes; there are a lot more, but most of them are very hidden. And very late game for some, so you'll only be using them on a new game for sure.


Overall, it's fully worth the price (at least 50 dollars, won't know for the DLC until that happens). For many, Remnant 1 was an average game; Remnant 2 is a massive improvement and an actual great game, and I highly recommend it (single or co-op).

Edit: First DLC is good!

Update as of October 27, 2023: The game has received quite a few optimization patches and is now in a significantly better state than when it first launched. At launch I needed to use DLSS Performance mode in order to get 1080p60FPS on even the Low settings preset. This is with tech that is one generation ahead of recommended. Now I can obtain 1080p60FPS on High/Ultra (more unstable at Ultra) while using DLSS Quality. To make that much of a leap in a few months time is good. I can now actually recommend the game to people. Even though my playtime is low, it really is just more Remnant. I dumped at least 50 or so hours into that game, maybe more. My issues now lie in why GfG did not delay the game to now if it needed this extra time for optimization and have an otherwise smooth launch. 

Playtime: 15 hours for the first campaign run. 

But, putting that aside, if they can carry this diligence and momentum moving forward, then the game can definitely surpass it's predecessor. The boss fights are good with interesting mechanics, the game is incredibly pretty, the guns feel good to shoot, melee feels a bit better than Remnant 1, and everything seems well balanced. There have been some massive damage glitches found since this review released, but those were patched.

Some of the bad sides of this game lie in it's boss fights. Some of them are too chaotic and it can be downright aggravating. The final boss is especially notorious for this. It is nigh impossible to actually try to deal damage because you have to constantly look at where the next attack is coming from. Though that seems to be a consistent problem with many of the Souls games and Souls-likes. Some archetypes (read: classes) also feel kinda...useless? One of them is definitely more so meant for farming, but it's also required to be leveled to max in order to get another archetype, which just isn't fun because it doesn't actually do much. It's just, there. My other issue lies with keys. Keys keys keys! Single-use keys! Dumbest crap ever. I understand wanting people to go back through the world again to get the other items, but without a way to give up some sort of currency to focus a specific dungeon, it feels like a huge ass waste of time. I know, I know, explore every corner, but still. That's a lazy excuse. 

My other large issue lies in how this game updates. I know the engine it runs on is the major pain point but I practically have to uninstall then reinstall every update because it requires the size of the game + the size of the update itself in order to patch. And with a 70gb+ game? Yikes...

Update for DLC 1: The first expansion released and is absolutely wonderful. It took me about 6-8 hours to complete. The final boss fight was good. Though I do take issue with the way the boss weapons drop. I think the way they did it was a bit wonky. The new archetype is great for status effect builds, and when paired with a hidden archetype (who I still need to get) + one of the new weapons, I'd imagine you can make some really damn good DPS setups. All in all, I'd say worth it. Especially if you like the world of Losomn it can be a pretty cool expansion to go through. 


Old review start: Good game, requires upscaling to even run properly (extensively tested this). Oh and the devs even admitted it: "But for the sake of transparency, we designed the game with upscaling in mind (DLSS/FSR/XeSS)." Skip if you don't meet recommended specs, don't like the look of upscaling, or didn't like the first (as it's more of the same, just polished).

My personal game of the year. Remnant 2 is my dream game, being an excellent soulslike ARPG that manages to cut out its own niche in a genre that mostly just focuses on the "Souls" part of that title. If you want a unique take on the genre made with passion and love, this is a good one to take a look at.

Pros: As mentioned above, build variety is a very strong part of the game. If there's a mechanic that you like interacting with, Its near guaranteed that you will be able to hyper fixate on it to a horrific degree. Want to spend the entire game with an overshield that doubles your health? go for it. Want to poison your enemies to death by dodging? morally questionably but doable. With the release of the first dlc, an item was introduced that constantly hurts the player, which in turn can be used with other items that activate on taking damage to give them infinite uptime. The possibilities are massive with the systems in place, and they tie perfectly into the gunplay, which I don't have much to say about other than it feels nice and snappy.

I also find the world building of the game to be very fascinating. The three main worlds you'll be interacting with, N'erud, Yaesha, and Losomn all take place in unique settings facing their own personal end of the world, and exploring through the areas while slowly finding out about the decaying societies around you is a wonderful experience if you like that sort of thing.

Mixed: This game is very big on secrets. We're talking "wear a very specific loadout to unlock a hidden door to unlock a secret subclass." kind of stuff in the worst case scenario. Personally, I love that stuff, and the developers have stated it was designed to be solved via dataming since thats a part of the community you won't be able to avoid, but if you're just wanting to go through it on your own while still wanting to see as much content as possible, it can be frustrating when you find out you needed to learn algebraic theory in morse code in order to get  the final piece of a build you're going for.

Semi-combined with this is gear progression. Levels being randomly generated means that theres some items you just won't see during a playthrough. The game emphasizes multiple runs through an area, but if you hate that kind of thing then its not going to be very good.

Cons: While I said I love the world building, I can't say the same for the main story. Its... written? I think? An integral character from the first game shows up at the start, sets the plot in motion, and then just disappears for the rest of the game. Unironic "I must go now, my people need me" kinda of deal. The rest of the main story has to deal with two other characters magicking up a solution to the earth's apocalypse while you go and stumble through some other worlds. There's interesting lore implications, but anything approaching character depth has no time to flourish and is incredibly shallow. 

What doesn't help is that alot of writing for human characters is written like marvel characters. Very quip heavy and irreverant, which can work for some characters but when its shoved in your face can get annoying fast. Its mostly just a problem in the opening section, but there is one character that is really hurt by it; the player character. You can only take so many "Pretty. Yeah, I don't trust this place"s before you lose it. There's a decent amount of voice options, but I can't help myself from wishing that there were fewer voices with unique personalities.

Despite these problems, I do still find Remnant's universe (universes?) to be highly engaging. I love this game, and I am excitedly awaiting to see where it goes in the future.

I want to give this a positive review, I do, but there a few things that stand out as steps backwards that stop me from doing so. In [strike]brief[/strike] summary, if you are directly coming to the game after Remnant: From the Ashes, you'll find a good handful of things familar, and foreign at the same time.

-Armor no longer has set bonuses or any benefits at all attached, side from armor rating and weight, not unlike traditional souls / souls-like titles. If you aren't fresh from Remnant: FtA, this is basically a non-issue, but for veterans used to throwing together armor sets, or cobbled pieces of several sets, its a bit jarring, especially considering that Leto's Armor has been downgraded from armor that basically gives you enough poise to rival [i]Havel the Rock[/i], let alone [b]surpass him[/b], into armor that just, makes you belly flop with minimal upsides, there is a disconnect. Of course, maybe there's a way to turn that into a positive with trinkets or a certain archetype, but I've yet to find that for myself.

-There is a hard cap on trait points that can be attained, est.. 65. Under most aspects this isn't important, since traits in Remnant: FtA, while powerful, merely acted as backdrop bonus utilities to supplement extra damage absorption, or stamina, or an extra source of crit. There are 50 traits in FtA, and each can be leveled to 20, giving you a whopping trait level of [b]1,000[/b]. This sounds powerful, yet remember, traits only go to 20. As a result, you can reasonably get your preferred traits maxed before extra ones you encounter in say, the Corsus and 2923 DLCs. [i]Backtracking back to Remnant II however[/i], since the maximum trait limit is 65, part of the character building process turns into a min-max perspective. Do you [i]really[/i] need that extra stamina? Is that extra little investment of Mod Generation really gonna help?
 
Admittedly, thats the main two gripes going from main game to sequel, but I will throw in one more caveat for the record; [b]namely, that campaign is now slightly random on initial and subsequent rolls[/b]. Specifically what this means, is that you have a chance to be initially sent to not just one linear campaign start, but rather potentially [b]3[/b].

If you are like me, saw Challenger at archetype selection and thought, "Ooh hey, Scrapper returns from FtA!" and then went through the rest of the lil prologue only to get thrown into N'Erud, where all the initial enemies are hovering robots, who fire homing projectiles that are very much capable of stagger-juggling you until a Specter spawns in, and, having spent all your attention on these flying Apple products, get one-shot killed in a small cinematic (which I'll admit, is kinda cool if you experience it by accident/underestimation).. well, that's how the road got paved I guess.

I got over that slump with careful consideration that the guns Challenger started with, were [strike]absolute dogs***[/strike] simply not meant for that zone, and proceeded to buy the LMG from Brabus, solving basically every problem since that point.

Oh, I almost forgot as well. This is the first game I ever bought, and played, which caused my GPU to cycle its fans hard enough to generate enough lift to act as an Amazon Delivery Drone. I have never seen any other game spike my card's temperature to 80 Celsius. Consider that a warning if you have a 3090 or less.

TL;DR - It has a weird stink that makes going from the first remnant to this difficult, mind your graphics settings, and do not pick Challenger as your starting archetype unless you're willing to gamble you get a starting point in campaign that suits it well, and do not, under any circumstance, f*** around with enemies you do not understand, cause you will undoubtedly find out.

This game is like Souls meets Destiny. It's a ton of fun, especially when doing co-op with friends! There is also a lot of replay value due to the roll and RNG systems that determine the loot and bosses of a world. You could play through the game several times and still not encounter every boss, tile, or piece of loot. The build crafting and difficulty settings are also well executed, and are very fun to master, furthering the replay value. 

The only downside is that the game doesn't run amazing on older hardware, especially on graphics cards incapable of using DLSS (My 1070 runs the game between 30 to 60 FPS on the lowest settings, depending on the area and how much is going on). The Devs have been adding optimization updates though, so hopefully this gets better over time. Other than that, I'd highly recommend this game to anyone looking for a great Co-op looter shooter experience.

I have a hate and love relationship with this game. Lets talk about the good parts first.

The combat is awesome. The ability/classes + weapon mod system is nice and gives you quite a lot of choices. It just feels fun to shoot a fire tornado at the enemy and destroy them with it.
Even some of the boss fights are quite interesting(not all of them tho). And i had the most fun playing it coop with my friend. I would say it is actully one of the better coop games. The story in the 3 different worlds are also quite interesting(not the main story sadly) and i think the areas look very nice.

Now i am coming to the bad part... This game made me so mad sometimes. Not because of difficulty or combat. I was mad because of the absolute stupid RNG in this game + annoying secrets.
I actually like secrets in games and they are quite fun to find out sometimes but i think they overdid it here with the secrets.
After i finished the campaign with my friend, i went to the wiki to see if i missed things. And there is a lot of stuff you will miss just because of RNG because some items and zones don't spawn always. I gonna be honest...i dislike this RNG system a lot. I saw items that would make my build so damm good but farming them was the most horrible experiance i ever had.

And to top it all off they hid one of the most fun classes behind a datamining challange(from what i read)???
It took me hours to get that class just because you had to lvl other classes for it as well. And you had to farm specific items for it. I also just wanna mention that one of the classes needed is also hidden behind a secret that requires you to have a special weapon. I can't believe they would hide such a fun class behind so much horrible grind. Basically no normal player will find this class unless they google a guide. I think hiding a class like that is stupid in my opinion. 

What i want them to change:

I hope they change how you get this class in the future for other players.
Because a normal player who just explores a lot will never find this hidden class without a guide.(trust me you won't)
I think they should add a system that makes random world drop items more likely to drop the thing you don't have yet. (because who wants to reset a world 20+ times just to get 1 item)

Aside from that... the main story was kinda lame. It didn't feel like a victory to kill the end boss. But the rest of the game is pretty nice.

I would recommend buying it when its on sale.

This was my most anticipated game of the year, following my enjoyment of R1 in 2021. Often referred to as "Dark Souls with guns," this game is a decent comparison. However, it truly excels in its co-op experience, surpassing its predecessors. Playing with a couple of friends enhances the fun, and the constantly changing worlds offer ample opportunities for exploration and enjoyment. While it's also enjoyable to play solo, the game shines when played with friends.

Secrets lurk around every corner. I rarely complete 100% of a game, but this one makes it an engaging pursuit. Tackling the game on its hardest difficulty is a true joy and ranks as one of my favorite gaming accomplishments.

The game has had its share of bugs, but the developers have been exceptional. They actively engage with the community on Reddit and Discord, acknowledging issues promptly. Their responsiveness and consideration of player feedback in updates truly set them apart.

For context, I played through to the ending co-op on nightmare difficulty. I'm going to say mostly negative things in this review but I want to preface this with I did genuinely enjoy the game and believe their is more good than bad and by a large degree, but the bad stuff is pretty bad...

Co-op, Difficulty and Builds. This game has some of the most penalizing scaling I've ever seen. Google up the chart for scaling to see exact number but as an example on nightmare difficulty, non boss monsters have 2.5 times health but do 3.5 times damage, this basically makes all but armor builds very difficult and niche. I understand that this is the harder difficulty but this isn't even the hardest difficulty and its not a problem of me 'getting good', it just means that you are effectively exempt from using builds because you can be stunlocked into being killed from regular mobs. Weapons suffer from scaling as well, a weapon that would otherwise be viable is gated from being not leveled up. Resources in your first 2-ish play throughs will be scarce as you can only upgrade 1 weapon at a time and you don't have a good idea as to what weapons will be found throughout the game without looking them up. And to make leveling weapons even worse, the game scales with the highest level of your weapons and classes, meaning that if you find a weapon you are not only doing less damage because you haven't leveled the weapon up, but the enemies also scale with how strong the weapon you just stopped using. Bosses luckily don't have their damage scale as much as their health scales but that's because they have higher base damage, causing you to die from full health using the tankiest build possible at certain points in the game because of stagger. All of the damage you take and the way that upgrading weapons works punishes you for trying anything new and this trend continues with classes. Co-op seems to increase enemy health and damage, but I have been unable to find out the amount.

Classes and XP. When you pick a class, the game doesnt tell you that you get the weakest skill and have to spend up to 10 hours in game to unlock the third skill in the class, you dont get to pick what you want from the beginning and you have to just deal with having the weaker ability and less attribute points. Farther into the game you will find more classes and want to use them but have to go through the boring process of leveling it up which will require that you give up something like 10-40% of your weapon damage and use likely a less interesting ability so that you can unlock the one you actually want. 

The writing. oh..my...god... Without using spoilers, I think a developer inserted their OC into the game and made them them the macguffin for the plot, and because its not a plot heavy game, that means that about half the story is just about this npc being magically important for basically no reason. The world has very good lore and some of the side characters that are "unimportant" are the more interesting characters. I would also argue that the established lore and story from the first game is effectively retconned into being mostly irrelevant which personally makes me angry at basically all of the writers for this game that had to do with the overarching story of Remnant 2. The writing is by far the worst part of the game by a big margin.

Combat. Remnant 2 has this problem where youre supposed to dodge animation windups and not attacks. When you see an enemy thats the size of a school bus, you would inherently thing that they have slow large attacks or ranged attacks, players will expect this without knowing they expect this, the enemies do not do this. if an enemy has a big sword and slams it on the ground, you would naturally think that you have to dodge the sword. In Remnant 2 the giant sword has no weight in animation, the windup is longer than the swing for arbitrary reasons, if you were to swing something, it is impossible for the swing to take less time then the windup, but not in remnant 2. If you look up a video of the final boss, the windup for their attack is 2-3 times as many frames as the actual swing, with the swing being roughly 100 milliseconds and the duration for I frames in your dodge is about 300-500 milliseconds, meaning that you dont dodge the attack, you dodge the windup animation. This seems like another "get good" situation but this does have negative impact on gameplay, with enemy design requiring you remember attack windups and dodging attacks by reaction becoming arbitrarily more difficult, you are effectively required to be hit by an enemy to learn how to evade them, meaning that its not actually a "skill issue", its more of a "remember this thing after you see it" issue.

Having owned Remnant From the Ashes since launch on Xbox, I wasn't sure about the second. But after playing it, it took everything about the first game and dialed it up to 12. classes *actually* matter now, due to having skills/powers/perks that can only be used while they're equipped. That alone is a massive game changer. But in terms of the world as well? absolutely massive in comparison to the first. Like the first it's semi-open world. You can't really do things out of order like a Bethesda game, but there's enough loot and hidden rewards that exploring is absolutely worth your time. There's also much more variety in terms of relic and build options.

couple major "downgrades" vs RFTA, however:
    You can't max your traits like the first game. there's a trait point cap. so spend wisely. thankfully they can be reset with a consumable that's fairly inexpensive (for the late game it's built for, the mats are pocket change). So no god mode with maxed everything like you can in FO4, for example.
    Armor is no longer upgrade-able. You get what you get and that's that. Haven't gone into any re-rolls yet, but you're only able to upgrade your weapons this time around. They have added the ability to downgrade weapons/items however. So no more +14 hunting rifles you never use anymore, can downgrade to base level for 100% mats and 50% scrap and flip it into that new toy you picked up.

Pro-tip - Your starter class doesn't actually matter much at all. But if you're going to be playing solo, your best bet to start is the Handler. That fur missile will come in clutch during the boss fights (and can be leveled to unlock an improvised medic ability with passive AOE heals, albeit slow)

A remarkable step up in story-telling and in animation from previous games like Fallout 4 (which was already good)!  I especially like the character interaction, which is also a long step forward from the previous games I've played.

Co-op third person shooter dark souls and that is a very good praise. The puzzles are interesting because I think it's dynamic so you are asked to commit more of your attention to solve it. A vague message might asked you to find a certain building for example, and there is no indication as to which building is the correct one. I like when games respect your ability to puzzle solve, even thought that puzzle just ends up being find 3 glowing numbers in the room. The variety of weapon types and builds, if we also include the different classes and multi-class, are staggering. The weak part of it is just the armor part because only the weight of it matters. It creates this weird contrast where you have all of this options to slot your weapons and healing items but there is no love given to the armor customization. I was expecting armor specified for medic to increase the amount of healing or something but alas. The combat is amazing and the boss are all very unique. Although the biggest star, in my opinion, is the different worlds that you get to explore semi-randomly. All of them are beautiful and different in their own way. My favorite is the Bloodborne dimension, a victorian looking city filled with twisted villagers, huge rats, and a ghostly figure roaming around. What is cool is that the boss that you encounter and their drops are also random, meaning that you could not completely see the story of that dimension in a single playthrough. You are incentivized to either do multiple playthrough or help other people in their dimension. The fact that the developers made something that might not be seen by the player if you only played it once is cool to me. The only big problem that I can think of is that the narrative is all over and I don't know what to feel of the story by the end of it. Definitely ignore the story and come for the gameplay.

Solid game.
Honestly one of my favorites.
Vast improvement over the first Remnant, that was also a great game.

The good:
Great variety is zones and dungeons that are relativity randomly generated with expected repeats.
Branching story and dynamic choices make multiple playthroughs a must (in a good way).
Loads of meaningful secrets to unlock new gear, classes, areas and more.
Difficulty feels fair most of the time, you find yourself adjusting play style to the world and your gear.
Healthy variety in builds, mods, traits, classes etc, builds have a lot of depth.

The not so good:
Gun handling is solid though not the best I've ever played.
Melee combat is/was more a meme, many mobs/bosses you can't kill with melee.
Lack of an actual jump is disappointing, maybe Remnant 3 will have a jump.
Inventory management can be frustrating with no quick reference. Such as the dozens, maybe over a hundred rings that you have to mouse-over each one to know what it does.
Armor is pretty bare bones, not a lot of option and you can't modify or upgrade them.

After you unlock most of the gear and areas the game can get pretty grindy, but that could be a good things so you have something to keep doing.

Playing with friends is great, though the added scaling on the mobs is very high. Would not necessarily say the game is easier with friends.

There's way more

Overall, great game, highly recommend!

Very fun. I had just as much fun playing alone as I did with friends. The game isn't stupidly unbalanced when playing with friends too. Early on, I needed my co-op partner to use less upgraded weapons to not overpower everything, but after a few hours of play, you upgrade your guns, find cool items, gain new abilities and any balance issues went away. This seems like the kind of game that will go on sale fairly regularly, definitely worth a purchase.

I adore these kinds of games that don't punish you for playing how you want to play. It's just as fun to play on your own, level up your items, guns, abilities, etc, then have a friend join and just keep playing. There's no "Oh, but I'm level 500 and you're only level 5, so we can't play together".

The first few hours can be confusing, and the first characters you are introduced to are the opposite of interesting, but it all kinda goes away as you explore the different worlds and characters and you figure out what you're supposed to be doing, and which characters are worth listening to and which characters you should embrace your inner iPad baby within during.

I played pretty much all afternoon after purchasing, and I imagine I will play for many more hours after writing this review.

Recommended specs is a lie. I was running on a 4060 and a 13400f and couldn't get a stable 60 fps without dropping to 720p or setting the graphics to low. Unreal Engine 5 is hot garbage, just don't buy a game that uses it unless you have at least a 4070 or equivalent.

Being able to play nearly every game at max settings at 1080p with a constant 60fps is great until you run into a game like this and you wonder what in the world would make a dev want to cripple their game with UE5's complications and higher spec requirements.

Playing this game on an i5-2500k, 16GB RAM, 2x SSDs and a GTX1070-Ti and it still runs 30-50FPS. Hardware wise, this game can be played with an older machine but the learning curve was so punishing on the first playthough as a medic that I had to give in to the companion/hunter class and play with a massive crutch. By the time I started to understand how to use most of the player combat and various weapons, I hadn't gotten to level 10 with 18-20 hours. 

Beating this game was not all that fun because of the over-the-top boss maneuvers leaving little time to understand what is happening before dieing repeatedly. I never "rage quit", but I certainly stopped having fun and didn't watch and video or guides on how to "win".

The game is built on a long grind for class unlocking to use skills and it's very repetitive; I don't find a lot of replay value here even with DLC. I would not buy this game again even with the stunning visuals, the content is the same story line. I would rank Fable 2 over this game any day.

I've got doctor diagnosed GADD. This is a rare disease which if you hadn't guessed it already is gaming specific attention deficit disorder. I'm cursed to hop from game to game to game, never completing a title and only sampling the potential experiences that lie beneath the purchases that fill the depths of my bottomless library. 

I've accepted my fate living with this disease. One day I mindlessly purchased this game as I often do scrolling through new releases. If a new release has passable reviews, then it's going to go into my library. It's just the way it is.

Installing and opening Remnant II... something happened that I never expected. My fried receptors in my brain started firing off endorphins in numbers that I've not experienced in years. The last time I felt something like this was when I popped a pill that had a pokeball imprinted on it that I was slipped shadily at an electronic music show. 

Needless to say, I've completed this game and I'm fully intending to complete any subsequent DLC that is released from this point forward. It's a "game-changer" as one might say.

Everything about this game exceeded my expectations and provided me an experience I had long given up on receiving from a modern release. 

If you skip over this one, you're doing yourself a disservice and I can only say that I feel sorry for you. 

Money and time well spent.

The End.

Woke nonsense from the start with multicultural mary-sues and weak males bumbling through dialogue in their absence.  Story is completely fragmented giving scattered notes and NPCs that offer hints through labored metaphor and vagueness to the point of annoyance within a few minutes.  Gameplay is painfully janky between melee and ranged with items and equipment that give the illusion of choice in "builds" that handle with the same hitboxes as Dark Souls.  Enemies that rely on inflated HP values and crowded hallway ambushes to hide terrible AI pathing and attack patterns.  Bosses have 'quirks' that boil down to bullet sponges with different flavors of "memorize charge-up and spam dodgeroll".  

It's a lesser copy of Dark Souls that sells on ranged combat that's about as fun or innovative as grafting it onto an existing Dark Souls clone with enemies that have no concept of avoiding damage as they attempt to fire back or lumber toward you or bosses that occasionally jerk left/right when you aim at them giving you just enough time to shoot a couple of times as your stamina recovers so you can dodgeroll into the next attack cycle.

Remnant 2 is everything I want in a game, and is a definite improvement on Remnant From the Ashes. The combat is fun, the online multiplayer is well-done, and there are some amazing boss fights. Plus, there are so many secrets and hidden puzzles that you will stumble upon a bunch of new content every play-through. My only complaints are with the new DLC, because the DLC area specifically has some performance issues on multiplayer, and it seems a bit improperly balanced for late game builds, so go in with a new character for the best experience.

Remnant 2 is a fantastic atmospheric shooter with souls-like element when it comes to mob and boos design, great gunplay and responsive combat. If you liked the first game chances are you are going to love this one, because the devs have gotten everything good about it and greatly improved upon it in the sequel.

There is a dual-class system which in combination with the amulets and rings allow you to build differently depending on your preferred play-style. You can be pure dps ranged, summon minions, blast your way through with spell-like abilites and mods or even go melee. You can even build as a tanky healer that heavily supports your team-mate and still be able to dish respectable damage due to the clever perk system. You have active and passive skills, mods, mutators for your guns and melee weapons, rings and amulets with passive skills/buffs, traits... you name it.

There is healthy variety of mobs, elites and bosses that are carefully crafted to fit in each of the different biomes, all with different attacks for you to learn to master the combat. The bosses really shine when it comes to variety of attacks and mechanics, and provide nice challenge on higher difficulties. 
 
The levels are masterfully crafted, there is quite deep lore and history to all the worlds which you can piece together from NPC dialogues, interactions with notes and item descriptions. There is a lot of replayability due to the random nature of the level generation where certain items or events might or might not spawn and some items might be used in different ways to get certain loot. World bosses can be killed alternatively similar to the first game so you can get different loot in forms of weapons and mods, which is a strong incentive to replay certain biomes. The Adventure mode is an excellent way to target-farm items without resetting your campaign progress, or just to visit again a favourite world if you need some variety.

The co-op play is fantastic, as a guest to your friend's game you do not share campaign progress due to the random nature of the level and quest generation, but you fully share the loot. You can have a random event spawn in your world and host for your friend to have the associated loot and vice-versa since every world has one of two main quests that will lead you through different paths and on top of that there are the random events and dungeons that might or might not spawn on this playthrough. I was a bit sceptical at first since I am not a big fan of random generated  content, but the devs have actually implemented random generation extremely well here.

One of the best games that came out this year, strongly recommend.
